[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This presentation, shortly, we will project for you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The MSBA building process, and I want to thank all of you who have been supporting this work, and I know

[Edouard-Vincent]: people may wanna know where are we as a district in this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is just to give you just a brief update on that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Medford Public Schools has been accepted formally, we announced it into the Massachusetts School Building Authority, MSBA eligibility process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you can see in the table that's being displayed, it's that first blue box.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is a significant first step to determine the future of Medford High School's physical structure.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A little more background information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This journey began for us a little bit ago.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The MSBA Statement of Interest, our SOI period, it opens annually.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for districts across the Commonwealth to submit applications to MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford submitted another application in the spring of 2023, last year, and provided updated facility information in the fall of 2023.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Just in December, late December, the Medford public schools was formally invited into the eligibility process, period that first blue box by the MSBA Board of Directors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are officially seven steps that each district needs to go through.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are currently at step number one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So under the eligibility period for Medford Public Schools, our eligibility period begins on May 1st, 2024.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we still have a little bit of a runway, but it begins May 1, 2024, and it's for 270 days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, that'll run from May 2024 into the beginning January-ish of 2025.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That will be our first eligibility period.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a certification of the school district's understanding of the grant program rules by executing an initial compliance certification.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Later today in the agenda, there will be a resolution regarding the formation of a school building committee, which is also a critically important step in meeting the requirements during this eligibility period.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While the MSBA allows for local communities to govern the overall composition of the school building committee, there are specific roles that are required.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The district must complete an educational profile, a questionnaire to keep MSBA informed of what's happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have to talk about our current

[Edouard-Vincent]: and proposed educational facilities, we have to share with them the teaching methodologies that we use in Medford, discuss our grade configurations, and all of our program offerings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of those things are required during the eligibility period.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will also provide a summary of the school district's existing infrastructure repair practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have to agree on the enrollment estimates, along with MSBA, because that's critically important when they're thinking about the size of the new facility, and the community is required.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to authorize spending by a vote during step three so eligibility period is step one step two is forming the project team which is still part of the eligibility period but also transitioning that's step two and um

[Edouard-Vincent]: During step two, one thing that's important is although we were invited and we are going to work to complete all of the eligibility requirements, it does not definitely guarantee us a spot in the MSBA's capital project pipeline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's critically important that we do not miss any of our deadlines, that we meet all of the deliverables, all of the requirements during the 270 day window, in order to be able to move forward to the next phase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we do not, for whatever reason, hit all of the deliverables, then as a district, we would have to go back to resubmit another statement of interest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we don't want that to happen at all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are determined to hit all of the deliverables ahead of the deadline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So step two is forming the project team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's what you see, the blue and the green rectangle.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at that time, one of the key pieces that will, key individuals that will be needed is the owner's project manager, OPM.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the owner project manager provides project management and guidance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is a new position that we will need to seek and hire to have someone be the OPM of the project.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That happens during step phase two, step two.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Step three is the feasibility study where they actually look at the initial space summary, look at the district's programs once again, look at existing school conditions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a lot of look at parameters.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they go through all of that during step three, the feasibility study.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and approval by the MSBA Board of Directors is required for all projects to proceed to the next phase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After step three, or phase three, we move to phase four, which is the schematic design.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Step five is funding the project.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Step six is the design, development, construction, documentation, and bidding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then step seven is actual construction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, as we have our upcoming meetings, we wanna just be able to give a little bit of information at each meeting to update and keep the community informed on the MSBA process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, we are only right now in the eligibility period, step one, which is a 270 day process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's my report for this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would, I mean, I know sometimes if everything, if all the ducks line up in a row, construction, if the votes and everything goes through, it may be as early as five to six years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes it takes seven to eight years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mean, we're gonna try to, this is Medford we're talking about.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're gonna try to make sure that we hit all of our deliverables early and we will be able to get to that point of construction, member Graham.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I'd like to extend a special congratulations to Dr. Vilma Bobo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations to Dr. Bobo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She is Medford's Coordinator of World Language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She was elected as the 50th President of the Massachusetts Foreign Language Association.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Bobo began her term this month as the 2024 President of MAFLA, M-A-F-L-A, a statewide professional association of world language teachers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: MAFLA was founded in 1967 with a mission to empower language educators through advocacy, learning, and support of world-class language instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The organization's work is focused on professional development for world language educators and advocacy for language education opportunities for Massachusetts students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The entire Medford School community should be very proud that world language educators throughout our state trust Dr. Brabeau to lead their collective efforts to prepare students for global citizenship.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Once again, congratulations, Dr. Brabeau.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also another important highlight that I'd like to share this evening, which is a free opportunity for all of our students, is the crash prevention training for student drivers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hands-on crash prevention training is available for free to all Medford High School students with a learner's permit or driver's license.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In Control Crash Prevention has partnered for years with Medford High School and the Medford Police to offer driver safety and crash prevention training to novice drivers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Graduates have a much lower chance of crashing and qualify for auto insurance discounts, up to 10%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: More information is available on our website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: DESE, our Department of Elementary and Secondary Education, is in Medford, and they are conducting their triennial special education and civil rights tiered focus monitoring review.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It started today, and this special review that DESE is conducting is reviewing all of Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: DESE visits each public school in Massachusetts every three years to monitor compliance with federal and state special education and civil rights regulations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So all districts are visited, and this is our turn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They're here today, tomorrow, and Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want the community to also know that during our information sessions, child care and interpretation services will be available at those meetings, and more information will be available on our school website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another wonderful topic to just share some key highlights with you is in the area of athletics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to do the special recognition Medford High School's girls soccer team received national recognition by United soccer coaches.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We received a silver level team ethics and sportsmanship award across the country 72 fall season boys and girls teams received either the platinum gold, silver or bronze version of the high school team ethics and sportsmanship award.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which recognizes teams that exhibit fair play, sporting behavior, and adherence to the laws of the game, as reflected by the number of yellow caution cards or red ejection cards.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are shown by referees throughout the season.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford girls soccer was one of 31 teams

[Edouard-Vincent]: that claimed the silver award, which is given to teams that accumulate a percentage of cards, ranging from 11 to 30%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Only nine other Massachusetts teams were recognized with team ethics and sportsmanship awards this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to send a special congratulations to coach Marco Siri, to our captains, Vivalyn Chavitana, who's grade 12, Josiah Kuyate, grade 11,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grace Mastromatteo, grade 12, and Isabella O'Brien, grade 12, and all members of the varsity and junior varsity teams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For the winter athletic season, our teams are off to a great start, and we're proudly cheering on our basketball, swimming, track, hockey, and gymnastics teams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also another critically important announcement, our CPAC team, there will be a special CPAC workshop and upcoming tiered focus monitoring review.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please consider joining the Medford CPAC's parent workshop on executive functioning to be held by Zoom at 6 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on Wednesday of this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mass General Hospital Inclusion Specialist, Elise Wolf, will discuss concrete strategies parents and caregivers can apply to help teach and foster independence for neurodiverse students at home and in the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: More information is available on the Medford Public Schools website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, a very important update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is related to our special education triennial tiered focus monitoring review.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is taking place during the week of January, 29, the department the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education desi.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Office of Public School Monitoring, PSM.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They will be conducting a review of Medford Public Schools special education programming.

[Edouard-Vincent]: DESE visits each public school in Massachusetts every three years to monitor compliance with federal and state special education and civil rights regulations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to the on-site visit, parent outreach is an important part of the review process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The review chairperson from the Office of Public School Monitoring will send all parents of students with disabilities an online survey that focuses on key areas of their child's special education program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Survey results will contribute to the development of a report.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if caregivers would like to contact the review chairperson to arrange an interview, contact information is also available on our website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council, CPAC, will host a caregiver orientation to learn about the upcoming special education and civil rights review in our district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Caregiver Orientation will be held on Tuesday, January 16 next week at 6.30pm by Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please join us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a few upcoming events this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: January 10 Wednesday is early release day for all students, middle schools release at 1130 and all other schools release at noon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For our outgoing school committee members, I want to extend special thanks and acknowledgement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tonight is a special and bittersweet occasion for the school committee because it's the final meeting for three of our dedicated school committee members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In order to recognize and thank them all, I'd like to take a couple of minutes to highlight the impact and accomplishments of each of these members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sharon Hayes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sharon Hayes joined the school committee after being elected in 2021, facing the daunting task of co-leading our school district through the post-pandemic recovery and readjustment period.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Throughout her two years on the committee, member Hays has always prioritized her values of transparency and equity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sharon promoted transparency in her work on formalizing the superintendent evaluation process and in sharing and explaining the work of the school committee in general.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She also maintained a strong belief in community voice, particularly the voices of students in school governance and leadership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She has challenged our entire district to always include the voices of all stakeholders through formal channels like surveys and advisory committees and through informal engagement by way of direct conversations and personal contact.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Hays, I know that our school district will continue to prioritize this kind of vital community voice even after your tenure on the committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Most of all, Sharon Hayes has been a constant advocate for equity in our school community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sharon always strives to consider how decisions will affect stakeholders at every level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This commitment to equity is particularly apparent in Sharon's active and earnest advocacy for school counseling and social emotional learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She is dedicated to prioritizing these sometimes overlooked but essential parts of how our schools care for and educate the whole child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Sharon member Hays, for your dedication to the students, employees and educators of the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now the mayor has a special

[Edouard-Vincent]: On behalf of the Medford Public Schools and the Medford School Committee, we do have a token of appreciation

[Edouard-Vincent]: should be due.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Hays, would you like to?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Fisher?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now I would like to recognize member Kathy Kreatz.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kathy Krutz has diligently served as a member of the school committee for the last eight years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Throughout that time, Kathy has always been a representative and advocate, deeply engaged with the needs and priorities of Medford students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She always shows up for Medford's kids to support them, advocate for them, and cheer them towards their bright futures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a noted champion of our district's highly lauded career technical education programs, Kathy is known for her strong relationships with CTE staff, students, administrators, and others involved in these incredible and impactful programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She is our community's ultimate advocate for experiential, hands-on learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Kreatz is well regarded throughout the Medford School community as a consistent, clearly spoken, reflective, and measured leader.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Someone who listens carefully and makes thoughtful and even-handed decisions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: creating wonderful opportunities for us to connect on a personal level, even during difficult moments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mia is a leader notable for her humility and thoughtfulness, sometimes the least likely to speak up in a meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All who know her share the confidence that anything she does, have to say, will be concise, direct, clear, and respectful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a common high school alma mater, and Mia graduated with my sister.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we come from similar landscapes of experience and perspective.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have always admired Mia's deep conviction and her personal faith, which have clearly guided her work and service as a member of the Medford School Committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mia, for your dedication and service to the students, employees, and educators of the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I'm so excited to share this news.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week, after years of applying for the program, Medford High School was invited into phase one of the Massachusetts School Building Authority's core program, which provides substantial reimbursement as high as 60% of all project costs for the renovation or rebuilding of schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are grateful to Massachusetts Treasurer Deb Goldberg, the MSBA Board of Directors, and our state legislators, Senator Pat Jalen, and Representatives Christine Barber, Paul Donato, and Sean Garbally, for their commitment to city-state partnership on this important priority.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you also to the countless Medford High School, MHS and district staff, educators who worked hard on our statement of interest to the MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also extend a special thanks to the school committee and the city of Medford for your continued support with this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Thursday, Medford participated in the first orientation session with MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're beginning to learn about the timeline, criteria, and process for phase one of the core program, and we're ready to hit the ground running in 2024.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're only at the very beginning of this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which will truly kick into gear next spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But for now, we are excited and pleased to celebrate this milestone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the new year, we'll begin to discuss in greater detail the timeline, priorities, and other steps to advance this great opportunity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because it was sent as a requested report, so that was why I hadn't put it as a resolution, because we were using the numbers for resolutions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we can actually start maybe a new number for requested reports.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and caregivers, so welcome, welcome, welcome to our school committee meeting this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So good evening and happy holidays.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many members of our local Jewish community will begin the observance of Hanukkah for eight nights beginning this Thursday evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hanukkah, sometimes called the Festival of Lights, is timely and welcome, coinciding with some of the shortest, darkest days of December.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Regardless of your religious beliefs, this is the perfect time to seek some extra light and warmth to your dark evenings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, just for those of you who are here and for the Medford community at large, if you've been anywhere near the McGlynn Andrews Complex campus, the McGlynn Playground has fencing around it right now, and that's for everyone's safety.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're really excited because the McGlynn School Playground is going to be

[Edouard-Vincent]: our new universally accessible schoolyard.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there aren't many in Massachusetts, but it's going to be universally accessible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do believe we'll have a lot of visitors from neighboring communities coming to use our new park because it's accessible for all of our young people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the construction was originally scheduled to begin in the spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, the timetable got moved up and demolition is going to be taking place this week with the hope of still completing the playground on time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if we're lucky, they might even finish a little early.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So while the construction is taking place, the playground will be closed to the public during construction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's the sad bit of news I know for our young folk, but it needs to be closed because it's no longer safe.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we do know that it was short notice, but we were given short notice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as quickly as we found out, we turned around and made sure that we communicated that to the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if the McGlynn Playground was your playground of choice, you now have many other options.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Harris Playground, Magoon Playground, Logan, and the newly renovated Morrison Playground.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are many other options nearby.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Work will be taking place between 7 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and 3 p.m., and we are working with the construction company, so we want to make sure that we minimize disruption to arrival and dismissal times when you're dropping off and picking up your children.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please, you know, keep us in the loop.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let us know.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want to extend a very special thank you to our mayor, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, and to the Medford School Committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to thank City Hall staff, teachers,

[Edouard-Vincent]: our staff in the schools and administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to thank our family and community partners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we also want to thank Shanine Pellequin, who is a parent and a great advocate and expert in the area of playgrounds, lending her expertise to really help us get the best playground possible for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we thank all of you and the community at large for your support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, another important update for the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's about our elementary literacy screening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Howell, for the presentation that you'll be doing this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we just want you to know that administering the early the universal screening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's crucial to promoting reading success for every child, and we value our partnership with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Just on a side today I was in a McGlynn school kindergarten classroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I got to see some students reading their early readers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They were so excited.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think I was more excited because I'm like, oh, it's only December 4th and you're reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our students are doing wonderful things.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So have your little ones read to you at home and encourage early literacy and reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also just want our listening audience to know that kindergarten registration, which is critically important for us to have accurate numbers of students that are going to be coming to Medford Public Schools next year, that kindergarten registration is going to begin next month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in January.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we start in January and it continues for a few months, but if some of you remember, we did have a surprise this summer at the 11th hour.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had a lot of kindergarten students come and register and we were forced to open additional classrooms, you know, with a very, very short turnaround.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please be on the lookout for those,

[Edouard-Vincent]: kindergarten registration opportunities and we will be providing child care and interpretation services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, the first event will be taking place on January 16.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a few important upcoming events that are going to be happening district-wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On December 5th, which is tomorrow, there is a financial planning webinar with the Massachusetts Educational Financing Authority at 7 o'clock on Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: please go to the Medford High School website, or you can contact Stacey Shulman for additional information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for juniors, for seniors, parents who wanna find out information, and possibly if you have even a freshman or a sophomore, and you're an early planner, take advantage of this college financial planning webinar.

[Edouard-Vincent]: December 7, as I said earlier, it will mark the first night of Hanukkah, so happy Hanukkah to our Jewish friends, families, and neighbors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: December 13 and 14, our wonderful band once again

[Edouard-Vincent]: and our orchestra holiday concerts are gonna be taking place at Medford High School at 7 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for being here tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Member McLaughlin.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just wanted to restate that as I was listening to the conversation that was being had, when I think about the MAP assessment data, it was said earlier at the beginning that this truly is a tool that should be used by the teacher to help inform her instruction

[Edouard-Vincent]: To member McLaughlin's point how she's going to differentiate with students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I received this exact same parent report for my own child who's in elementary school, and when I've had my parent conference meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: where they pull out the, they talk about the quadrants, but they also end up saying, these are the areas where your child has strengths, and these are the areas where you need to continue to monitor and work with your child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, Alexia, ST Math, those, you know, in my

[Edouard-Vincent]: where the braid my daughter is currently in everything is online for homework.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's, you know, part of its Lexia part of its math part of its I ready, and they are monitoring the progress, and earlier on, I believe it was Dr Riccadeli talked about.

[Edouard-Vincent]: how some of these supportive programs like ST Math, they adjust Lexia, they adjust to where the child, if you're doing well on the assessment, then you will continue to do well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They make the adjustments on an individualized basis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what is, I almost feel like where we're getting a little caught up is that, yes, a teacher is able to look at that quadrant graph and see where her whole entire class falls,

[Edouard-Vincent]: but she also was able to drill down and see how each student is performing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And before in Medford, we never had a system or an internal assessment system where we could monitor students' progress across the schools and have it be normed data that we were referencing or using that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel like there is a place for NWEA MAP to support instruction and to help teachers be able to say, oh, I am gonna need to spend a little more focused attention or do another mini lesson or a reteach because I had so many students that struggled with the concept or the opposite.

[Edouard-Vincent]: wow, my students are doing fabulous with operations and algebraic thinking.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's not an area I can share that data with the students, congratulate them, say pat yourselves on the back.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to spend a little bit more time on measurement and data or number and operations and really target it that way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is just to really share with the committee because initially the committee, you know, did ask for demographic data, EL data, special students with disabilities data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So trying to pull as much data as possible to just share on a global level to say this is where the district is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: but in the opening when the RIT scores were shared to show where is Medford Public Schools in comparison to the nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for the most part, we're on par, and in some areas we're outperforming the national RIT scores, and in other areas we are not.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The MCAS data that was shared, where it kind of gives you the predictor of where they think you're going to perform, and then we don't find out until we actually take the MCAS.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, I feel even that predictive aspect of the NWEA map is really

[Edouard-Vincent]: beneficial because yes, they're saying what students are not meeting expectations, what students are exceeding expectations, and then the students that fall in the meeting and partially meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it gives you a ballpark.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not set in stone, but at least you do have an idea of the direction that you're moving in for the time being.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say that this really is a tool that should be used and is being used at the school level by the teachers and it can be shared with parents during report card conferences, during SST meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Data might even be taken into some of the IEP meetings or EL meetings, progress report, progress monitoring on English language development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I just wanted to stress that this is a tool to help us better gauge where our students are at.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you and good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They attended the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association Convention.

[Edouard-Vincent]: ASHA is how it's referred to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It took place in Boston this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The ASHA convention is one of the largest professional development events for audiologists, speech-language pathologists, and speech-language and hearing scientists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: bringing together approximately 15,000 attendees.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The annual convention offers more than 2,500 sessions eligible for ASHA Continuing Ed credit.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's covering the latest research, clinical skills and techniques in communication, sciences and disorders.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our Medford speech language staff will share what they learned with one another at upcoming staff meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if a student were to feel uncomfortable, they could use a different single stall, a separate changing area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So case in point this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the committee met during the summer and we had a policy that was approved in August.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So because it was approved in August, this April 1 deadline, if the handbook had been finalized, we would be doing either addendums or reprinting and doing it over again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if we were to maintain that April 1 date,

[Edouard-Vincent]: then we would need to make sure that policy subcommittee meetings that would need to be added into the handbook happened prior to April 1 so that we wouldn't be doing work two and three times over, just making one revision.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we think we're able to maintain that by April of April 1st of every year, then I think that's reasonable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But if we think we might need the month of April and make May be the cutoff so that we could have the handbooks finalized and ready to go for the start of the school year in August, then that would be my one consideration to the committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with the March 1st, 2024 deadline, where the committee wants to be able to review revisions, my ask would be of the committee from March 1st to April 1st, that gives 30 days to essentially review the entire handbook and make sure like, if anything else is gonna be, is that enough time for the committee?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in response to several of your questions, member Pritz, for students, depending on what grade level the students are at, the principal is deeply involved.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know Mr. Tucci has his hand raised from the middle school level, but at the elementary, middle, and even at the high school level, the parents, families,

[Edouard-Vincent]: work closely with school administration, the nursing office, our guidance, our, you know, counseling and behavioral health, Stacey Shulman's department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we work collaboratively with families at that point in time in terms of if we have students whose names are officially changing, that will go through registration, again, working in collaboration with the principal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that information will be done through the registration office.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in the official database, the child's new name would be recognized, and that's what we would have officially documented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as the students go through the different levels, when they come to the high school again, member Hays was just sharing what the students can do, but some of that information

[Edouard-Vincent]: the district is already aware of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we do have a lot of Councilors available that work with our students and work with families combined also our health services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our nursing department would be also deeply involved.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it is something where depending on the age,

[Edouard-Vincent]: of the student.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If it is a younger age student, elementary age, the parents are usually the ones who are expressing that desire and working collaboratively with the principals to let them know this is

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, how I would like my child to be addressed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is significant communication with the principals, with school administration, the health services department, and our counseling department, and working collaboratively with registration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it is something that we've had to deal with, and it's been dealt with appropriately, you know, I would say.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Hays.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to begin this evening with a reflection on the challenging week that so many in our community have experienced with the outbreak of war in Israel.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As this conflict continues to escalate, we should take some time to think about how the news from Israel and Palestine might affect our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: More and more of the devastation and violence is being shown on social media, from news outlets to individual accounts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Content moderators on many platforms are overwhelmed and ill-equipped, meaning that all social media users are likely to encounter graphic or misleading content.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We strongly, strongly encourage our caregivers of our younger students to closely monitor any online activity to ensure that children are not being exposed to inappropriate content.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also agree with advice from experts that older children with access to the internet should be encouraged to be skeptical of videos shared on social media and offered help with evaluating the news sources that they are using.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are here for all of our community, especially those with loved ones and friends facing the atrocities of this war firsthand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We strongly condemn the terror attacks perpetuated by Hamas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Moreover, we join our community in grief for the lives broken and lost in this last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Amid these upsetting events, I am reminded of how fortunate and privileged we are to live in a safe and loving community here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I hope we can all stand together to support our neighbors and community members in this difficult moment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford High School will be hosting an open house for our eighth graders.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grade eight students and their families are invited to attend the Medford High School open house on Thursday, October 26th from 6 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students can meet the principals, administrators, teachers, and current students and ask them questions about their experiences at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There will also be opportunities to visit and tour vocational shops, learn about athletics and extracurricular programs, and enter to win giveaways.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford High School is excited to welcome the class of 2028.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also for the community to know that there are free English classes for caregivers of English learner students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In collaboration with the Welcome Project and the Medford Public Library, Medford Public Schools is hosting free English classes for Medford families starting tomorrow, October 17th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please visit our website, mps02155.org, to register for classes or obtain more information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All information is available in English, Spanish, Portuguese, or Haitian Creole.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Classes will be held in person and virtually.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Rocco's here, Sieri, coach.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations to these two senior student athletes and the entire team on a terrific showing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Great work and congratulations to all of our unified athletes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these are draft goals for school year 23-24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the first goal is our district improvement goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The district improvement goal for the draft goal, again, I'm waiting for additional feedback from the committee, is that during the school year 23-24, the Medford Public Schools will improve systems and structures that directly impact student services, student and family and communications, and school facilities and operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our goals are to continue to maintain a learning environment built upon the pillars of safety, equity and consistency, creating a culture that values consistent communication and safe and accessible school facilities for all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were six key actions that were proposed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the first key action was again, improving physical accessibility at school facilities,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and developing a maintenance ticket system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was recommended by the committee as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Consistent communication to families across all schools, including student services such as athletics, counseling, career services, and student governance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Three, effective and appropriate and consistent messaging during any emergency scenario.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for reestablish the capital planning committee to examine building systems in creating a replacement timeline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Five, seizing every opportunity to collaborate with MSBA to improve facilities and building systems.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we do have another meeting scheduled this week on October 19th with MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, informational meetings for all districts that have applied to MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And number six,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Enhancing our human resource practices, such as job postings hiring and payroll management.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so some of the proposed outcomes would be increasing accessibility and parking pedestrian restroom facilities communication platforms, such as some more and final site.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our mass notification systems that are going to be used regularly and consistently by all schools and student servicing groups.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to have well documented model communications and templates that are going to be utilized by all school administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and officials so that, again, things are standardized and streamlined for any kind of emergency communication scenario.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A capital planning committee, reviews of every single school would be one of our outcomes and streamlined and more effective job postings and onboarding procedures

[Edouard-Vincent]: for our staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these were the draft recommended district improvement goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to just move to our student learning goals, which are, we continue to use literacy as our student learning goal, an area that we really want to focus in on and continue to develop greater strategies and strengths.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, our student learning goal would be to assess literacy skills and implementing interventions in literacy to improve outcomes by deepening teacher and principal knowledge of literacy practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: while maintaining a district wide focus on instruction and assessment through the continued use of our in-house system NWEA map dibbles, and our newly adopted literacy program into reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the goal is similar to last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, we have catered it to really be specific to where we are at this point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have six key actions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, many of them were repeated from last year, but the work continues.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is kind of now that we've officially selected our literacy program into reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to do all of the things possible to continue to make sure that that programming and the significant financial investment really has the opportunity to get really strong traction within the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we will continue as a district to follow DESE's, the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education's dyslexia guidance, which we've been doing for multiple years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're using inter-reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're also doing ECRI, which stands for Enhanced Core Reading Instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we're using DIBLS, which I mentioned earlier, but it stands for the Dynamic Indicators of Basic Early Literacy Skills.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And those assessments are used, DIBLS is used with our youngest learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, tier one ELA blocks in all grades for kindergarten to grade two.

[Edouard-Vincent]: district wide, and we have a continued partnership with Hill for Literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During the 23-24 school year, there is embedded professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week I had the opportunity to participate in professional development with the Missittuck School, third grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so coaching is being provided that's going to really support instruction and help teachers to look

[Edouard-Vincent]: at their specific literacy data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will continue to use NWEA map again as our district in-house district assessment so that we can have baseline beginning of year data, middle of year data, and then end of year data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we can monitor our own progress and growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we will continue to work with our elementary district literacy leadership team, the DLLT.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there's a lot of work happening in literacy it's critical work right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are beginning to see really positive payoff outcomes from that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we list some of the outcomes, scope and sequence for grades K to five.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford Public Schools is establishing data cycles that are going to be measuring our performance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, this is a new area that we are really formally entering, working with partners and collaborators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And one of our outcomes where we're saying visible implementation of the science of reading the best practices that are taking place during our literacy blocks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have that listed as an outcome because again we've made a significant investment with every hill for literacy, and now with into reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the expectation is that this is what is being used every day in all of our classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So accountability measures, we would like to see under NWEA map, 65% of our students in grades two through 10 to meet or exceed their projected growth targets on the NWEA map assessments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to see for dibbles 90% of our elementary students, that they will make at least 10% growth in oral reading fluency.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that's words read correctly by June of 24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for professional development, Medford public schools will continue to provide targeted

[Edouard-Vincent]: targeted professional development for our elementary staff with inter-reading training every month during the 23-24 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But for the purposes of this presentation,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to go through this slide deck and present the key highlights from the Culture and Climate Survey that took place last year at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The survey questions were developed last year by Medford Public Schools and the Medford Department of Health

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was open to all of our high school students between May 18 and June 6 of this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 736 students participated in the survey, just over 60% of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At that time, we had 1,222 students enrolled.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students were given designated times during their English classes to complete the survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The survey was also translated into five languages so that students who were English learners had the opportunity to participate in the survey in their native language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And just I want to share that the results of this culture and climate survey are truly a snapshot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and don't necessarily reflect what is happening right now at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So during the survey, there were eight categories, cultural awareness and action, diversity and inclusion, school belonging, school climate, school engagement, school safety, student teacher relationships, and valuing of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I said in my previous remarks, but I do want to preface before I go further with this presentation, that this survey was a benchmark, and we want to use the results of the survey as the beginning point so that we can measure progress and growth and use this data in a most meaningful way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The eight categories, as we analyzed and looked carefully at the data and the responses, the areas as a school that we felt were strong areas, our strengths, were school belonging, school engagement, and valuing of schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The area that was varied right in the middle was cultural awareness and action, school safety, and student-teacher relationships.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The areas for growth that were identified from the survey, according to our interpretation, were diversity and inclusion and school climate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was varied.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The question was, how often students learn about, discuss, and confront issues of race, ethnicity, and culture in their school?

[Edouard-Vincent]: A significant minority of respondents, our students, agreed that students at Medford High School were teased or picked on about their race or ethnicity or based upon their cultural background or religion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An area that we identified as an area for growth fell in the category of diversity and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which talked about the level of diversity integration and fairness for students of different races, ethnicities cultures and abilities or identities, about 40%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: responded that they agreed that at Medford High School, students were teased or picked on based on their physical or intellectual disability, or based upon their real or perceived sexual orientation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford School Committee proposed and approved the new bullying prevention and intervention plan for this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our next steps as a district, October 15th, principals reviewed our bullying plan, the revised bullying prevention and intervention plan with their staff during school-based staff meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at our upcoming November 7th meeting on there will be a bullying presentation during the morning session of district wide professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And later during the month of November, we will be having a parent presentation by an outside presenter who will be coming to present to our greater community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm sorry.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under school belonging, we identified that as a strength.

[Edouard-Vincent]: How much students feel that they are valued members of the community, 90% felt that they belonged and they were accepted in the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was clear for us that the majority felt that they had many chances to be part of class discussions, extracurricular activities, and school-sponsored events and activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Two-thirds of the students felt that they are part of the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the same time, an area for growth was school climate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was the overall social and learning climate of the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A substantial number agreed that people of different backgrounds get along well at Medford High School and more and that was really saying about greater than 80% and more than two thirds didn't feel that students are often bullied.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An area that students clearly identified as an area for growth to support a healthy climate had to do with school bathrooms and school grounds and that they didn't feel they were sufficiently maintained last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were mixed results, measures related to healthy and effective conflict resolution and discipline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is an area we know that we will continue to target and work on specifically.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Moving forward, our action items for that

[Edouard-Vincent]: Student bathrooms, including gender neutral bathrooms are available on each floor throughout this throughout the school day assistant principals and building monitors and engagement specialists conduct regular walkthroughs of the hallway common and bathroom spaces so we have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: additional structures in place where we're receiving timely feedback in order to ensure that those areas are being maintained.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Custodians are conducting regular cleaning schedules on all of our bathrooms and facilities and grounds.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They've adopted a new landscaping routine to improve the Medford High School campus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also Medford High, we have submitted an MSBA application for the renewal to have a new and improved high school with the desire of long-term improvements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Page 11, please.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under student voice, Medford High School is committed to continued events

[Edouard-Vincent]: is committed to continued efforts to build school community and expand opportunities for student voice and leadership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are regular student advisory blocks with community building activities built in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are facilitated activities now during lunch and other opportunities for students to engage using the gymnasium.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are building, continuing to build community through the house model and additional student feedback is going to be gathered through follow-up surveys and student group sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our assistant principals are also going to be trained on increasing student voice, opportunities for greater student voice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Page 12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another area of strength was school engagement, student attentiveness and investments in the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nearly all respondents indicated that there were positive measures on school engagement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 88% agreed that a teacher or another adult at school would notice their absence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And 90% felt that they have the opportunity to participate in class discussions or activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And 93% reported that there are many opportunities for student involvement in activities outside of the classroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, that was a great area of strength.

[Edouard-Vincent]: varied, again, student physical and psychological safety within the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, we did have 60% of students agree that they feel safe at school, but many also felt that students at the school regularly fight, steal, or use substances such as drugs or alcohol at school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 80% of respondents said that there is a teacher or some other adult who students can go to if they need help because of sexual assault or dating violence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they do feel that there is a trusted adult who would be able to provide support in the event of those situations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under student-teacher relationships, that was identified as an area that was varied.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this is the strength of social connections between students and teachers within and beyond the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 70% felt that they had strong social connections with their teachers within and beyond the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And most of them felt that their teachers cared about them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, at the same time, there was a minority of 45% of respondents that felt adults working at the school did not treat all students with respect.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that is something where we are working on all of that together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we identified that as varied because there were different results.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another area that was identified as a strength

[Edouard-Vincent]: was valuing a school, how much do students feel that school is interesting, important, and useful?

[Edouard-Vincent]: 55% of the students indicated that the things they're learning in school are important to them and connected to life outside of the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And 90% responded that their teachers expect them to do their best.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And 73% felt that they could talk to a teacher or adult at the school about something that was bothering them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when we opened, I showed this screen, and again, the areas that we identified as clear strengths were school belonging, school engagement, and valuing of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The areas that were varied were cultural awareness and action, school safety, and student-teacher relationships.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the areas for growth were diversity and inclusion and school climate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I say once again that this survey was given at the end of last school year, and that we are looking at this data as a benchmark, and not a report card.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our intention is to continue with the reforms that have taken place thus far.

[Edouard-Vincent]: remedies and improvements that are clearly underway at the high school to lead to more favorable responses in the future culture and climate surveys that will be given this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, the rate the race equity task force, and we have not reconvene this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we need to select new students, and, but we have not started this year yet, the race equity task force.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the first time this data is being presented to the committee first.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have not shared it with staff or the greater community yet.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We wanted to present the data here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, even as we looked at all of the categories, you take the information,

[Edouard-Vincent]: where the pluses were, where the deltas were, and where there were mixed results, and look at that and say, okay, where are we going to improve?

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, where were the low-hanging fruit?

[Edouard-Vincent]: What was the low-hanging fruit?

[Edouard-Vincent]: What few things could we do immediately?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Where some of the areas where we had some of the really low marks, we were able to put some changes in right away to start tackling those areas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then some of these areas which are more complex, working collaboratively, you know, using our advisory blocks and other opportunities where students are together to be able to have conversations with our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, you don't know until you get the data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then once you have the data, you say, okay, how are we going to use this to inform our next steps?

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, we realize that this was a snapshot in time, but we also realize like we still have work to do, but we need to share it with the other stakeholders as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they can look at it and unpack the data for themselves and see the responses of the students and then, you know, go forward with that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know they're thinking about somewhere around the halfway point in the new year to potentially do another check in with the students to see where now that they've been in school for a full semester.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do, I cannot say the specific date for the next survey administration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even with taking this data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know when when we started to present last week and it's a very valid point, depending on which question was being asked.

[Edouard-Vincent]: it's it was confusing was it favorable or unfavorable so.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we give it exactly the same way, as it is, then we could just be comparing apples and apples if we do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: make the adjustments, then it's going to be different information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know if the questions could be asked in a different way, but so that's something that I would definitely have to bring back to the team to just see do we give the exact same questions as is and just see how they respond.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So then we'd have two sets of numbers that are

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even though the favorable and unfavorable is confusing, it would be the same exact way it was given the first time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Attendance last year, once we were dealing with the situation at the high school, we kind of went into a different mode.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had fluctuating attendance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were meeting by Zoom on Mondays.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So sometimes we would have some students attend.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes it didn't work out with their schedules so there was a lot of scheduling challenges.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes people's work schedule didn't always work out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, I want to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: reach out to the families or the parents and caregivers that originally said they want to be able they want to continue to be part of the equity task force and see how many people we end up with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we can have a manageable number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we talked about different, different topics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: again, is new information that we didn't have before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this definitely would have been data that would have been shared with the Race Equity Task Force to have a conversation with them as thought partners and be able to say this is some of the data that students are saying and, you know, get feedback and suggestions from them as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Just requesting approval from the committee for the 10,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The implementation plan is going to be developed by assistant superintendent Lucy and our coordinator Suzanne fee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it is expected that the plan will be completed in the very near future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So my recommendation is that the school committee approved this generous and appreciated donation to the Medford public schools for CCSR.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Like it could go either way but I do have more data to provide that's not my preference would be if they could present the full packet, and then I think it will, it'll tell more of a picture of the entire district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If I may, through the chair, I just want to really stress that

[Edouard-Vincent]: The new elementary schedule allows for common planning time on a weekly basis, and that never existed before in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that's a critical lever, a critical tool that if you're able to meet weekly with your grade level peers and look at data, look at student work, bring different writing samples, compare, use rubrics,

[Edouard-Vincent]: conduct the learning walks, all of that is the critically important instructional work that moves the needle forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if those things aren't happening, if ILTs are not able to meet because the schedule doesn't allow for it, you're not going to be able to go back and do all of that important

[Edouard-Vincent]: reteaching.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I was so happy that we were able to make the elementary schedule work and to use larger blocks of time to provide quality professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, even though we are on par with the state, I agree with you, we should not be satisfied at that point and that we want to perform so much better and we can, but now we have new systems and structures in place where it's going to create the best learning opportunities for our educators to learn from one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and to receive quality planning meetings, quality grade level team meetings, and using data to inform instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It just, it didn't work under the old schedule and now it is able to work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we'll be able to do so much more as a district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was the esteemed former superintendent of Shawsheen Technical High School and a well-loved and experienced public servant.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was actively involved in Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was an incomparable advocate for all public schools, particularly career technical education, and his loss is keenly felt by those of us who are lucky to be his peers, colleagues and beneficiaries.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I remember the last time meeting with him at the Medford High School campus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I just want to share that may his soul rest in peace.
