[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a slide deck that I'm going to go through the slide deck this evening to discuss our results from last year's Medford High School culture and climate survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to thank member Hays for working with me and with members of our team throughout this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and helping to make sure that we were on track to present the outcomes of the Culture and Climate Survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm pleased to share this presentation this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is going to be, you know, the key highlights from the Medford High School Culture and Climate Survey, which was conducted in the spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So on this first slide,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's important to note that the survey questions were developed by the Medford Public Schools and in collaboration with the Medford Department of Health.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was open to all of our high school students and the survey window was open from May 18 until June 6 of 2023.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had 736 students who responded to the survey, which is just over 60% of our total population.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At that time, it was 1,222 students at the end of last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students were provided designated times during their English classes to complete the survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The survey was available in Arabic, Haitian Creole, Portuguese, and Spanish, which are the four most popular languages currently in the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I wanna note that these results reflect a snapshot in time from spring of 2023, and do not necessarily reflect up-to-date attitudes and perspectives on Medford High School's culture and climate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the survey question categories, there were eight categories that the students responded to questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cultural awareness and action, diversity and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So under cultural awareness and action, it was how often students learn about, discuss and confront issues of race, ethnicity and culture in school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under diversity and inclusion,

[Edouard-Vincent]: That address the level of diversity, integration and fairness for students of different races, ethnicities, cultures, abilities, or identities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: School belonging addressed how much students feel that they are valued members of the school community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: School climate was the overall social and learning climate of the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: School engagement

[Edouard-Vincent]: looked at student attentiveness and investment in school school safety addressed students, physical and psychological safety within the school student teacher relationships addressed the strength of the social connections between students and teachers within and beyond the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the eighth category was valuing of school, how much students feel that school is interesting, important, and useful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those were all of the categories that all of the questions fell between.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to state that this survey is a benchmark I think it's critically important, it is not a report card.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The responses will be most meaningful and impactful when used to measure change over time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We believe that the reforms, remedies, and improvements already underway at Medford High School will lead to a more favorable response in future culture and climate surveys.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the next slide shows you how we as a district performed in the eight categories.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Green is identified as our strengths.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The areas where as a district we performed very well were school belonging, school engagement, and valuing of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The yellow area varied were areas that we had mixed results, cultural awareness and action, school safety, and student teacher relationships.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the area that was an area for growth, the red area, is diversity and inclusion in school climate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I'm going to share key highlights from the survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If I may, I would like to present

[Edouard-Vincent]: My hope would be that I could present it and provide some of what my thinking was about the results, because even under students at the school are teased or picked on about their race or ethnicity under cultural awareness.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even the fact that 30% actually feel like they're being teased.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and picked on because of their race and ethnicity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if you think about the totality of the district, and if it's 60, 40, and if 30, if 30% potentially of the 40% feel like they're being picked on, I didn't feel like that was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think based on some of the questions that were starting to be surfaced, again, as I said, I interpreted this data as a benchmark, not a report card, but hearing some of the questions and concerns, I do not mind going back over the data again to review it one more time and see if the information can

[Edouard-Vincent]: be looked at or presented with a slightly different interpretation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't mind going back to the drawing board to do it again and bring it back before the committee at our very next meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just want to recognize the entire team both Suzanne, Joan, and Tom Thomas for helping with the presentation and the language to be able to try to keep the language, clear and understandable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I will definitely take that feedback I hadn't

[Edouard-Vincent]: The packet that I gave you says favorable, I don't have a problem presenting it as, going back and representing it differently so that the numbers are there, what it says, either remove the favorable completely, the percentages, or add both so that people could look at it

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm definitely willing to go back and do that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If it will provide greater clarity, and not lead, make people lean one way or the other.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will say that I did try to do the color coding to kind of simplify based on feedback that we've received other times of kind of what we felt was really strong in the middle, an area for

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, varied responses and then the areas that clearly were areas identified as serious world, but I'm willing to go back and shuffle.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The essence of it but take away those percentages if it's definitely confusing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also would be remiss I want to thank Mr. Paul DeLava as well who's been working with us in a data capacity, helping us look at data, a little differently as well so I just want to recognize him as well for working with us so we will continue.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will go back to the drawing board to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Try to take the feedback that you have just given and see if that will help to make.

[Edouard-Vincent]: substantially change the ratings that I had, but at least the numbers that the essence of what we felt the survey was saying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, there were clear areas that we were very strong.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, areas that we want to work on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then areas that need immediate attention.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'll also be working, continuing to work with the high school team because they also, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cabral and Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Schulman also helped to look at this data as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they're just helping us to look at it and see where are we going in terms of next steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I will take it back to the drawing board and represent it again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're meeting here today in the midst of the Jewish High Holy Days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This past weekend was Rosh Hashanah, the start of the new year, 5784.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And next Monday is Yom Kippur.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We wish all of our Jewish community members a happy new year and a meaningful holiday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a reminder, school is closed next Monday, September 25th in observance of Yom Kippur.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I'm looking forward to welcoming our high school principal, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Marta Cabral, who will be providing us with an update on the start of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cabral has helmed the exciting and positive start of the school year at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She'll be discussing several important school policy plans and the ongoing and upcoming opportunities for student engagement across grade levels, cohorts, and experiences.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After the report from Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cabral, members of the district leadership team will present the results of the comprehensive review conducted by AIR and the Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This report published earlier this month by Desi highlights many great accomplishments and strengths in our district across a variety of measures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It also points out several key areas for growth, which I hope will help to guide this committee's strategic vision and leadership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Curriculum nights across the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All four elementary schools in the McGlynn Middle School hosted curriculum nights in the past week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Principals have gratefully acknowledged a high level of family engagement in these open houses.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The two remaining curriculum nights will be held at the Andrews Middle School tomorrow at 6 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and at Medford High School on Thursday at 6 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Early Release Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This Wednesday, September 20th, is the first half day of the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Middle schools will be released at 11.30 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and all other schools will be released at noontime, 12 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The district will be providing students with a cold food option on half days this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The food will be provided during snack time at the elementary schools, and after dismissal at the middle and high schools and elementary students who prefer an alternative they're always welcome to bring in a healthy snack to school from home.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The cafeterias will be open for students to sit and eat and students will be asked to sign up in the morning, so kitchen staff can prepare and have an accurate number of meals ready.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Breakfast and lunch continue to be served free for all students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thanks to the state law that was passed by the legislature and signed by Governor Healy earlier this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Families do not need to sign up to receive free meals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With the exception of qualifying homeschooled families who can apply for a special P EBT food benefits until September 30 families can contact my office with questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Athletics, I have lots of good news in the department of athletics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Boys and girls varsity cross country won their first meet last Thursday against Lynn English.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Boys golf recorded an early win over Lynn English last Tuesday and gave a strong effort in a matchup later in the week against Lynn classical.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Boys soccer notched a commanding victory over Lynn Classical and a close loss to North Andover in games last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Girls varsity soccer shut out Lynn English 7-0 and contended against Lynn Classical in a scoreless draw.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Girls' varsity and freshman volleyball ended the week on a high note with Friday night wins over Salem.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our boys' freshman football team defeated Cambridge Range and Latin at home on Saturday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the middle school level, our girls' softball team earned a 7-0 triumph over Chelsea Middle Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And congratulations to all of our student athletes and coaches for their efforts, good sportsmanship, and love for the game.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As always, go Mustangs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also have some news to share about our Mustang mall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you wanna show your support for the Medford Mustangs, consider picking up some Medford gear from the Mustang mall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Mustang mall,

[Edouard-Vincent]: is a school store run by our business marketing students at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The storefront is open weekdays from 11 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 2.30 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can also shop online at mustang-mall.square.site and follow the store on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter at the handle MHS underscore Mustang Mall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a few selected upcoming events that are happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, this Wednesday, September 20th, district-wide early release day for all students K through 12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Friday, September 22nd, and Saturday, September 23rd is Run Medford being held at Hormel Stadium.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Mayor, you said Friday evening is at what time?

[Edouard-Vincent]: HAB-Danny Teodorua here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: HAB-Masyn Moyer): fabulous 630.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, on Monday, September 25 I mentioned earlier there is no school again, all Medford public schools will be closed next Monday in observance of Yom Kippur, and other key events will be as always included in the Friday memo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, and I just wanted to just make a comment in regards or in support of not using the backpacks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't think about the backpacks in terms of

[Edouard-Vincent]: bringing weapons to school per se, but we do have some students that are very entrepreneurial, and they may have ideas about bringing maybe certain liquids to school, or, you know, using entrepreneurial skills.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And sometimes they bring things to school and they bring them in their backpack so it may not necessarily be a weapon but they may want to bring certain beverages, or we were dealing with a little bit of vaping and at one point in time, I know that the assistant principals

[Edouard-Vincent]: and staff were confiscating a lot of vapes that should not be at schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So by them not having a big backpack that might have inventory, the teachers can really closely supervise and monitor and ensure that the students have

[Edouard-Vincent]: their books or whatever is needed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I think it kind of creates an honor system, in case they were tempted, and no one has to worry about that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I just wanted to present that as a possibility I know we have wonderful Mustangs but we do have a few that try to test limits.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I was thinking more of that in terms of if the backpacks are secure in their lockers, and they travel to class, we don't have to worry about that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's one less thing or something fewer to worry about than with a large backpack.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Miss Cabral, I just wanted to also say in terms of surveys I want to thank Miss Hayes member member Hays for communicating with me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last year we completed this high school culture and climate survey, and at our very next meeting on that data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: was partially presented in the late spring and we want to be able to do a thorough presentation of what that data says, so we can have the data from the culture and climate survey that took place in the spring, and look at all of the changes and use it to continue to inform

[Edouard-Vincent]: the important changes that are happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just want to thank member Hays, who has been working with me patiently.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, member Hays.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at our next meeting on October 2nd, we will have a comprehensive presentation of that survey data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to comment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I too, in thinking about the three reports.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The three reports, all of them were valuable in different ways.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first report by Cindy weeks was really a deep examination of human resources and the systems and structures that we actually

[Edouard-Vincent]: ended up being revealed we did not have in place that we needed to put in place as a district to ensure that we're bringing in and recruiting and maintaining dynamic staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The second report from Michael Welch in regards to the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do feel with that data being published.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cabral and her team and everyone within the district has had the opportunity to look at that report and see some of the key areas that definitely were identified as areas, growth areas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many of those areas have been addressed even in the presentation that Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Cabral just gave to us this evening about a lot of the shifts and putting systems in place and having that consistency and accountability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This DESE AIR report, prior to coming to Medford, I was getting DESE AIR reports a lot, especially when you're working with schools that are underperforming.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This report, I see it as the glass is half full.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are areas for growth for us as a district, but there were so many areas that DESE did identify that the district was doing well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This school year, the new calendar, the new schedule that is in place with early release happening for all schools K-12, allowing for greater, more meaningful professional development that used to not have happened K-12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Only our secondary students were exposed to that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even working on the new schedule that's going to happen for the high school, because we still have the six day schedule of the comprehensive high school and the five day schedule of the vocational school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Five and six, they don't talk to each other and it's like we've been force fitting for I believe eight years prior to my arrival.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that's finally going to happen for the 2425 school year, and I was on one of the calls with the

[Edouard-Vincent]: consultants and the team, where they're going to be pulling in a lot of data to say, how are we going to make Medford High School function like seamlessly?

[Edouard-Vincent]: That yes, we still have a robust vocational program, but the comprehensive side of the school, that they will talk to each other and it will be a win-win for everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when I look at this data, it has been nine years since Medford Public Schools was reviewed at all in this

[Edouard-Vincent]: type of a capacity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even when we were doing instructional rounds, and some of you participated pre-pandemic, when we were just looking at the five core actions, the pandemic caused a lot of changes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The pandemic did impact everyone in different ways, but we made shifts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the elementary level, we did not have weekly grade level team meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the team can tell you, I had been saying it to them for five years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we cannot get the teachers to meet at the lowest levels, progress is going to take significantly longer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is going to be the first year that all teachers will be able to meet with the new schedule and the added specialists, that that work is going to be able to happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So seeing Desi talk about what we can do with instructional leadership teams

[Edouard-Vincent]: what more we need to do with student support teams, I feel like the pieces of the puzzle are clearly laid out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So yes, it's a dense document, but what those 89 pages say are like, this is your roadmap.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you implement these particular areas and maintain the things that are working well, the district's going to move forward at an accelerated rate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we talk about change and changes sometimes difficult for people to wrap their heads around.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But as we talk about change we do have to pace it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Desi came to see us after nine years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the changes that are happening right now, we're basically.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is our ground zero, we're starting with significant change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do feel optimistic, like when we read this report and when I read it, I saw the areas that were identified as deltas, but I really left feeling reassured because I felt like it was attainable that the new systems, the new structures that are in place, the new schedule, K-12, that we're gonna see the benefits and reap the benefits

[Edouard-Vincent]: with the changes that are happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They talked earlier about whether it's the DEIB work, what's happening for our most vulnerable populations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Tesheira talked about what they identified for EL and, you know, the whole thing of equality.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And yes, we're meeting the needs of our students at the McGlynn School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We don't have that population currently at the Andrew school, and for us to look at other options.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I don't want people who haven't yet seen the full report to feel like the district's falling apart because it actually isn't.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even in speaking with Jesse they're like, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is it's it's a decent report in terms of like we know what we need to do as a next step.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just don't want people to leave feeling like the district is failing and run pack up and run, because that's not what it's saying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's saying, if you do these strategic things instructionally, meeting the needs of all of our diverse learners, the district will continue to move forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I felt that it was optimistic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for the strategic plan, the feedback from member Graham, that first strategic plan, six years ago or five years ago, four years ago, right now the years are blurring together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we spent like a year and a half just trying to get the entire administrative team together to say, these are all of the things that are happening in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so now that we have that plan, we're able to say, okay, it's true.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It doesn't need to be as big as it is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's focus in and decide what are we gonna hone in on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the instructional priorities, which was the second to last slide, that's going to be what's going to really be our driving force moving forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just, I just wanted to provide that context because we should unpack it, we will continue to unpack it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But the data that we received from this really said to us, wow, we started earlier doing DEI work, and we're going to continue doing that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this summer, with the 35 other districts at Tufts University.

[Edouard-Vincent]: our team was able to see how much work they were actually doing that was in line with what was being presented at Tufts University with 35 other districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the question now is, how do we take this new data, this new information, and continue to propel the entire district forward?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's wonderful to be back.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So before I begin my update, I invite you all to join me in a moment of reflection on the 22nd anniversary of the September 11, 2001 terror attacks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is a very sad day for many Americans, especially those of us with ties to Massachusetts, New York, and Washington, D.C.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The anniversary of 9-1-1 is a reminder for all of us that things can change unexpectedly in a moment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to remember that over 3,000 individuals who died an untimely death, untimely and senseless death at the hands of terrorism.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May all their souls rest in peace and may their loved ones find solace and comfort in their memories.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Furthermore, we want to honor all of our firefighters, police, EMS, and other first responders who run into danger when most of us would run away from it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is no better time to say thank you to our first responders than today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I invite you all to reflect on a poem which one of my superintendent colleagues shared with me and all of the superintendents in Massachusetts this morning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's called The Power of One by Cheryl Sawyer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As the soot and dirt and ash rain down, we became one color.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we carried each other down the stairs of the burning building, we became one class.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we lit candles of waiting and hope, we became one generation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we fell to our knees in prayer for strength, we became one faith.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As the firefighters and police officers fought their way into the inferno, we became one gender.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we whispered or shouted words of encouragement, we spoke one language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we gave our blood in lines a mile long, we became one body.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we mourned together the great loss, we became one family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we cried tears of grief and loss, we became one soul.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we retell with pride of the sacrifice of heroes, we become one people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are one color, one class, one generation, one gender, one faith, one language, one body, one family, one soul, one people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are the power of one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are united.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To honor the memory of all the lost, I respectfully ask that we all rise for a moment of silence to remember those who died on that dark day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am going to shift gears because I would like to take some time to talk about our school opening and just coming back to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So although teachers and students reported back to the Medford Public Schools the week of August 28th, administrators and new teachers and staff returned the week prior.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Central administration was happy to welcome back our administrators together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're so excited and fortunate to welcome over 50 new staff to the Medford Public Schools community this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Wednesday, August 23rd, Dr. Bernadette Riccardelli organized a tour of Medford for our new teachers and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The tour included stops at Tufts University,

[Edouard-Vincent]: the Medford Public Library, and Medford City Hall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our maintenance and facilities teams have been working tirelessly to keep our systems online.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also wanna just share with the community that the Medford Public Schools has adopted a new messaging system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I did mention this in last week's communication, but we have migrated to Blackboard Connect.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so when we migrated and we sent out the first message on the new system,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were initially told that it would look the same so that our understanding was that it would be seamless.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You would receive it in your inbox and just receive a new message.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it was quickly brought to our attention that it was saying no reply at notification.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for some people, it ended up going into their spam boxes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So once we got that information, we wanted to let everyone know that we migrated to a new system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that signature that said in the past no reply at notification.com will now have a normal email address.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, we have migrated to Blackboard Connect and this new messaging system will work collaboratively with our website and our other platforms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to notify the committee and the community of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for that feedback.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We hope that as we continue to work on our official communications that everyone will see the quality of communications

[Edouard-Vincent]: improving and the presentation of the communications really being beautifully presented as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's going to continue to happen with the new platforms that we have, which now talk to one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thank you for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ooh, Gabby.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you share with the committee your four languages?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Gabby, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for coming out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for joining Mustang Nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're so glad to have you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, and then in addition to for the heat, a lot of the classrooms and hallways used reduced lighting shades down, we recommended kids were loose light fitted clothing, and no one was being encouraged to go outside and like

[Edouard-Vincent]: run like you're running in the, you know, running a marathon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was really, if they went outside, they could get some fresh air, but not to overexert themselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But if students didn't feel well, they definitely had access to water to stay hydrated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if they needed water breaks, they definitely could go and get that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then the nurses again were there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So everyone really tried to

[Edouard-Vincent]: not have the students become overexerted or to overexert themselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if that were to happen, the nurses were able to support those students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon, school committee members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm very pleased to introduce Mr. Gerald McHugh.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I enthusiastically recommend that the Medford School Committee vote to approve his appointment as interim finance director of the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. McHugh comes to us with more than 40 years of extensive hands-on experience in the educational and municipal finance administration and operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Gerry McCue retired from the Chelsea Public Schools in July of 2018 after almost 30 years of work as their executive director for administration and finance and school business manager.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Since 2018, he has continued to work as a school finance consultant.

[Edouard-Vincent]: His wealth of experience will be a great benefit to our district and community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During the interview process, Mr. McHugh impressed our team with his steadiness and experience.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a seasoned school finance professional, we're confident that he will complement and aid our central administrative team across a variety of relevant work areas, including accounting, revenue and expense forecasting, budget development, and financial data management and reporting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. McHugh earned his Bachelor of Science in Public Administration from Bentley College, Bentley University, and his Master of Science in Administrative Studies from Boston University.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are thrilled to welcome Jerry to Medford and know that his skills and experience will be major assets to the work of our team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I present to you Mr. Gerald McHugh and I am asking the committee for approval of his appointment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They have like a CPA licensure, but they do not have school finance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there are so many really critically important innuendos with school finance that the school finance administrative license is very, very limited.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That position posted, but the majority of the applicants do not have the proper credentialing they have financial credentialing but they don't have school finance experience at all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are looking at you know different options but

[Edouard-Vincent]: The pickings are slim and there are other districts that they found themselves in the same exact position.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're trying to think creatively about getting someone with the proper credentials to be able to come in and help us because next year will definitely be a year where we have to really start planning early.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to make sure that, you know, everyone is informed in a timely fashion and they know where we are, what's the status of our finances.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is a little space where we have compensation allocated for non-unit employees.

[Edouard-Vincent]: How much?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, if we were to be looking at all of

[Edouard-Vincent]: The totals, depending on what the committee will end up approving or not approving, we should be able to cover it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For the majority of non-unit employees, we have 2% allocated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there are a few individual contracts that are in the process of being renegotiated as we speak.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With the non-unit increases, we would have that coming out of the undistributed account, our undistributed errors and omissions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That is where we place

[Edouard-Vincent]: Right now, it's slightly over 500,000, and we're still negotiating a few of our contracts, unsettled contracts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Approximately for all, for the non-unit employees, we're probably in the vicinity of 120,000 to include the raises from the different departments across the district and level setting some salaries that were not level set for several years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So right-sizing salaries that are not competitive with our neighboring districts and colleagues, which is something where, you know, we're subject to people being recruited to go to other districts, good people that you wanna hold on to because other districts are able to recruit them at significantly higher rates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Graham.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would be remiss if I did not discuss today's Pride Month contest incident at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were made aware that a teacher's decorations for the Pride Month contest were torn down.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This type of incident will not be tolerated and has no place at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have spoken with Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Frances Nwaje, the city's Director of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, as well as Chief Buckley, Chief of Police for Medford, to initiate investigations into this matter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hate will not be tolerated here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A safe and supportive learning environment is what our Mustang community expects and deserves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are here for all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at the Renaissance, and I just have to say my bucket was completely filled.

[Edouard-Vincent]: dancing, jumping, singing, laughing, and really just enjoying themselves so it was a wonderful send off and I know Wednesday will be a continuation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, sorry, Margaret.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By next Wednesday,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, next Friday, I was going to ask for the just the additional two days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would love to be able to go all the way through.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I look forward to presenting the budget slide deck to you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I begin this evening's presentation, I wanted to share the Medford Public Schools funding sources.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are four areas where we receive as a district funding sources.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's the operating budget from the municipality, which is approximately 81%,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We receive grants, such as IDA, and our title grants, which amount to 12% answer, which was a one time funding source 2% and revolving accounts, which account for 6%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These percentages are representative of fiscal year 22 spending.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to qualify those percentages, but to let you know that there are multiple funding sources that contribute to the Medford Public Schools budget.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for funding sources,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford public schools operating budget is funded by the city of Medford general fund allocation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This amount is comprised of the chapter 70 state aid plus state determined minimum required local contribution.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The city contemplates all available financial resources and provides a general fund allocation to Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The state defines net school spending as the minimum amount a community must spend on education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford has historically allocated substantially in excess of the net school spending minimum amount.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, Medford Public Schools receives federal and state grants for its educational purposes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The total fund allocation is historically comprised as follows.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 20% of funding comes from the Commonwealth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's our chapter 70 allocation for education, our local aid and circuit breaker.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 5% comes from the federal government.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The federal government funding often includes or comes in the forms of the special grants which I mentioned earlier title one title for ID a food service, etc.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These grants are not part of the general fund allocation and are separately managed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 75% of our funding comes from the city of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It comes from a general miscellaneous revenue, which does include property taxes, meals and hotel taxes, excise taxes, and the like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thus far with our budget process, the FY 24 process, today is May 15th, and today I will be presenting the superintendent's recommendations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, the remaining steps on this timeline, we started back in June, the strategic planning goals were approved, budget surveys took place during the month of March,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those surveys were for department heads district administrators school committee members to weigh in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had budget meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And now today is the recommendation, our next meeting on June 5 will also be the school committee requests to the municipal government.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And sometime in June will be the municipal appropriation and the school committee adopting the budget that meets the appropriation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as of July 1st is the official implementation of the new budget, the new fiscal year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our budget objectives today for May 15th will be the superintendent's recommendations on the strategic priorities of Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our FY23 budget numbers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools adopted operating budget, which was approved in June, was $69,294,776.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we move forward,

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as I frame the district's priorities and present my recommendations, I want us to keep in mind what is Medford's future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The aim of the Medford Public Schools is to equip our students higher education and professional pursuits.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This objective is the driving force behind all of our efforts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the key priorities for school year 23-24 are going to fall into four categories, which are aligned to our strategic plan, the ACEs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Regarding achievement collaboration, equity and safety and support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So stabilization is one of our key priorities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to focus on the culture and climate district wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: stabilize operations at Medford High School, plan for integrated scheduling at Medford High School for the 24-25 school year, in addition to the new schedule that will also be implemented this year for our elementary schools, which will no longer be having the early release Wednesdays, but a different schedule.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under the bucket of curriculum and instruction,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, we will be implementing new programming in literacy to fully integrate the science of reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that presentation will be coming to the committee by next month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to a new literacy program that will be chosen is a new health program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there have been many, many meetings with the HECAT team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we'll be looking forward to hearing what their recommendations are as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, this is to provide enhanced offerings for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our third category is recommitting to the arts with the integration of an art rotation in the traditional CTE programming.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is the programming that takes place in our vocational, with our vocational programming, vocational programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: CTE stands for career technical education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this year,

[Edouard-Vincent]: For grade nine, we will be introducing the fine arts in a theater, theater instruction, taking place this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, again, it's going to be enhanced offerings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to the, the, the vocational offerings that students normally receive.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The fourth category is going to be expanded CTE, which is, again, growing our CTE programming and expanding to meet the Medford demand, which is ever increasing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of our key priorities, again, similar to what you saw in the previous slide, just presented differently.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The categories, strategic staffing investments, focused on our most vulnerable learners, literacy interventionists, social workers, adjustment Councilors, the theater teacher, CTE expansion, occupational therapy, and speech and language services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Professional development and training is going to be critically important, especially for the new programming that we plan on bringing on for next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be offering building-based professional development, district-wide professional development, looking at restorative practices, responsive classroom, and continued training in the new literacy program and continued training in math, because those are both new programs at the elementary levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Summer programming again grant dependent, but we are definitely moving forward this summer with fine arts, to add to our traditional array of summer programming options for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the fourth category is miscellaneous departmental supplements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, as I mentioned earlier, it's critically important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have two different schedules, six day rotation on the comprehensive side of the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and a five day rotation on the vocational side, and we need to carefully merge the two different schedules so that we will be able to maximize offerings for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and consideration for our elementary new schedule in order to provide the maximum amount of teacher time together, common planning time, grade level team meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We needed to add an additional 4.0 specialists in order to make the new schedule work and in order for us to be in compliance with our new CBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's just the historical overview of what the superintendent's key priorities are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we're gonna move into the operating budget.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as I transition to the operating budget, I will begin with what the superintendent's budget recommendation is for the next school year, 23-24 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The recommendation that I'm putting before the committee this evening is 71,835,165.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This new number reflects comprehensive budget review, following meetings with

[Edouard-Vincent]: principals, directors, senior leadership, really, really looking at anywhere where we could bring about savings and seek other sources, financial sources to make our budget work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here I have a list of some of our fixed cost increases that are expected for next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under the line item of salary and personnel, we're expecting a fixed cost increase of approximately $2.7 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This number includes the six completed CBAs and presents 2% for the remaining CBAs and non-unit personnel.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we have special education, transportation, maintenance, and athletics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here is another way to review the FY24 to maintain level services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for salary and personnel, as I discussed just on the previous slide, there's a $2.7 million increase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in FY23, it was $56.7 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for next year, it's going to be approximately $59.4 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Out of district tuition, for FY23, it was 3.7 million, and for FY24, we are expecting it to be $4.2 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For school bus transportation, FY23 was approximately 1.2 million, and that anticipated increase is 1.25 million for FY24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for utilities and gas 1.85 million for FY 23 expected 2 million for FY 24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our outside cleaning contract, I gave the historical overview of 400,000 in fiscal year 22, 445,000 is FY23.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are anticipating 45 to a $50,000 increase for FY24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for our specialized transportation which is our van special education vans we are expecting an increase there from 1.5 million to 2.2 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for our operating budget reductions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We really took time to look at budget identify areas where we could make reductions, and we have approximately $772,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: identified as reductions thus far for the 23-24 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That includes things such as a double head count when there was a leave of absence, necessary reductions in positions due to lower enrollment,

[Edouard-Vincent]: cancellations of unnecessary technology platforms that might have been relevant during the pandemic but right now we're not having, you know, significant user subscription use.

[Edouard-Vincent]: are recommended investments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: secondary schedule works, because again at the secondary level, all teachers are content area specialists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a cluster, but at the elementary level, the teachers are experts in every single area because they teach reading math science social studies history, you know spelling penmanship, they teach all of

[Edouard-Vincent]: every single content area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they need that time as well to be able to work together and further their practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 45 minutes or 35 minutes when they had the previous schedule of the early release Wednesdays, when it was all said and done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that that was like something that was necessary in order to really give them that opportunity to work and collaborate together as professionals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, I am truly pleased and honored to present this Mustang hero award for special recognition to Mr. Kenneth Thompson Rodriguez, who is an 11th grade student at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am pleased to present him with this award.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week on Tuesday, May 9th, the high school nursing office received an emergency call on the walkie-talkie during student lunches.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When nurses Jennifer Silver and Sarah Kelly arrived at the scene, Kenneth had stepped up and given a fellow MPS student the Heimlich maneuver.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And his fast action really helped that student who was choking.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And just an important fact for everyone to know that the nursing office shared with us that in the United States, choking is the fourth leading cause of unintentional injury death.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are very, very proud of you, Kenneth, that you took the initiative, you stepped up and helped your fellow Mustang.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we would like to present you with this special certificate, and I will pass it on to the mayor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Fallon, can we have Mr. Sam Christie, the wonderful teacher, and I know Mr. Noah Lukowitz isn't with us, but please come forward as well for your wonderful leadership and instruction of the students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, come on up, Mr. Christie.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Don't be shy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Christie.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Christie, can you say who we're in competition with?

[Edouard-Vincent]: You were mentioning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's fabulous, fabulous, fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Absolutely fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would love for us to take a picture as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we will definitely get certificates to all of you as well for your wonderful accomplishment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So do you want to come forward so we can take a picture together?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So dear mayor longer current and members of the school committee, as the year winds down to a close, it is hard to believe that there are only six weeks of school left to this academic year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I had the opportunity to gather data and reflect on this past year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was so much to be proud of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And yet at the same time, during the most difficult times, there were many lessons learned from crises.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can say that looking back, I have grown both professionally and personally this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I forge ahead, I am determined to stay focused on what is important and positive, our students and our staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools, currently we are at an important crossroads and through thoughtful community and family collaboration, we will continue to improve and thrive as a district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will provide a few brief highlights now, but I look forward to taking you on my journey with the Medford Public Schools this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools continues to be an inclusive school district, rich in history and diversity, which offers so many educational opportunities for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We encourage our parents and caregivers to collaborate and to partner in their students' educational processes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: My aces of achievement collaboration equity and support guide me in my duties daily.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, social emotional learning continues to be a cornerstone of our district, along with responsive classroom and restorative practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year we work to hire additional guidance Councilors and social workers adjustment Councilors school psychologists, teachers and many more.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We join the Sandy Hook promise to teach our students to start with hello, see something say something initiative, and new to us this year, we implemented the new say something anonymous reporting system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in an effort to empower everyone, students and staff to help create change and promote safer schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also implemented a 10 point action plan at Medford High School for safety, transparency, culture, climate and accountability, which did include the Sandy Hook promise, updating the handbook and implementing new hall and bathroom passes for students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, we offered viewings of screenagers presentations for our middle school students and parents and caregivers to help them be aware of the dangers of too much screen time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In my practice, I continue to bring an equity lens to all the work that I do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I stand in agreement with this quote from Maya Angelou.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In diversity, there is beauty and there is strength.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In Medford, there is so much beautiful diversity and strength.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I continue to work and support Medford Public Schools' work on race, equity, and diversity across the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I continue to serve as well on the Melrose Wakefield Hospital Tufts Medicine Board of Trustees, and also as a member of District Attorney Marion Ryan's anti hate anti bias task force, to name a few.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In closing, for this portion, the sea of aces represents collaboration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Without the collaboration, thought partnership, and input from my senior leadership team, Peter Cushing, Suzanne Galuzzi, Joan Bowen, and MPS administrators, this work could not exist.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm truly grateful that I have such a talented team to work with collaboratively with and on behalf of Medford Public School students, staff, and the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next category of 3C communications.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which I mentioned earlier in my opening remarks, we engage in regular two way culturally proficient communication with families and community stakeholders about student learning and performance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The weekly memo, although it is one sided going out in one direction the weekly memo does.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We ensure that it is translated in the four most popular languages that are in the district, which are Spanish, Portuguese, Haitian Creole, and Arabic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for talking points, it's a two-way application that we use with our non-English speaking families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that has really gotten significant traction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: where messages can be sent out to families through talking points, and they are able to respond right away and communicate with teachers or administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is one of the areas where we clearly, I feel, are making strong inroads with communications and with our families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we had many, many negotiations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: when they had taken place, and also the say something app which was presented to the committee already, but this is again something where students, staff, if they want to be able to report something anonymously, they are able to report it and we are able to follow through with that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so those are all of the indicators and I just wanted to thank the community, and the committee for this opportunity to present my.

[Edouard-Vincent]: self-assessment to you and provide evidence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just wanted to close in saying that in order to continue the work of leading this district, it could not be done again without the support of a team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I wholeheartedly thank the support of my senior leadership team again, and the administrators who manage all the schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This takes collaboration and coordination of teams, administrators, teachers, and staff,

[Edouard-Vincent]: to create the best learning environment for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, I close by saying I am still the very proud superintendent of the Medford Public Schools, and I am very grateful to be a member of this community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And those are my closing remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please refer to the school calendar posted on our website for a listing of the dates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also in order to accommodate transportation needs middle school dismissal on half days will be at 1130 am high school dismissal will be at noon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just wanted to weigh in just to say this is definitely a very rich conversation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I actually feel like even though the original document was too long,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We should probably really make a concerted effort to see how we could really get the document down to be a manageable size document, so that it isn't overwhelming to families and to parents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And focus on the key, the key pieces that need to be in the policy, following the law, because I think it is true, if we end up echoing what was just shared by member Graham and member was so that if we have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We can make references to other policies, but we haven't gotten into the habit of just being able to clearly cite a policy because the policies are on, you know, that's the whole point of the subcommittee, trying to get us to a place where we're going to have

[Edouard-Vincent]: clean policies that people will understand that are easy to translate, that are digestible for all stakeholders, for them to understand, okay, this is what I need to do when bullying takes place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I almost feel like now that we have the language or we have highlights for the areas that need to stay legally because of the law, let's stick with those pieces.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then again, if it means creating a separate policy, but freestanding,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would be in support of that because we're only on page five and if at this rate, we'll be lucky if we even make it to page eight by six o'clock and there are many, many, many comments that need to be adjusted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the comments I think

[Edouard-Vincent]: instead of student member of the school staff, you know, like some comments might be able to just be tweaked and everyone will be able to accept those comments, but also just for us to feel like we're able to make progress because May is next week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to member Ruseau's point, like if, if we can't at least, you know, make a decision to get through this one policy during this school year, um,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to be still working on this policy come September, so that that was just my.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I encourage us to kind of like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: focus on the bullying, focus on the key pieces that we need to focus on and not mix multiple policies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was our attempt a few years back trying to update it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we can see, there were many flaws.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were areas that were repeated unnecessarily.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just feel like we should really try to get this document down to at least half its size if that's possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, no, I was gonna say, I was definitely in support of removing the scope and sequence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think probably in 2010 or when that was added, it was appropriate, but where we're gonna be changing programs and I don't think any of this is really necessary for what we're doing right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I just wanted to comment because when the bullying investigation takes place and you follow the flowchart, there are pieces that you have to look for to make the differentiation between is it truly bullying or is it a disciplinary incident?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so sometimes

[Edouard-Vincent]: In some people's interpretation, it could be defined or interpreted to be bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in some situations, it's a disciplinary incident.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just want to say that we do have some students within the district that may need additional supports

[Edouard-Vincent]: based on their specific learning needs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so sometimes in those areas, we might have higher incidents or higher occurrences of certain things that take place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as a result of the IEP, for example, and we realize that it might be identified as part of a child's disability, we're not going to be identifying every single incident as bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't have a problem with greater accountability, but I also just want to say that sometimes we're dealing with situations that there's an area of gray that has to be taken into consideration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had specialized training with all of the administrators around bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We worked with Murphy, Hesse, Toomey, and Lehane to really

[Edouard-Vincent]: understand what is it that administrators legally can do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I don't have a problem with having them come back to redo the training, but I do feel that they, you know, they clearly explained to all the administrators, you know, what was acceptable and kind of helping us really parse out the law.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if there are other situations that, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: family members have a concern about maybe how something was handled, they can always bring it to the superintendent's attention.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I just don't want to have like blanket statements written into a policy and then there are other documents or other pieces of information that we have access to that, you know, aren't going to be,

[Edouard-Vincent]: taken into consideration the same way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want us to be careful that we're not trying to over legislate this bullying policy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think we need to be clear that this particular document is specifically about bullying and what the law says.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we truly are trying our best to follow the law.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if there are disciplinary incidents which don't rise to the level of bullying, then they're going to be handled as a disciplinary offense.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a disciplinary incident.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just want to say that because, you know, there are limitations when we're dealing with discipline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are some things that we have to keep in mind, and I know it might not be the answer that everyone wants to hear, but we do have to follow the law for all students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just wanted to say that the language that Member Graham just, not Member Graham, Member McLaughlin just added about, you said students with disabilities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think if we leave, if we add that language, I still do feel that we should leave the IEP and 504 language in there because there are students that are on maybe an IEP or a 504 where

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, self regulation may be listed as an official disability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so those students are entitled to

[Edouard-Vincent]: additional protections according to their IEP.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just didn't want to remove the words IEP and or 504 from the bullying report and add what member McLaughlin said to include students with disabilities that may not have an IEP or a 504.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I just want people to know that there are some things legally that

[Edouard-Vincent]: we have to take into consideration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if we don't take into consideration, then once again, the district is liable and the district is at fault for not following the IEP or 504 plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to add that piece so that those who may come back and watch later understand that there are some other things that we do need to keep in mind.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon, Mustang family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am so excited to be here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have right now 77, probably more than 77, because I see some of you are with your parents right now on the call.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm really excited.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are getting ready to do our middle school lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am Dr. Edouard-Vincent, your very proud superintendent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And with me today, I have our data manager, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kim Miles.

[Edouard-Vincent]: who is going to be working magic in the background on the table right behind me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And next to me is Dr. Bernadette Riccadeli, who is our director of professional learning and student assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Dr. Riccadeli is here as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we go through today's process to actually select the schools and do the actual lottery, if there are questions,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be putting it in the chat box.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you have questions or you need clarification or support, either Dr. Ricciardelli or Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kim Miles, you will be able to email them with questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we will make sure that we get that into the chat box.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want to thank you all for your patience.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a couple of different technology.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're using the Zoom room and we're using our individual computers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're muted at different points.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want to end the suffering and hopefully have lots of rejoicing that's going to take place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to start this lottery process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as soon again, as the schools are picked,

[Edouard-Vincent]: we will be working very diligently to get those numbers online.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that you will be so give us about an hour, but we may be able to get it online, you know, maybe within 30 to 40 minutes.
