[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, Madam President Morell and esteemed body of our city council.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, City Councilors, all of you for having me this evening to present our resubmission of the MSBA statement of input statement of interest application.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We submitted a year ago and we've submitted many years in the past.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This past year, we were very close, but

[Edouard-Vincent]: based on the feedback that we had received, the amount of schools that were approved this past year was a smaller number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as a result of that, we just weren't able to make the number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We didn't make the cut, but we were given very positive feedback to resubmit our application, which we have done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I'm requesting the entire city council if you would approve Medford Public Schools reapplication for the statement of interest for the core program for Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm available to answer any questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Councilor Knight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, we had a very strong application, again this past year, and because the number of schools that were awarded this year was a reduced number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Unfortunately, we, we just missed that cut.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and we were encouraged by the MSBA to resubmit for this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is one key difference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In previous years, MSBA was having two programs, the accelerated repair program and the core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This current year,

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are not accepting applications.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They're not doing the accelerated repair program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's only the core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're resubmitting our application from last year with the addition of a few things that have surfaced at the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had pipes bursting and some asbestos work for tiles that had popped on the floor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we did have additional work

[Edouard-Vincent]: that needed to be done because the building is aging.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we are reapplying for the core program and MSBA will come back out if we're approved, if our statement of interest is approved, they will come back out and do a senior study and follow the appropriate steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I also want to say that this is just, today's request is permission to,

[Edouard-Vincent]: reapply with the statement of interest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But as we continue with MSBA, there will be multiple opportunities to come before your body and respond to questions and let you know the status of what is happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: MSBA just does not want a school district on their own to go and say, we're putting in this application and not have the support of both the school committee and the city council.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The school committee did approve it last week for us to move forward, and my request is that the city council will allow us to apply.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think we should continue to apply.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that the high school needs work, and I feel very confident in our resubmission and based on the feedback that we received that we should not give up but move forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The additional pieces that I just shared were things that happened this year since we applied.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's what it was, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: No, it's not identical year before last year's application was was significantly different brought in consultants and had additional help in terms of how we structured the application.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so last year's application was looked upon very favorably, and we did advance to the next phase of senior study, which is promising.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some districts do not advance even to that phase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we were able to advance to the second phase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we did receive positive feedback from MSBA to definitely reapply.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so,

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's, that's why we're reapplying resubmitting the application was the additions, what was the consultants cost.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do not have the cost of the consultant right now but we did secure additional support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I don't, I can get that number to you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Just waiting for the slide deck to be pulled up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I'm going to be presenting before the committee this budget update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And based on questions that came in from the members and were asked last week, I have attempted to respond to provide answers for the majority of the questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm going to start the presentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the first thing, for those of you in the community who are just joining for the first time and are not certain how school budgets function and the different funding streams that are available to school districts, this slide shows that these are the different ways that funding comes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the governor's budget,

[Edouard-Vincent]: submits an allocation to the municipality.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That funding goes to the municipality, the city of Medford, and the city of Medford's chapter 70 allocation, that's what the city, local aid, local contribution, that's what comprises the city's funding sources.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Based on the allocation from the city, that funding funnels and goes to all of Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it allows us to address our district priorities and goals, departmental priorities and goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It includes the superintendent's recommendations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This process, the budget meeting process, which is a multi-step process,

[Edouard-Vincent]: school committee requests.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We receive again the municipal appropriations and then eventually school committee adoption.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also federal funding is involved in this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the federal government provides supplemental grants and again it's intended to supplement, not to supplant.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we receive federal and state grants, our title grants, our Perkins grants, our IDEA grants at the time of the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the additional COVID-19 grants.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I want to state that these allocations, the federal government grants, they fluctuate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it does not remain the same exact amount every year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes there's a slight increase and sometimes there is a decrease.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say this is kind of where the funding streams kind of come from that come to the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next slide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In particular, for Medford Public Schools, all of our funding sources are as follows.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The general fund allocation, which we talked about the Chapter 70 allocation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grants, again, IDEA title grants.

[Edouard-Vincent]: ESSER, which is one time funding source.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the fourth funding source is revolving accounts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The revolving accounts are accounts that are based out of Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not part of the official operating budget, but it is a funding source that we do use.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So everything that is happening within the district comes from these four

[Edouard-Vincent]: funding sources, so I hope you can see that there are funding sources coming from these four areas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in response to the budget process, right now we are at April 10th, and there were several steps that have already taken place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The school committee has approved the district's strategic plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were budget surveys that were administered during the month of March that went to school committee members, department heads, administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are now in the process of having budget meetings discussing funding and where we are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And right now we're at our second budget meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This process will continue where the superintendent will give formal recommendations coming up at the May 1st meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: School committee will formally put in their requests by the May 15th meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in this context, the municipal appropriation was given to us a little earlier.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do need to slide that block up forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The committee will adopt it in June, and there will be implementation in July.

[Edouard-Vincent]: July 1 is the implementation of the new fiscal year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the previous budget objectives at our April 3 meeting, which was just a week ago, it was the introduction to the budget process and reviewing our FY 23 allocation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today we will be looking at some funding requests, reviewing the available FY 24 ESSER funds and highlighting some priorities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Upcoming on May 1st will be the official recommendations on our strategic priorities for Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our FY23 budget, the budget that we are currently in right now, we were allocated 68,994,776.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these are our FY23 budget numbers that we're currently working with right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our anticipated operating budget that was given to us from the municipality is $71 million for FY 24 budget numbers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our anticipated operating budget to be approved in June is totals a $1.7 million increase over the operating budget that we received last year, which is the equivalent is a 2.5% increase for this coming fiscal year, FY 24.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of the key budget drivers, which I will talk about later, is our employment agreements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And just for a refresher, our FY22, based on our contracts that were settled, 2.5% increase for FY22, 2.5% increase for FY23.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and for FY 24, 2.5% plus an additional 1% on the 100th day of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, we're talking about a $1.1 million fixed cost increase based on FY 23 increases, and that is inclusive of the teachers only.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I reviewed some of the fixed cost increases, and again, I wanted to just go back to kind of restate some of the fixed costs that we know are going to increase and where some of them are going to have impacts on this budget process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are aware that for FY24, which starts on July 1, that our special education costs are going to increase, and that projection is around $1 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, that is a projection because we know that there is an unanticipated, unknown piece to those numbers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our FY 24 contractual increases across the board, our increases to personnel, we are anticipating that at a $3.3 million increase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A significant portion 2% in FY 22 and 2% sent in FY 23 of these increases were incorporated into our last two budgets in anticipation of our negotiations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: still with FY23 and 24 increases, exceeding the budgeted amounts, that has really impacted our flexibility that we previously thought would have been, that we previously thought would have existed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For FY 24, we do have anticipated vendor increases.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'm saying anticipated because we are still working on some numbers for outside contracts, transportation, and maintenance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those are anticipated, but we know it's going to increase and not decrease.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are still working on additional CBAs for our custodians, our monitors, our administrators, our security monitors, and our food service workers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here is another way of looking at our anticipated increases.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I will kind of restate this again later in the slide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Out-of-district tuitions, we're expecting again from 3.7 million, which was allocated for this year, FY23, we're expecting that increase to be approximately 4.2 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, that number can fluctuate our transportation and van services as a 10% increase there from 1.5 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are expecting or anticipating approximately 2.24 again that number can fluctuate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our transportation and school bus, our big yellow bus transportation, we anticipate going from 1.2 million to approximately 1.25 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we are looking at that anticipated that our current contract and also looking at the possibility of other contracts to look to see what's going to best meet the needs of the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a few more anticipated increases, utilities, gas and electric.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those are increasing as well from 1.85 million for FY23.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are expecting it to come in around $2 million for gas and electric next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And our cleaning contract, FY23, we paid $445,000 for that contract.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are anticipating an increase in that, a similar increase of $45,000 to $50,000 for our cleaning contracts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say where some of these anticipated increases are coming from.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So to total all of that, we're looking at approximately $1.4 million increase in ordinary expenses, things that are non-salary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So a $1.4 million increase in ordinary expenses, a $3.3 million increase in personnel expenses.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And those are our settled CBAs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are anticipating a $4.7 million increase, which is about 6.8%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So just based on the increases that are in place and our approximations, we would be anticipating a $74 million potential request

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is a gap that we will definitely need to address moving forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want to address the FY23 and FY24 ESSER budgets.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I did mention this in our previous presentations, but I just wanna say how some of our ESSER funding is currently being used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for cell and counseling programs, for supervision and evaluation, professional development, for talking points and other subscriptions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are doing analyses on subscriptions that are not being used to the highest levels about dropping those.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that number,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although you see a TBD listed, we are really working at looking at the usability of all of the subscriptions, and we're still in the process of calculating those numbers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For our MBTA PASS program, we will probably, this will be one of the areas that we will talk about.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We anticipated $150,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are thinking we're going to be closer to $202,000 for next year as an anticipated expense.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The connectivity fund, we still have as TBD.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for summer programming, we have those listed as TBD.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Continuing with our FY 23, 24 estimated budget, we have some numbers that are fairly similar.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Currently right now, our engagement specialists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've had some were engagement specialists we did have a vacancy we had some turnover, and we had some engagement specialists that are not 1.0.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are working in supporting the district, but they are working for us in a point six capacity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that also attributes for the lower number that you're seeing for behavior specialists were anticipating 130,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have the 1.0 reading specialists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we are to carry two of them on our ESSER funding, it would be approximately 200,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our ELL newcomer program, we do have newcomer, we currently have five newcomer staff, and we're looking at that number as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then we have another,

[Edouard-Vincent]: payout of $, that will be coming out of our funding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hill for literacy, which is our intensive professional development that we are offering for

[Edouard-Vincent]: are elementary educators who are participating in that professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We still have it at approximately 90,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the last time I presented to you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we still have four more that we're working on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that number, the 3.3 million will go up by the end of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Hays was communicating with me earlier today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had some, there were some additional supplemental, I'm gonna just look at the list of what we had that was deferred from last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An example of a deferred position was like we had something, a transportation coordinator.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They use Adobe Illustrator.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The special machine is a Roland 54 inch VersaCam.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and they laminate the books and they add granites.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And these books are going to be posted to fences in some of the parks throughout Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: or the Gay Lesbian Straight Network of Silence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is a day that started back in the mid-90s by two college students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Day of Silence is when LGBTQ plus students and allies all around the country and the world take a vow of silence to protest the harmful effects of harassment and discrimination of LGBTQ plus students in schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is expanded to reach hundreds of thousands of students each year, and students share their experiences to bring attention to ways their schools and communities can become more inclusive.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In terms of diversifying the school force, we are making a concerted effort.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Every time we publicize and advertise jobs, not only do we do it on the district school website, but we also use NEMNET, which is another organization,

[Edouard-Vincent]: where candidates of color, they could be from other states, also have access to jobs that are posted just to see if there's interest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And most recently we are working collaboratively with a few of our neighboring districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Chelsea, Everett, Malden, Revere, there's going to be a

[Edouard-Vincent]: upcoming job fair April 26 so we're working with five other communities and Medford will be represented at that one to see if that will increase our chances of having other candidates

[Edouard-Vincent]: participate so we did do it last year with Chelsea and we did have other candidates but more bilingual candidates that came through but again once they have options and you're working with four or five other districts the candidates have to decide what districts maybe where they live.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, those are other factors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, we are trying to be intentional about partnering and collaborating with other districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're all in the same exact boat.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, when I say that everyone's looking for teachers, so it's about what is most special about your community, that someone will say, oh, I want to come to Medford instead of going to,

[Edouard-Vincent]: another district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we are partnering with universities and trying to work with Lesley, UMass, and some of our other local schools to say if we're advertising and looking for candidates, please advertise and post for us as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are trying to find

[Edouard-Vincent]: Unusual interesting ways if we're able to bring in interns that could potentially be trained with us for one year and then if there's an opening in their specific area, then they would be able to come but Right now with education and in other areas that the numbers there isn't as much interest as there was in the past And I do think the pandemic did make a lot of people fearful in terms of working in a school environment or

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some people, like, I don't want to be in a classroom anymore.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to do something else.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A lot of people have chosen work from home options.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they're working remotely in all sectors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are going to have our work cut out for us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even at the state level, DESE with the department, our department of education, elementary and secondary education, they are also aware of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: trying to think about ways to be able to recruit and allow people to come into education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are looking at waivers for people who may have special licenses in math or physics or even languages that are being taught.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that they may not yet be fully licensed, but DESE is willing to work with them and say, OK, we'll give you a waiver.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But with with that waiver, you have like a one to three year window to go and get all of the official credentialing in line.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then you would be official with the state.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are trying all different avenues, but it is something that's going to take time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I do want people to know that it's not for a lack of trying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's just that there are a lack of candidates or a very limited number of candidates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just want everyone to know that as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Graham, if I may, through the chair, Member Ruseau, I agree that here right now, especially with the changes that we're trying to make, we definitely are providing people with bullying paperwork.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If families feel that bullying has taken place,

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in that regards, we're not trying to run away and not conduct the investigations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even if the determination is at the end that it might not be bullying, it could be something else.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But maybe Principal DeLeva could speak to it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I am aware, and I do know that sometimes

[Edouard-Vincent]: a bullying claim or something could be reported.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then there's evidence, maybe cell phone evidence, texting or things that were on social media that might show otherwise.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not the norm, it is the exception, but it has happened within the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I don't know if you could give a very kind of vague example, Principal DeLeva.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Um, I just also wanted to say that I'm similar to DCF if I can make this scenario that when 51 a is filed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is ruled in for 10 days, and DCF does the investigation, and at the end of their determined investigation they determine whether it's ruled in or ruled out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, if a family is going to complete the bullying paperwork, we are going to look at it from the perspective of, we have to rule it in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: conduct the investigation, and then at the end come to the determination.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I don't want people to think that we don't want to go through the process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's better to be safe than sorry.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So complete the paperwork, submit it, and we'll conduct the investigation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it will either be the rule in or the rule out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so with DCF,

[Edouard-Vincent]: What they say to us, Department of Children and Families, is when in doubt, file, and let them make the determination.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if a family is in doubt, they should complete the paperwork, and then let us do the investigation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was gonna say, depending on the age of the child and like the, you know, at the high school where the kids are much older, but if it were to be in the younger grades, we definitely would have to have, you know, parent involvement and consent for them to know what was going on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But the high school, I think, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some students are 16, 17.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can't thank you, Principal Tucci's on as well, but I would definitely say, depending on the age of the child, and as we're revamping this, it could be something where we just say, no matter what, as part of the policy in Medford, parents, no matter what grade level, whether you're 11th grade or sixth grade, parents have to be notified that the bullying paperwork is being completed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Anyone can fill out a form, any staff person at all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you so it in the event, I know we had talked about the flow chart before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But if, for example, conflict was the determination, it wouldn't just be that oh there was a conflict and nothing else is done, depending on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: what the situation involves, counseling is an option.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So working with the families, communicating with parents, whether it's writing to the parents, giving them a letter, speaking with them, emailing them, Zooming them in this modern day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then there are follow-up meetings that can happen with Councilors or teachers or

[Edouard-Vincent]: other parties that are involved.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it isn't just kind of like, oh, it's a conflict and you never address it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is some, I would say, follow up, but it would depend on, again, what each situation is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's on an individualized basis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I think once a bullying investigation takes place, you're now on the administration's radar in a more substantive way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if conflict is determined, you also would be aware because there were students that aren't dealing with bullying at all and aren't having any conflicts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel that there would be additional supervision or additional scrutiny to just make sure that things are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: staying calm the way you want them to be and not heading back in the direction of bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's just, it would be an appropriate response to what the outcome is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But for DESE purposes, when we're reporting to the state and it's meeting what the law states, they want that information documented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: from a state perspective.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for conflicts, restorative circles, working with Councilors, guidance Councilors, adjustment Councilors, school psychologists, the teacher, the administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are a lot of potential offshoots that the conflict could be addressed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't want people to think that it's a conflict and you never follow up, never deal with it again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: No, I just think that there, there definitely was a lot of information or suggestions shared today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: hopefully something wonderful that said.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're here today to discuss the Middle School Lottery for the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And what I'm going to do is I'm gonna take you through a slide deck, an informational slide deck with data kind of telling you where the Middle School Lottery started, the beginning, and then where we are right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So just give me a moment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to share my screen with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also saw that we had some administrators on the line.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I wanna thank those administrators for jumping on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I saw Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Demos online and I'm not sure some people don't have their names showing, but thank you for jumping on and I'll keep my eye out to recognize any other administrators who may join the call.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So just give me a moment to share my screen and hopefully everyone can see it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'm going to begin the slide deck.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the name of the slide deck is Correcting the Imbalance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in 2019,

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was the first time that the lottery was actually done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what I'm gonna share with you is the history of why Medford Public Schools has a lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This, what you're looking at right now is a demographic data for the McGlynn Middle School in 2019.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if I just move to the next slide,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was the data for the racial breakdown of data for the Andrews Middle School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to the racial breakdown that there was a noticeable disparity between the two schools,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also, at that point in time, were able to show you the socioeconomic status breakdown.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so this was the McGlynn School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this was data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was a problem of practice that was presented to me when I came to Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: with how would you propose finding a way to better balance the two schools?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because there were significant discrepancies between the two schools that you could see that there were differences, not only in racial breakdown, but also in the socioeconomic status of the students that were attending the schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so there was an ask of how could we make the two communities become better balanced?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we knew that we wouldn't be able to have both schools be exactly the same, but how could we bring about greater balance between the two schools?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as a result of that problem of practice, that challenge that we were facing, the middle school lottery was birthed with the intention of balancing, better balancing the two schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They're both middle schools, which you know, they're both essentially located on the same campus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can look out the window and you see one building, you look out the other window and you see the other building.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so there were a lot of questions about why was there such a discrepancy?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And let's do a lottery and see if we did a lottery, would the data change?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the next two slides that I'm gonna share with you are this year's current data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with the birth of the lottery, it did change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the 2022-2023 data for the McGlynn Middle School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, although we were not able to again get them to be exactly the same.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can see that the needle definitely moved significantly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: From the previous slides, if I just go back and show you the original two slides, when you looked at the breakdown of the schools, this being the McGlynn in 2019, where it was 46.1% of the student population were white students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the following slide

[Edouard-Vincent]: Excuse me one second, the following slide showing the Andrews where it was 73.6% in 2019, and if we advance once again to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The McGlynn right now it's 56% of our population is is comprised of white students and all the other races are also identified and 61% of our students at the Andrews are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: of Caucasian descent and all of the other subcategories have also shifted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is definitely greater balance between Native American, Hispanic, Latino, Asian, African-American, and then multi-race.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, you can see that the schools, again, although not perfectly balanced,

[Edouard-Vincent]: but better balanced in the McGlynn, 13% African-American, 10% Asian, 15%, 15.6% Latino, Hispanic, and 0.2% Native American.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is just to share with you again, kind of what was behind the lottery taking place for the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what does the lottery look like?

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is a summary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 50% of students at all of our fifth grades at every elementary school will be assigned to one school, the Andrews, and 50% will be assigned to the McGlynn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, to the best of our ability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now there are a few caveats that I wanna explain to parents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If a student has a program level, a specific educational need, whether they're an English learner or if they were to be a student with disabilities, they would be placed in the school that offers that particular program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with the lottery, we have something with sibling preference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you have a child that's currently at the school and will be at the school at the same time as a parent, you have the option to select sibling preference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And also for parents that have twins or children that just wanna be separated, you also have the option to opt out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if you have one student at one school, and you're like, I don't wanna activate sibling preference, I want it to be an authentic lottery experience, then if that is the case, your child will go into the lottery, and as they go into the lottery, you take your chances, and it's a 50-50 chance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please note that for sibling preference,

[Edouard-Vincent]: the sibling does need to be either in sixth grade or seventh grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you would essentially have two children in attendance at the same time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there was one other tiny note that we had for our English learner population.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We allow buffer seats, and I'll explain that a little more as we go forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here is an example of a sample school because the rules essentially apply.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So at this point, you'll hear me say middle school A, middle school B, but it's essentially two schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are 103 students in a fifth grade class, in a fifth grade at one of the elementary schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We add an additional three buffer seats for our English learner population.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of you may be saying, why do you need to add buffer seats?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, our English learner population,

[Edouard-Vincent]: they enroll within the district on a rolling basis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's not as if all students are able to start on the first day of school in August.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some students may transfer to Medford in November, others may come in January.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so as a result of it being a moving number,

[Edouard-Vincent]: we added three buffer seats in for each school for a total of 12 seats for the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can say to you now that we've done the lottery multiple times, we have exceeded those 12 seats.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the sample school has 106 seats total.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In this model, the lottery is taking place, 20 students are classified as English learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and they will go to middle school A because middle school A offers the English learner program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is one student that has a middle school A sibling preference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are seven students that have a middle school B sibling preference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Two students have a program requirement to go to middle school A special education program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One student has a program requirement to attend middle school B.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for that group of 12 students, we do a separate lottery because we try to balance the caseloads between the two schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in essence, those 12 students would be in a lottery and six would be assigned to middle school A and six would be assigned to middle school B.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So once we do all of those deductions from the 106 students, there are 60 students that enter the general lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those 60 students do not have a sibling preference or their parents opted out, and they do not have a special program requirement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what I've just explained to you in words, I'm gonna show it to you in this table.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 50% of students from each elementary school will be assigned to one of the two middle schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what I explained to you based on the 106 students, we divided that

[Edouard-Vincent]: to be 53 students attending school A and 53 students attending middle school B. And the breakout shows you the specific requirements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so for middle school A, 29 students were already accounted for.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So of the 29 students, the remaining 21 students

[Edouard-Vincent]: plus the three buffer seats would give us a total of 53 students per middle school A. And for middle school B, the breakdown is similar.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there would be 39 students drawn from the lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For those of you that are visual learners, I know that I said a lot of words, but this is what it looks like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Total 106 students and how those 106 students got divided based on their programmatic needs or requirements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the highlighted yellow bar shows you

[Edouard-Vincent]: how many students entered the general lottery after the required categories were addressed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 21 students would be assigned to middle school A, 39 students were assigned to middle school B. And this is the process that will take place

[Edouard-Vincent]: When we actually do the lottery, and it will take place for every school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, this is a an imaginary school, but I want you to see what the processes that will take place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So on April 12, when we do the lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and it's a random lottery, a number generator, and there are a lot of other specifics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'll have Dr. Riccadeli talk about those specifics to you, but I wanna just continue to take you through the slide deck.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And hopefully, again, if you have questions, we're gonna take questions at the end, but I hope I'm being clear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mentioned earlier about our English learner students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do have a growing EL population across the entire district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have newcomers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we reserve 12 seats at the McGlynn Middle School because the McGlynn Middle School houses our EL program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want parents to understand that that's the building where all the English learner educators are assigned.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that particular program is housed at the McGlynn Middle School Complex.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the three buffer seats that are added, in the end, it's 12 seats that are coded as a buffer for the bodies that will be coming over the course of the entire school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This Friday, March 24th, there's going to be a special letter going out to you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that's the sibling opt-in, opt-out form.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm gonna have Dr. Riccardelli just talk about that for you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All right, so I'm going to go back to our screen share just to finish up the slide deck, and then we will take any questions that you may have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, Dr. Riccadeli just went through the entire timeline of events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, Dr. Riccadeli, Bernadette Riccadeli, and Kim Miles, that's K-M-Y-L-E-S at medford.k12.ma.us, our data manager, they both will

[Edouard-Vincent]: be overseeing all of the background work related to the lottery so if there are challenges, you can use this email Ms middle school lottery at Medford k 12.ma.us and.

[Edouard-Vincent]: they will be able to help you very quickly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as Dr. Riccadeli already shared, the principals of each school will also have the official lottery numbers assigned to your child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there'll be another way to keep track of that special number that you're gonna be assigned prior to the lottery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next slide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, we discussed it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also will be putting this in my updates moving, continuing to put it in the updates moving forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's actually very, very quick.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We play Jeopardy music and we try to have it be an enjoyable process, but it's something that is generated fairly quickly and

[Edouard-Vincent]: we probably are able to complete the lottery within, I would say like 20 minutes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if you don't see the lottery, you're not able to catch it live, it will be available and the numbers will be uploaded as soon as it's done onto our website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the Zoom link is there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then finally, the,

[Edouard-Vincent]: April 24th is the date where you will receive your official, Monday, April 24th, right after April vacation, you'll receive your official notification of which school you're assigned to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then the following week, both middle school communities are ready to warmly welcome you again, Tuesday at the McGlynn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and Thursday at the Andrews.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those are dates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, I end with the purpose of the lottery was an attempt to balance the scales, balance the two schools to the best of our ability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that it's not a perfect system and you can never get it to be exactly

[Edouard-Vincent]: 50 50 because we're dealing with some numbers that are fluctuating.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But this is what the lottery has been doing for the Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Wonderful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to stop the share.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we really respect student confidentiality.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, again, with the spirit of transparency, we want you to know that there is a separate draw to balance those numbers between the two schools for some of the assignments, but everything just gets added.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When the lists are put together, you're not going to see any names.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the number that you are assigned for your family, that's your personal number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you do not have to say my number is, you know, X, Y, Z, that's a letter, but my number is one, two, three.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's your personal number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's why we wanted you to know when they go home, they're gonna go home by backpack on Thursday, April 6th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Provided they get two schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Delphine, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the Medford public schools, we would not be able to say what the assignment is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the open houses, we hold them on two different days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Tuesday, May 2nd, and or Thursday, May 4th, each school will be offering the open house, but the original lottery takes place for all students that are currently in the system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because they're currently attending another school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So because they're attending a different school, you've begun the registration process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But registration is officially complete when the students

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of the prerequisites, what needs to be there, all of that documentation would be there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You're welcome.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And some, the answer is yes, and some families actually,

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, opt to say, I would like to go through the lottery experience and, you know, take my chance 50-50 to see what school my child will be assigned to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that also has happened.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are different there are there are different specialized programs the Andrews.

[Edouard-Vincent]: has one specialized program and the McGlynn has a different program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, depending on the needs of the students and those students, if their IEP requires them to be placed in one of the specialized programs, then we are obligated to place them in that appropriate placement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the schools do have,

[Edouard-Vincent]: They both service students with special needs, with disabilities, and they both, the McGlynn is the only school that does service our students that are English learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is the, I think the one key difference that the English learner program

[Edouard-Vincent]: is not at both of the middle schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are special licensed teachers and they work together as a team in helping our students move through the English language development levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is how they do work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I hope that answers that question.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if additional guidance is needed in the area of special education, we can definitely have you speak with the ETLs in your respective buildings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Joan Bowen is our director of student services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we want to make sure that we do respect student confidentiality.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when the lottery was created, we wanted it to be as equitable as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But at the same time, we are required to make sure that we are providing the required services for students in the right programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the schools do

[Edouard-Vincent]: house different programs, slightly different programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so if there are specific IEP type questions, we definitely can make sure we have special educators involved in that part of the conversation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I didn't know you were going to have such wonderful questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is a wonderful, inquisitive bunch.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can only imagine what your rising sixth graders are going to be like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I want to just say thank you for jumping on the call this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And thank you for all of the questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I see, Sarah, you've raised your hand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the first piece that I would definitely wanna just share is that if we're anticipating about 300 or so rising fifth graders, it could be a little over 300, that number is split in half.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when you think about class size, you're not going to be able to have

[Edouard-Vincent]: a class, one class of 150 students, you know, taking grade six math.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not the, you know, the college level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So once you get to that number of 150, it has to be broken down into smaller classrooms, homerooms, if I can use the term homeroom, since you just left, like groups of 25 as they move,

[Edouard-Vincent]: to math and history and ELA and world language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when you're hearing A and B or the different groupings, it's just taking the large number of 150 and putting them into respective classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the classes have to rotate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Which is one of the big differences between elementary and leaving elementary school level and entering secondary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So from six through 12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students will be rotating and the teachers that they will have will be content.

[Edouard-Vincent]: area content experts in a specific domain, whether it's science or ELA, humanities, math, etc.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the students will be divided into homerooms because, you know, it's just impossible to have the entire cohort travel as one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's not a

[Edouard-Vincent]: a subdivision in terms of something bad.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's really just breaking them up into manageable numbers so that they can rotate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: through the different content, the different classes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In terms of opportunities for the middle school students to actually engage and see one another, those would be primarily afterschool opportunities because we have, both schools have a significant amount of club offerings and we're a part of the GBL, the Greater Boston League of,

[Edouard-Vincent]: So sports are also available at the middle school level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at the respective open houses, they will talk to you about all of the programs and afterschool offerings that are available for the students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So both schools offer afterschool programming and there is a late bus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so you have from arts, you have sports, you have,

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, chess, I believe there's a chess club, there may be like acting or drama.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a lot of, there's a diverse array of offerings for students to participate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so if you were assigned to the McGlynn School, but your friends or someone in your class was assigned to the Andrews,

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the after school program that was a greater interest to you was offered at the Andrews, then during those days you would be able to go to the Andrews so they, you're allowed to cross register for just the purposes of saying there are those opportunities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: where the students can see each other in many of the extracurricular events and activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, because of how transportation goes, if students were taking the school bus transportation, then they would be on the same buses in the morning and in the afternoon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: because the buses drop off at both schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they're on the same transportation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they could see each other at the start of the day, see each other in extracurricular afterschool programming activities, and then be together when they're leaving or be together playing sports.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are definite opportunities for the students to be together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for jumping on the call this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I will preface that I do have some lengthy remarks this morning, this afternoon, or this evening I should say, but a lot of good news to share a lot of wonderful things happening this month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I'm going to get started.

[Edouard-Vincent]: March is National Disability Awareness Month, and tomorrow is World Down Syndrome Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: National Disability Awareness Month began in 1987, when President Ronald Reagan proclaimed it to raise awareness about the importance of inclusion of people with developmental disabilities in all facets of community life.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It also brings to our attention the barriers that people with disabilities can sometimes face when connecting to the communities in which they live.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In Medford, we are proud that we are an inclusive community for all, but we are constantly learning about how we can do better.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, as tomorrow being World Down Syndrome Day, it's a global awareness day officially observed by the United Nations since 2012.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year's theme is With Us, Not For Us, which means people with disabilities have the right to be treated fairly and have the same opportunities as everyone else, working with others to improve their lives.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you are aware, those with Down syndrome have an extra chromosome.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So often people will wear crazy socks on March 21st.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm told that chromosomes are shaped like socks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So get your craziest socks ready to wear for tomorrow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On behalf of the Medford Public Schools, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate one of our state representatives, Christine Barber, for receiving the Legislator of the Year award from the Massachusetts Developmental Disabilities Council and the Arc of Massachusetts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For her work with people with intellectual and developmental disabilities,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Representative Barber serves as a member of the Massachusetts Autism Commission and works directly with advocates to address challenges facing the disability community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So congratulations State Rep Christine Barber.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today, the Medford Vocational Technical High School students in the Early Childhood Education Program begin a story, song, and art activity event with the Medford Family Network.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This program started today and will continue on March 22nd, March 27th,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and March 29th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The early education students will lead the children in sing-alongs, art, and STEAM activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They will also read them stories.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Truly, this is a win-win partnership for both our students and our young student group community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This coming Wednesday, March 22nd is Crossing Guard Appreciation Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We can't thank our crossing guards enough for keeping our students safe and helping them get to and from school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Remember to thank them, especially on Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also on March 22nd, we'll be hosting a Zoom informational meeting for parents of incoming middle school students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These are our fifth graders rising up to sixth grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will discuss the lottery and middle school curriculum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please join us from 5 to 6 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The lottery will be live on Zoom on Wednesday, April 12th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also on March 22nd, our CTE programs, our career technical education programs, will be hosting a showcase at Medford Vocational Technical High School from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All 8th graders and their families are welcome to attend this Wednesday, March 22nd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: March is also National Women's History Month, and both Medford High School and the Vocational School have planned informational events for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Vocational School kicked off Women's History Month on March 2nd, when they presented six guest speakers from the construction and technology industries.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This panel focused on women and individuals who are non-traditional employees in their field.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students in grades nine through 12 from the construction cluster, electrical, carpentry, construction craft labors, and metal fabrication, and the technology cluster, which includes engineering, robotics, and programming, and web development participated in this event.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Panelists shared stories about how their personal career paths led them to their current position.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As one of the panelists stated, you have to get comfortable being the only you in the room.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So get comfortable with being uncomfortable in educating others that you belong there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We thank the following panelists for taking the time to address our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Whitney Crooks, who is the manager system test development at iRobot Design Assurance Engineering.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mackenzie Grammer, an electrician for IBEW Local 103.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Stavrula Orfanas, a building inspector for the city of Salem.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kasai Sensel, technical program manager, RDST, Amazon Robotics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nikki Slaughter, senior operational excellence manager at Vecna Robotics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Shalini Vates, project manager, FBN Construction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank all of those panelists who came out to support us during that National Women's History Month event, and we will continue to have more events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Continuing with that theme, on March 31st, the Medford High School will present its second annual women's panel.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those participating will include Chief Justice Kimberly Budd of the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court, Commander Billy Fowler of the USS Constitution,

[Edouard-Vincent]: WBZ News Reporter, Tiffany Chin.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Jamie Chia of the Broad Institute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lisa Flores, Director of Sales and Marketing, Columbus Hospitality Group.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Asima Mohanty, Engineering Professor, Tufts University.

[Edouard-Vincent]: our own Congresswoman, Catherine Clark, small business owners, Paige Boldini and Kelly Rose Sano, and our own Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn and myself, Superintendent, we look forward to another exciting event for our students on March 31st.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would also like to take this time to recognize some of our outstanding athletes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Athletes that qualify for this competition often go on to be college stars and some represent their country at the Olympics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, last week, I want to recognize our Director of Counseling and Behavioral Health, Stacey Shulman.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She served as a panelist for our District Attorney, Marion Ryan's presentation, Dealing with Gun Violence in Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Over 130 people from law enforcement, education, and nonprofit fields attended from Middlesex County.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Stacey spoke of the Medford Public Schools commitment to the Sandy Hook promise, which began with our partnership in 2019.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As Stacey mentioned at our last meeting, prevention strategies such as start with hello and say something have been shown to significantly improve perceptions of school safety, foster socialization, reduce bullying, and begin to change culture from within.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Stacey has been fully committed to providing the very best for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Her presentation provided great information for all in attendance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the sport of archery in June.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mornings at seven.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The hillsides do cold.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The locks on the wing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The snails on the thorn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: God's in his heaven.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All's right with the world.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you hear your name being said, first congratulations to all of you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please come on up and we will shake your hand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Clay Canavan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Come and share.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, so the following report is in response to some specific questions that were asked about some of the changes that have taken place at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so there were a lot of questions regarding how long are students waiting to use the restrooms, you know, regarding the,

[Edouard-Vincent]: the new structures that are in place at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so at lunchtime, we have the cafeteria bathrooms open on all floors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And sometimes during that time, due to the volume of students that are eating, a line of three to four students can be there waiting anywhere from two to three minutes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But usually the lines are moving fairly quickly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As for other periods throughout the day when we don't have a large number of students eating at the same time, I'm not really noticing lines and neither are the administrative teams aware of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the end of the day, sometimes during period six, there are some students that do request to use the bathrooms at that point in time, but we've been working with them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next question that was asked was, how do we know that it's working?

[Edouard-Vincent]: The two-person maximum for the time being right now, we really feel that it's truly ingrained.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students know what the expectation is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so they go in, it's two students at a time outside of all of the larger bathrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We now have hooks that the students come, they hang their placards and they go into the restroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So at any given time, you can see there are two placards outside.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when they come out, they take it and they do that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've added the hooks because it helps to keep track.

[Edouard-Vincent]: but also we just felt that it was more sanitary to keep the placards outside of the restroom as opposed to inside the restrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the next question was, is there evidence that fewer students are outside of the classroom?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the administrators pulled the data

[Edouard-Vincent]: going back to the beginning of the year, and you can see the noted reduction in cuts that were taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so not only do, when you're physically walking the halls, it's completely different experience, but there is hard data to support

[Edouard-Vincent]: what we're seeing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we're very, very encouraged by that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Moving along, there was a question regarding about the availability in our last meeting and how do we solve this problem in a permanent and sustainable way?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we currently have seven building monitors at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so between the cameras being monitored and supervision and support throughout the high school and a designated monitor, at least at the front door, as students and guests or guests come into the building, we do feel that we have a good amount of coverage at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in addition to the teachers that signed up to take on some of these additional duties.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've encountered a few glitches when we've had coverage where maybe someone was absent and that could be one of the building monitors or if someone was feeling ill, not well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in those cases, we've had to shuffle around

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if we're short coverage, then the additional administrators will step up and support with additional coverage.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But again, we do feel at this point in time with the seven monitors that are currently working at the high school, that we feel that it is a manageable number and sustainable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So question two, again, was about do we see fewer students roaming the hallways?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, if you refer to the same table that was in question one, yes, it is definitely very obvious and there is a difference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And a culture shift is taking place at the high school and we are paying close attention to that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the next question was about the sustainability and the distribution of the school IDs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that which I shared in my last update is an area where we are looking at other options and one of the

[Edouard-Vincent]: possible suggestions was is there an opportunity to provide electronic IDs or some kind of ID, given that smartphones are everywhere, which we thought was a, you know, excellent suggestion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we are, you know, willing to look at other options and that could be because again,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Almost every student has a telephone, so it would just be a question of them potentially being able to show their identification through an electronic ID of some sort.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are trying to explore and look into that as an option.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Question three was, has there been an increase in the report of bullying?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so for the 21-22 school year, there were seven reports of bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as of March 15 of 2022, there were two confirmed bullying situations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have had 10 reports of bullying, bullying, two of them have been confirmed at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, some of you may wonder why is there a discrepancy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With the reports that go forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There could be a variety of solutions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There have been restorative circles they have been meetings with students and families where bullying report was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: submitted but you know the parties came down, came together sat down, had conversations and families chose not to go further with the bullying investigation that happens sometimes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also have some students that a bullying report may have been started for a student and over the course of the investigation and looking into additional supports for those students, that some students may currently be placed in other settings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they received other settings that would provide additional support to them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so in those cases, sometimes the bullying report, because the student was receiving additional supports elsewhere, that that's why that number does not show.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, sometimes when the bullying investigation takes place and it runs its full course, that in the end, it may not be identified or found it to be bullying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's also another factor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But at this point in time for the high school for this year, there are two official confirmed bullying reports that are on record at this point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next question was, has there been an audit of appropriateness of prior decisions to ensure that prior decisions were made in compliance with our definitions and policies?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the administrative team debriefs regularly, including conversations with our medical staff, our school Councilors, engagement specialists, and other building administrative members to ensure

[Edouard-Vincent]: that appropriate disciplinary measures are being meted out based on the needs of the specific child or student.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I can say that not every situation is a one size fits all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are special situations

[Edouard-Vincent]: that are taken into consideration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we do collaborate consistently with other members of our team, again, including our medical staff, our Councilors, our adjustment specialists, our engagement specialists, our adjustment Councilors, school psychologists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We bring in many different stakeholders as we look at situations that arise.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Has the district been responding in a timely way?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the district is responding in a timely way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The responding administrator follows up with the reporter within 24 to 48 hours or sooner, depending on what the situation is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is frequent communication between teachers and administrators, and there is a response within 24 to 48 hours.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, decisions are made as soon as practicable based on the details and complexity of what is being reported.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Question four, when will the handbook be presented to the school committee for review and approval?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the high school site council reviews and makes final recommendations at the beginning of May.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This handbook can be presented to the school committee anytime once the site council review is completed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We anticipate bringing an updated version before the committee with revisions by late May to early June of this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, the date can be changed at the discretion of the committee, but since it is something that the site councils do look at, there are periodic

[Edouard-Vincent]: Revisions that may have been done but in light of the greater substantive changes that took place this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to be able to just work with the site council and then bring it to the committee by late May early June.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the percentage of acknowledgement forms, they have been signed by students and families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The hard copies are kept in the assistant principal offices on file.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So each house has approximately, you know, 400 students, give or take.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are just working on getting those tallies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I can work on getting that to the committee, what the final percentage was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: How will we know that this worked and what will be or look different if this action was effective?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel the hard referral data to the assistant principals has gone down at a significant rate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This has allowed them to effectively manage and address student behaviors in a timely fashion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students are reporting during monthly listening sessions that they feel safer now at the high school with the changes that have been made since January.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Staff are also reporting that they visibly see less roaming in the hallways.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and students spending more time in their classes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students are following the protocols, using the placards when they need to use the restroom or if they need to go visit one of the other offices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is really being fully used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the eHaul pass system is also giving us additional accurate data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When a student leaves the classroom and returns.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, the other piece is the change in tardy check in process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's allowed us to consistently see which students are coming to school late in real time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I think all of these changes have significantly contributed to more calm and greater consistency and clarity around expectations at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to make sure that I responded to all the questions that I had received.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were only three stalls, but not only that, I think now that there are the new rules in place and the students are hanging their placards, they're going in, they're doing their business and they're coming right back out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think before they were going in and

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, that level of socializing, if you don't have a group of people to socialize with, there are only two people, you're gonna just go in, do your business and come out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So even the times that I've done bathroom duty, it's pretty quick.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They go in, they know they might see two or three people waiting, they go in, they come out, they go in, they come out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And where you have the bathroom stacked,

[Edouard-Vincent]: If one area were to have a slightly longer line, they know they can just go up one floor, which some students have done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Or up a floor or down a floor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mean, I've seen it happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the answer is yes, the survey is in the Panorama portal and the translations, Dr. Cushing, are the translations in the portal as well?

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was the last piece we were waiting on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I know I can't believe that March and spring is just around the corner, although snow is continuing to try to poke its head, but that's all right.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I do just bring to the community's attention that there were some special celebrations that are taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this evening,

[Edouard-Vincent]: the Jewish holiday of Purim is taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Purim means the Feast of Lots.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is a joyous festival commemorating the survival of the Jewish people in the fifth century BC.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to wish all of our Jewish students and families a wonderful Purim.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also this Wednesday, March 8th, begins the Hindu Festival of Holi.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Holi marks the beginning of spring and has been celebrated in India for centuries, dating back to the fourth century.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is one of the most popular Hindu festivals, also known as the festival of colors, the festival of spring, and the festival of love.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To our Hindu students and families, I hope you have an enjoyable Holi.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have some wonderful announcements to share with the community this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This past weekend, 12 of our Mustangs represented Medford at the Region IV Science and Engineering Fair held at Tufts University.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 22 schools were represented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The team of Dan Khoi Nguyen, Vina Lee, Owen Lau named their project, I Lost My Marbles.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Does more randomness increase the accuracy of statistics-based measurements?

[Edouard-Vincent]: These students won the Tufts University Science Fair Prize as the best Medford project, and it ranked 13th overall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They won $250 and qualified for the State Science Fair.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The following students, Morgan Reynolds, Oprah McHara,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Rakshita Shankarganesh submitted the project, How Does the Weather Affect Cosmic Ray Moons?
