[Edouard-Vincent]: Adaptive Cast will perform at 1 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They sound wonderful, we hear them practicing after school, so I think it's gonna be an excellent treat.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I hope you're able to come out and support that production this weekend.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On March 12th, the Medford Family Network is hosting a clothing and book swap from 1 to 4 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at Temple Shalom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please register with the Medford Family Network in order to attend.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On March 15th, Medford High School will be hosting two important information events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford-Malden Transition Fair will be held in the gym from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The fair is designed to provide students, families, caregivers, and professionals with information about community-based services for adults with disabilities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There will be over 25 exhibitors representing vocational job training and support, adaptive education programs, recreational opportunities, and supported housing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The event is free and open to all members of Medford, Malden, and surrounding communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students between the ages of 14 and 22 who receive special education services through their IEP are encouraged to attend.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The exhibitors will be reaching out to adults with autism, developmental disabilities, intellectual disabilities, and emotional disabilities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you have any questions, please email Charlotte Heim, our OT transition specialist at Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's cheim, H-E-I-M, at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, on March 15th, the postponed 8th grade course selection night will begin in the Cannon Theater from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's a very important evening for parents to come out to find out about the course selection for your rising 9th grade student as they prepare to enter the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in closing, March is Irish American Heritage Month in the United States.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Beginning in the middle 1800s, Irish immigrants began settling here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Like so many immigrants before and after them, they sought a better life in America.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While Irish Americans celebrate St.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Patrick's Day on March 17, we all celebrate along with them, for they helped to build the country as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to share with you an old Irish blessing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It says, may love and laughter light your days and warm your heart and home.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May good and faithful friends be yours wherever you may roam.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May peace and plenty bless your world with joy that long endures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May all life's passing seasons bring the best to you and yours.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so to start to kick off our budget process for this year and talk about our timeline, I just wanted to take a moment to go through the slide deck with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can advance Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for last year in June of 22, our operating budget was $68,994,776.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as you can see, our wonderful students, our wonderful programming here in Medford, our arts, our teachers, our students actively learning, engaged, involved in, looks like an art class, and

[Edouard-Vincent]: The money that we use, the money that we use to run the district is to provide our students first and foremost with the best quality education possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next slide takes that 68.9 million and it kind of just gives you a general breakdown of how that money is divided up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: is allocated toward general education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 9.1% is allocated towards security and maintenance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 25% is allocated towards special education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Student services equal 5.25% and administration is 6% of that pie.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just wanna share a few numbers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then, cause I may end up answering a question on a future slide, it's possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then we'll go back.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I have a hard copy with me as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So right in front of you right now what the slide is showing is our ESSER estimated budget for this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it talks about some of the key investments that we made under personnel, engagement specialists.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had 1.05 engagement specialists, one school nurse, floating nurse.

[Edouard-Vincent]: three behavioral specialists, reading specialists, ELL newcomer instructor, contractual stipends, professional learning, literacy, Hill for Literacy, responsive classroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Camp Mustang, we have that as a TBD.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our MBTA pass program currently right now is about $15,000 a month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for the 10 months, that's 150,000 coming out of ESSER funding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Emergency connectivity fund, there was an additional 90,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then under miscellaneous cell counseling programs, our rebus professional development training for our administrators, talking points and other subscriptions, that was approximately $50,000 that we spent on ESSER funding for this year, estimated budget.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So moving forward to fiscal year 24 for next school year, you see before you four key priorities which are aligned to our strategic plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Implementing curricula, which you heard earlier about our literacy presentation, there are important shifts in curricular investments that need to be made.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Looking at assessment, instructional strategies to support all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our second priority is going to be focusing on building culture through community engagement and fostering collaboration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our third

[Edouard-Vincent]: priority equity, but looking at equitably supporting the academic, the social emotional learning needs and physical needs of all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And our fourth priority would be looking at school infrastructure, student supports and safety of creating a safe learning environment for all of our learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those are kind of the buckets that we're going to be focusing on as key priorities which are all aligned to our strategic plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to go a little deeper on, again, this slide, which is showing next year FY24 budgetary priorities, we will be sending out a budget survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there's an asterisk next to the word needs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at the bottom, it says it reflects the preliminary information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we do not yet have the survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The surveys have not gone out as of yet.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But as we receive the survey data, as that data comes in, it will also help to shift our budgetary priorities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But this is just a draft.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're still looking heavily at strategic staffing investments focused on our most vulnerable learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: professional development and training, which is critically important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're investing in talking about spending hundreds of thousands of dollars.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the literacy program alone, it's estimated to cost about 600,000, which will appear in a later slide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But to spend that kind of money, more than a half million dollars, and not include

[Edouard-Vincent]: professional development for our educators, it doesn't make sense to bring in such an expensive program and not provide the training.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So professional development and training is critically important for our academic success here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we want to continue with district-wide professional development on restorative practices, responsive classroom,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and further curriculum training for the elementary math and literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we continue to look at other programs, such as the HECAT program, any other programs that we may be thinking about bringing on board.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In terms of summer programming, it's something that we do feel is very important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that there is significant cost with that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are looking at pursuing grant opportunities to continue several summer programming options for our community here in Medford, from literacy to math,

[Edouard-Vincent]: to finance to sell programming during the summer, and then a few miscellaneous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: supplements that we will need as part of the newly negotiated contract.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be working on the high school scheduling, which is finally fully merging the vocational school schedule and the comprehensive school schedule, having the two schedules talk

[Edouard-Vincent]: and be aligned because we still have the five day, six day schedule.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's a lot of force fitting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we agreed to have a consultant come in to support us with the high school scheduling and at the elementary level where we have also shifted where our elementary schools will be having the additional early release half days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for that, we had to do some shifting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The meetings are still taking place, but for elementary scheduling, we will need to have a slight increase in staffing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So where elementary scheduling is concerned in order to make the new schedule work for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's something that we're aware of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we just wanted to put that down.

[Edouard-Vincent]: old pipes and, you know, freezing and just different things that have happened.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is across the entire Commonwealth of Massachusetts that all districts

[Edouard-Vincent]: have been notified to expect an increase of 14% for special education out of district tuitions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that is a significant increase in one year to be able to

[Edouard-Vincent]: make the necessary adjustments but I just again wanted to put this out before the committee for you to be aware that this is a new piece of information that all districts are dealing with and I do believe that there's been a lot of legislation and working with members of the delegation to try to see if something can be done

[Edouard-Vincent]: with that number of 14%, but as of right now, the communication that did go out to all districts is that that number is expect a 14% increase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there are also just ordinary anticipated financial challenges that may come along.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In Medford we were hoping to be able to add a theater teacher, a 1.0 that is one period that

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is truly a problem, but there's also like a limitation because when you think about bullying, it's about someone wanting to show power.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They want to be the powerful one and take advantage of someone else in that particular point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so technology and media or videoing is now

[Edouard-Vincent]: being manipulated in such a way that whoever the videographers are or the person who's actually doing the bullying, they feel empowered by that and I just feel like it's

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we create this and kind of say what our expectations are, I think there's so much about education that needs to happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: special education, I want to be able to say it the right way, but Medford's going to be doing a bullying workshop and it's about what parents and professionals need to know is the title of the workshop and it's being done in collaboration with the Federation for Children with Special Needs and I just feel like

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to continue to educate demonstrate and show our students that are in front of us what is appropriate and what is inappropriate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just wanted to add that piece to the conversation because there were some things you know we can have the best intentions, but if someone truly has malicious intent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, we need to be able to say that this is wrong, and also get that person the necessary help that is needed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just kind of feel like bullying has existed for a long time but the way in which it presents itself now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: with these videos getting liked and I don't know how people do it, but they resurface it, they share it with different people, they do the airdrops, you know, the images, students taking images of themselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: with limited clothing or no clothing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it's, it is a form of bullying and sometimes it ends up classified as child pornography.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I'm just saying that these are the things that the administrators, especially at the secondary level 612 world have to deal with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on a consistent or not a consistent day, but at least they've encountered it enough times.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just feel that the education, educating parents, helping parents to become partners with the district, for them to understand, like, when we're reaching out to you to say that this is what's taking place, we truly do need them to partner and collaborate with us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: get the appropriate supports their child needs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And sometimes the cell umbrella I just, I can't stress it enough because it's something that we're all dealing with and we shouldn't pretend that it's not happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So 7.30 tomorrow morning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as of right now, Metro Public Schools is open, but we are continuing to just monitor the news and try to get accurate

[Edouard-Vincent]: information in terms of how much snow we're really thinking may come to us tomorrow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, I would just like to share that the Friday before February break, Friday, February 17th, was our Black History Month celebration at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was a great celebration that took place in the gymnasium.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The entire high school community packed the gymnasium, and it was a wonderful celebration, our mayor spoke I got to give remarks and there was an inspirational guest speaker in the person of Mr. Brian Owens who really spoke

[Edouard-Vincent]: about his great accomplishments and overcoming odds and being successful in what he, you know, from being an athlete and now being a successful businessman, and really just gave an inspirational speech to our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also had many of our students in the Black Student Union, BSU, that one student shared poetry, others performed dance, fashion show, really just showing their culture.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I really wanted to thank Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Walker, Shavos Walker, who is one of the high school assistant principals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Jackson, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Later that week, they beat Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, which made them eligible for the Nationals Ethics Bowl, which will be taking place at UNC, University of North Carolina.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This 10 point action plan was implemented as a result of what transpired at the high school in December, and I'm here to give you an update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Dr. Cushing, I'm not sure I shared one of the documents with you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm hoping you can screen share that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On a weekly basis, I've had it linked to my Friday communications, the 10 point action plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'm here today to just inform the committee of all the things that have been happening, what's working, and where are the areas that we do need to see additional growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first area on the 10-point action plan is our school resource officer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I am pleased to report that we now have two full time school visas officers working at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have Officer Conway and Officer Patia both working at the high school and Chief Buckley.

[Edouard-Vincent]: has two other additional SRO officers that have also been trained to be school resource officers, and they will eventually be cycled through between the middle school and the high school so that they are exposed to more students, and students are also exposed to them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Officer Poitier is a female school resource officer, and Officer Conway is a male.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and Chief Buckley shared that one of the other school resource officers that was trained is an officer of color.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so really trying to be intentional and inclusive of the school resource officers that will be supporting all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so for that immediate action and support, very, very grateful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to the partnership with Chief Buckley.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was point number one, and Officer Poitier came on in January.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was the first bullet.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For bullet number two, what we ended up doing at the high school, having clear and consistent protocols for bathroom occupancy,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now we have blue and red language or tags.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I had shown them back in January, but when students are going to use the restroom in their inner classroom, they will be given a blue tag.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also have the eHall pass system, which is the online system as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it is, that system is working, it's being used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The red house is for students that will be going to a different part of the building, it could be the nurses office, it could be to go see guidance or maybe going down to the library for something but students when they're traveling in the hallway.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are carrying either a red or a blue pass, so it's easily identifiable and you can speak with them and they will show you, I have this pass, this is where I'm going and I'm returning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that has, that was implemented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I met January and then as of February 3rd, everyone is aware of the new process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's, I feel it's now, it's just, it's part of the routine.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's part of what happens at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So bullet number three,

[Edouard-Vincent]: clear and consistent protocols for students, for student identification, check-in and hallway presence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So one of the shifts that did take place in January, in the past, students used to report to the three different floors, the house offices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so now when students are checking in, they report at the main office.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, can you, I'm using your screen share, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was on number three, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for student identification, check-in, and holiday presence, again, the tags that are being used, check-in is taking place in the main office, and student identification is handed out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm going to give you the key highlights of what has transpired, and then I will also talk about the areas that we've identified where we need to continue to do some additional work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bullet number four point number four was the bullying prevention reporting and investigation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, in January.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have assemblies for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students know that they are expected to report something to an adult or to the assistant principal or to a guidance Councilor or an adjustment Councilor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's paperwork that can be used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they have been fully informed about that and can use those documents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Number five, the anonymous reporting system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By the end of January, we had all students in grade six through 12 that have been trained in the anonymous reporting system and staff are also aware of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And next week at the March 6 meeting, Stacey Shulman will be presenting specific data on what has happened with that, but it is up and running.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's been used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so...

[Edouard-Vincent]: she will be able to give some specifics to what we've seen thus far, but this is now again an opportunity for students to report anonymously and not have to worry about, you know, someone saying that, you know, they're snitching or they're telling on them and for fear

[Edouard-Vincent]: of any kind of problems that could arise.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the anonymous reporting system, I'm very excited about that, and that's through our partnership with Sandy Hook Promise.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On point number six, the student handbook.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, the real student and faculty staff meetings,

[Edouard-Vincent]: student sessions, listening sessions, advisory meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students are aware of what the handbook says, what is acceptable, what is not acceptable, and we're continuing to work through that with them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Point number seven, reminding families that counseling support is available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that social, emotional well-being and health is critically important and that students respond, whether it's impulse control or whatever challenges they may be facing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We can definitely refer to families and students

[Edouard-Vincent]: to all of the counseling supports that are available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if you go to the website, there is a listing of additional outside counseling if families were to choose not to have their student

[Edouard-Vincent]: participate in counseling, whether it's with a school psychologist, an adjustment Councilor, a guidance Councilor, if they choose to have outside counseling, but that is available to all of our families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have been working collaboratively with Mr. Michael Welch, who is a retired superintendent and former high school principal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He has been working at the high school level and that has been going very well, providing consult, meeting with staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: meeting with the administrative team, providing guidance and support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that has been a very positive experience having Mr. Walsh as a consultant and giving us feedback on the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Number nine, administering a confidential school culture and climate survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Creshen,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Actually, let me, member McLaughlin, is that okay?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because I'm on, and Dr. Cushing, you can stay there because I just have to go to number 10 and then we can take all the questions at once.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So point number 10, we have posted for the communications director position that was posted on, I believe, the February 17 right before February break.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're in the process now of gathering

[Edouard-Vincent]: resumes and looking at candidates who would be interested in coming to join the STEM team and supporting the work that we're going to do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But that is where we are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to at least give those first 10 points and then I wanted to just make a

[Edouard-Vincent]: A few, a few points about what were key positives and then what were the key areas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, one of the great positives is now having to assign those at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, I was very happy to have and it's just wonderful having two additional support people in the school to help us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Check-in process has really expedited, you know, students realize that they have to report to the main office and so we're seeing a significant

[Edouard-Vincent]: decrease in the amount of late arrivals, and students are getting to classes much quicker.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The anonymous reporting system is in place, it has been used a few times, and again next week, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sherman will talk about that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the high school level, I believe there was one report, and at the middle school level, I'm not sure if it was one or two reports, but a few came in, I think, at that level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But just allowing us to have that opportunity to respond very quickly and address it anonymously.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the hall pass system has really, the blue and red tags, that has really, really worked very well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So some of the challenges that we found when we implemented the hall passes, we also implemented bathroom monitors and hall monitors, and we asked staff to support us

[Edouard-Vincent]: at the high school in addition to the building that we have so we have hired additional building managers we're still trying to hire at least one more.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes because we have staff that are helping with closures, if we have people who are absent, some staff have consistently asked to be part of the rotational schedule.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And some, because it is, although they're being compensated, they need to volunteer to say they want to take on that additional task.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So sometimes we do not have some coverage issues.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is something that we're watching.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's been an ask of students and we're trying to see at this point in time we have two students at a time using the bathrooms, no more than two.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the students have been asking and we are considering possibly increasing that number

[Edouard-Vincent]: to three students being allowed to go into the restrooms at one point in time, but it's something that we are just monitoring because we don't want to go and rip the band-aid and end up with some of the challenges that we faced before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is something that we're looking at because it's been working fairly well and the students are respecting the total number of people in the bathrooms at a time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The check-in process sometimes, although check-in is taking place in the main office, because it's now taking place in the main office as opposed to the house offices, sometimes there was a slight delay for the assistant principals that are in each of the houses to be able to quickly check in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there was a slight delay

[Edouard-Vincent]: because it's no longer happening in the respective offices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're trying to work on that piece, which is a glitch.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then this is the final piece that I wanted to say, which is a challenge, but it's something new that didn't happen at Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we did pass out the student IDs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I would probably have to say when I'm in the hallways,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would probably say, I don't even think it's 50% of active involvement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students who wear their IDs, I will say to them, great job.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If I see them wearing it, but a lot of the students will say, I don't have my ID, I left it at home, it's in my binder, it's in my locker, but they respond respectfully.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I know that it's a new,

[Edouard-Vincent]: was a new protocol that we put in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is the one area that I can clearly say, and I know we have our student reps here, that the students are not consistently wearing their ID all day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I can say that,

[Edouard-Vincent]: In behaviors, the students are respectful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I see students in the hallway, and they're saying, where are you going?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Are you on your way to a class?

[Edouard-Vincent]: They respond, when I speak with them, they do respond respectfully, and then they will make sure that they're moving in the right direction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanna be fully transparent, because I know that that was something where people were asking specifically, what's going to happen if someone doesn't wear an ID?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we wanted the students to wear the ID, but we also wanted to see a change in behaviors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so seeing the significant change in behaviors, that was most important to me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so although we're not having full participation with the IDs, at this point in time, the students are, I feel, comporting themselves in a respectful manner.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just feel such a significant difference from talking with students what they said to me themselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it is something that, you know, we're going to continue to work with, but if, if you're walking in the halls and member Graham member Graham member McLaughlin was with me right before break.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students were going to class, they were doing what they needed, they were being students, but not everyone had their ID on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to make that known to the committee that that is the one area where I feel if they're in school, they're doing their work, they're reporting to class,

[Edouard-Vincent]: that's something that we're aware of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it was such a significant shift to take place in the middle of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're trying to look at other options.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's gonna be a lot of things that we're doing with like food service and trying to think about other things where if you need your ID and you can have it, like your ID is used for other things, then everyone would need to have it on them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have not ruled that out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But at this point in time, that's the one area that we're not seeing consistent implementation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At last count, when I had the number of IDs, that students who never took school class pictures, it was 97 students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So over 1,100 students had ID pictures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we ordered backup.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we had IDs for like over 1100 students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the number was very small and I was told that the students that didn't have IDs that their pictures were being taken on the computer and they were going to have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It wouldn't be the same exact idea because even new students that are enrolling if they're moving, you know, you move from New Hampshire to Massachusetts, then you wouldn't have taken pictures, and the photography vendor, when they tried to see if we could get the vendor to come out again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the vendors were booked months in advance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was the reason why we could not do like, you know, another picture day and say, okay, these 97 students are, you know, it could be 105 by now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was the information that I had, but we did get duplicate IDs made for the students, but I can definitely follow up on that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, because I also spoke with Mr. Spagnola, who's from Graphic Design or Media Tech, either, or we have the two departments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And he also was interested in trying to design like a temporary ID.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford public schools will be closed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In light of this this storm is truly unpredictable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But due to the significant amount of surrounding communities that are also closed, we're really concerned about our staff coming in and taking care of their own families and children because many of our staff live in the surrounding communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so they would now not have childcare and it definitely could end up being a significant impact.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have not,

[Edouard-Vincent]: put it out yet, but we'll be putting it out on the media and sending out a communication that tomorrow the Medford public schools will be closed due to the timing of the storm with the morning commute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, the governor did ask for DCF involved families that DCF will be closed tomorrow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we already received notification that

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of our most vulnerable families would not be receiving transportation to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was going to be an excused absence, but just in light of, again, so many of our surrounding communities that have already closed, it would be, I could see it being a significant hardship for the district for us tomorrow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there will be no school for the schools tomorrow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But because of the break, we're just trying to get ahead of it right away.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, okay.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Based on our January 9th meeting, where there was a recommendation from the committee to create a form where incidents could be documented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I shared with you a draft document

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's in your packets.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to just share some key pieces of information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During the time that we created this forum, senior leadership met, we met also with principals, and I had the opportunity to meet with principals at all levels, and the assistant principals as well at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I had the opportunity to meet with them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And through the rich discourse, it was really discussed at that point in time,

[Edouard-Vincent]: that the recommendation for the incident form would really be used with grades nine through 12, that that's where it would be most appropriate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we created the draft form, but from the time of this original report being created back in January and now,

[Edouard-Vincent]: we have been able to access or increase access to our school brains portal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so on this incident form, where it had a limited number of areas,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now on School Brains at the high school level, if a referral is written for a student and the parents are notified by the teacher or the staff person of record, parents and students now have access to the referral portal that is a part of School Brains.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are multiple categories, you know, over 50 categories.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mean, the mayor is next to me, so she's able to see, but I'm gonna just, what is available online as the referrals are being generated, it's,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's extensive, whether it's challenges on the bus, attendance, inappropriate language, truancy, lack of cooperation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are cutting class, which is documented in this referral process, disruptive behavior, distribution of substances,

[Edouard-Vincent]: or illegal drugs, failure to identify self, failure to report to Saturday detention,

[Edouard-Vincent]: if there were to be the sale of tobacco, if there were any kind of smoking materials, it's very expansive what's actually available in the actual portal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the staff person of record who is creating the referral goes in

[Edouard-Vincent]: and clicks on the boxes, the respective boxes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then once they click on the boxes, they're able to add comments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when they reach out to the family, both the student and the parent are able to go in and say, there was a referral created.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it clearly shows once the staff person clicks on the indicator,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It has a blue checkmark, and it identifies exactly what took place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, we were able to get access to this portion which before we did not have access to that so this is a new.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's new and the students report cards, the students that were in the portal, they are now seeing their referrals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it's clearly spelled out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so both the student can see what was documented as a referral and the parent can see it as well, because the parent view is the same as the student view.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the talking points activity has increased significantly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the staff person of record is sending a communication to the parent stating that your child did not show up for mathematics today, or your child missed Johnny missed science period two.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we know that Johnny's in school and then he attends the rest of the day so they will see the talking points message, and the parents are now back on talking points.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But now that we were able to not only will they get the talking points notification but when they go to the portal, they can actually see exactly what the infractions were that are checked off, and the staff person who is reporting the student.

[Edouard-Vincent]: they get to see a referral was entered in what it was that took place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with School Brains, again, at the secondary level, at the high school level grades, there was definitely active participation from parents at the high school level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Midterms and other key communications happened through the School Brains portal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And now seeing

[Edouard-Vincent]: When I actually was able to see the actual list of, you know, it's probably about 90 different indicators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The fact that it's already housed in one place so you could see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of the reasons with adding separate documentation like this.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First, it's, it's not going to be able to capture like 90, almost 90 different indicators that I'm looking at.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But secondly,

[Edouard-Vincent]: In School Brains, not only does it let you know, okay, this happened on February 6th, but if there's more than one referral made, it keeps track of all of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you actually have in one spot from the start of the school year throughout, you can go and click and count and say, oh,

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were 15 referrals for, you know, inappropriate behavior or cutting class.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's all in one place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And you can see who the different staff people are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So having it within the portal, you're able to keep the data in one place and parents are now able to see

[Edouard-Vincent]: who's sending it, you know, they would have received a talking points or a phone call depending on what, you know, what transpired from a staff person, a guidance Councilor, an assistant principal, a principal, reaching out to them to say this, you know, this is what ended up taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they can also now go into the portal and see what the actual referral was about and what was, you know, the time of day, who was the instructor who sent it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is now,

[Edouard-Vincent]: a new ability that we did not have before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I actually, now that it's working, and the students are realizing, like, this is being documented, they can actually see what the referral is for, it's also great with accountability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you're working with the students and saying, well, this happened on this particular day, and now this is the third event or the fourth event, you're able to just

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, you're able to better monitor you're able to keep parents up to speed, and parents are able to see, oh, you know, there was a computer violation, or, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, you were smoking today, or you were attempting to do something that you shouldn't have done and parents are now able to see what the infraction was and support the school in meeting out discipline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's not for K through, was it middle school or was that elementary school?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do know at the when I met with the principals, especially at the elementary level, they were all together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the schools use a slightly different form, but they definitely focus on communicating with parents at the elementary level, because it really should be what's appropriate if it's, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: a younger child, letting the parent know immediately this is what happened.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is, you know how we're handling it and trying to handle it at an appropriate level in this situation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, there are suspensions that do take place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Not often at the elementary level, but sometimes there are some extreme behaviors that, you know, there needs to be a serious consequence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But that is like the exception and not the norm.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Usually, if it's something at that level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know the parents would receive a phone call the parents may come in for a meeting to speak with the administrator or speak with the teacher to say like this is what the appropriate the inappropriate behavior was and this is our expectation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next go around.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, you know, you said you received a form about you know.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Maybe, you know, excited behavior in phys ed, and then as a mom you were able just to support the district and say like I expect perfect behavior.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you, you know, travel to special specialists or wherever it is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that's the hope of definitely trying to have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: communication and collaboration, supporting one another in this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think at the high school level, where we're dealing with young adults, and in dealing with young adults who are going to be going out into the real world, that

[Edouard-Vincent]: what's happening right now, reaching out to the parents through talking points, completing the referral, and the administrators following up on, if it's a staff person, the administrator following up with the parent as well to say this is being addressed, but it's clearly being documented, that it's what is developmentally appropriate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the middle school level,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I do feel that communication with the parents is critically important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, if the behavior is truly a behavior that's unacceptable, then there will be consequences for that behavior.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But a lot of the behaviors that are being addressed, the administrators and or teachers or staff work in collaboration with the parents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, with the training I would actually I'm going to ask for assistance with tenant Susan glues and Dr Christian if they would wouldn't mind coming up to speak specifically to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: how things look differently at the elementary level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In terms of training, I would even ask maybe member Rousseau or member Mustone, do you recall having a special training with school brains?

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think some of it's intuitive.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know we have the translators available and Talking Points does translate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I'm not sure if there's a formalized training so I'm deferring to you guys to also chime in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not sure.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just know that they were able to get access on the referral portion to get it opened.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wasn't on that back end piece to say, how could you let families see referrals that were in the system?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that aspect got opened or unlocked.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not sure of the specifics of how it happened.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was in addition to what was already there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was an additional form that was created.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the other forms that are already at the high school, those ones would continue to be in use, and that was in addition to it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was just a draft based on what had been said and trying to bring the administrators together to see what else could be created.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But then, again, now that we gained the additional access, it was like,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This actually gives more information than what the form could ever give.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, I am fully in support of not using that additional time at all and continuing with the talking points.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now that the referral portal is open and parents can actually see, oh, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This happened, I received a message, I looked in, I saw it, and the student can actually see it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they could never see it before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I actually feel like this is eye-opening for them as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It just, I want to say, is it a week, Dr. Cushing or Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Galusi?

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think it's been about a week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's fairly recent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: have all these little tiny boxes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would say the training for families to learn how to use the talking points.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, school brains.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, I was thinking definitely by March in order to get the training created, whether it's gonna be a video, I'm not sure if it would be, could it be on Zoom and then have it on video or do it like a webinar and then send it out so that everyone knows this is what it looks like with the screenshots and so that they know where to click and again,

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you're using a telephone, it's gonna look differently than if you're on a computer, but to at least highlight those key areas for families to be able to look at.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm thinking like March, we should be able to have families, the training completed, get families trained, and in March as well, have a working group going.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So by the end of March, to be able to report out some information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think I had the wrong mic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not working.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I apologize.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What I was just sharing with the committee was that goals can be multi-year goals and that when I originally came on board, I had a multi-year goal

[Edouard-Vincent]: looking at elementary mathematics at that point in time, that was a decision, was a data informed decision based on where we were performing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if the committee were to select a goal that could expand over multiple years, we could just put in benchmarks to say at this point in time, this is what we would like to see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then, you know, year two, this is

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, what else we would like to see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are a lot of options of multi year goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even if the superintendent's evaluation timeline had to shift to be aligned with the school committees,

[Edouard-Vincent]: that that's an option as well, that it doesn't have to be September to June, it could be January to November 30th or January to December and say, this is what happened during the calendar year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is a lot of, I think, flexibility available, but I think the fact that you as a committee are going through this exercise to think about your own goals and how they align to the superintendent's goals,

[Edouard-Vincent]: even if they change and they evolve, and how they align to the district's goals, that that is a step in the right direction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I just was going to say the version that I emailed to the committee is November 2022.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that there was a 2019 and then Desi updated it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I'm not sure if that's the same page member member McLaughlin is on right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if I don't see you raising your hands, anybody, please just... I just was going to comment that I felt both of those indicators are aligned with the work that's taking place, the work that we're doing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do feel that that's there, and we'll probably be able to provide additional data, some assessment data for our early literacy assessments, but we're doing that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So indicators B and E, I'm in agreement with those two indicators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I feel, you know, I feel significantly relieved knowing that we're identifying the specific indicators, which are fairly closely aligned to the goals, so that I think this is going to make it more manageable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I think you said right now we're up to nine I feel like

[Edouard-Vincent]: that's probably a good amount and that I will continue to gather and compile evidence in those areas, you know, to the best of my ability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I think, you know, when you're looking at every single indicator, it's just too much, it's too much content to be able to cover everything and try to cover it well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, it's good just to have a clear plan and to know what the expectations are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I know we didn't get into the specifics of the indicators, but now that I know the areas to focus on, I'll focus on providing evidence for those key indicators and try to get feedback along the way between now and the end of the school year to see if I'm moving in the right direction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yep.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I just wanted to weigh in when member Graham you started sharing about potentially having a inclusive art experience, and right now we are working on, I talked about it last week in last week's memo the mosaic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this past Wednesday, students went with our coordinator of finance, Suzanne Fee, and they're gonna do a middle school day and they're going to do a high school day as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so some of those mosaics she shared with me for families that weren't able to come to the high school to work during that timeframe, they are going to provide some opportunities for additional pieces of the mosaics

[Edouard-Vincent]: to go to the respective schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So by the time this piece of art is completed, students from all of the schools will have had an opportunity to at least, maybe not every single student, but students will have had an opportunity to have participated in this beautiful mosaic that's going to be created.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so as you were talking about the different ways to include the community,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and not thinking about cost per se, exception of the arts materials, I was thinking that that could be another beautiful way to beautify the space and have it be inclusive of the students and members of the community and

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, art is beautiful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Maybe it could be something where the art is interchangeable, you know, twice a year or something like that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They could switch it up for the seasons.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I'm thinking that there could definitely be a lot of creative ways to have that community footprint and have it beautify the space through the arts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to share that as a possible suggestion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think you should probably have four levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You should just include a platinum level because you never know.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You may have a extra generous person who wants to give at that level and

[Edouard-Vincent]: If people are willing to do that to support the schools, to support the community, I think we should recognize them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know what the monetary amounts would be, if it would be like 10,000, 25,000, 50,000, and 100,000 plus or something.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know how you'd want to do that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If people are willing to be generous, they could be spending the money on

[Edouard-Vincent]: a trip around the world or something else.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If they're willing to give back to the community, I, I, I, I feel strongly that we should be able to, um, acknowledge them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And, um, you know, we may end up with so much that there's extra money to, to go towards another playground.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mean, wouldn't that be wonderful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And put that in that, you know, if we reach whatever the goal is, whatever the magic number is that, um,

[Edouard-Vincent]: people wanna get to, if we reach that number, then say, you know what, let's tackle the next playground that's in desperate need of an upgrade or something like that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sac passe!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sac passe!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sakpase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sakpase means it's good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What's happening?

[Edouard-Vincent]: How's it going?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Napule, even though if you take it literally,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It says like it's burning, but you don't really use it literally that way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's just, it's good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's good to hear everyone knowing that phrase.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm so excited to be here, always to come before you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I begin my remarks today, I want to say thank you again to the BSU.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to thank all, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Andrea Pierre-Paul, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Walker, Charose Walker.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Jackson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not sure of all of the other advisors that helped, but thank you for coordinating today's event and just giving us an opportunity to share with the larger community about the Haitian culture.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, as I said, I'm going to share very, very brief remarks, and then I have a special citation from the mayor from the city of Medford to share because she was not able to be with us today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today, I am going to do something a little bit different than what I've done in the past.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This past Saturday, I had the opportunity to be at the city of Medford Haitian Flag Day celebration as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I shared a few key proverbs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I want to share a few of them with you here as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because within the Haitian culture, proverbs are used a lot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for my staff and people that I work with, a lot of times when I share, I give visual images.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do feel it's because of my culture and how I was raised that usually there is either a proverb or a visual image to connect to something that you're trying to say.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as you can see, the wonderful red and blue today represents the flag.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And on the flag, the statement on the flag says, L'union fait la force, which means our unity, our strength is being in unity or being in accord.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is a guiding principle of Haitians.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as superintendent, there are many times when I have spoken in the past, I've said we are one Medford, one district, because we are stronger together than we are apart, and you can take that on all levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So together we stand strong, but divided we will fall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford and Haiti are similar in that we have diverse and historic populations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many of us in the room have different skin color tones.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We practice different religions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We speak different languages.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have different traditions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But together, we are a blend of cultures, much like our mascot here, the Mustang horse.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've said many times that mustangs come in a variety of colors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some have patches, some have spots, and some have stripes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are intelligent, peaceful horses who are hard workers and live in herds led by a female.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are all Mustangs, no matter our color, heritage, or creed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And our Mustangs happen to be led by a female, me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we come together today to celebrate, I want to share a quote with you from Maya Angelou.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She said, we all should know that diversity makes for a rich tapestry and we must understand that all the threads of the tapestry are equal in value no matter what their color.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I say that to you because I feel it's symbolic of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: No matter what color you are, what creed you are, we are stronger together and everyone has equal value.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want to just share a few proverbs with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One is this.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's three words.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you can repeat after me, I'd greatly appreciate it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first word is shita.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Pa.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bai.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Shita, pa, bai.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Excellent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A plus for all of you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A plus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What does that mean?

[Edouard-Vincent]: It means sitting doesn't yield.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What it means is if you're sitting down, you're not able to produce.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's an encouraging proverb that tells you get up, get out there, do what you need to do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Shita pabai.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another proverb I want to just share with you, which is a short proverb,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tutmunsemun.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's four words.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tut.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mun.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Se.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mun.

[Edouard-Vincent]: People are people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It means we love one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We care for one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are all people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Everyone has equal value.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tutmunsemun.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One more time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tutmunsemun.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Wonderful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want to say I am so proud and grateful for this opportunity to stand before all of you and share a little bit of my culture, which all of these wonderful students are sharing with you as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I thank you for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to share the proclamation from the city of Medford from Mayor Brianna Lungo-Kurd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Haitian American Heritage Month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Whereas Haitian American Heritage Month is a jubilant celebration in the United States, embracing Haitian heritage and culture,

[Edouard-Vincent]: And whereas first celebrated in Boston, Massachusetts in 1988, Haitian American Heritage Month is now observed nationwide in the month of May from Florida to Massachusetts with parades, festivals, and school activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And, whereas, Haitian American Heritage Month salutes Haitian and Haitian American communities who exhibit appreciation for their culture and heritage that has immeasurably enriched the lives of the people of Medford, our state and our nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And, whereas,

[Edouard-Vincent]: As educators, authors, community leaders, activists, athletes, artists, musicians, and politicians, Haitian Americans have made their mark in every facet of society and have contributed to the betterment and diversity of our city, state, and nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And whereas May 18th is Haitian Flag Day,

[Edouard-Vincent]: in Haiti, which celebrates the culture and heritage of the Haitian flag, which honors their forefathers and replenishes their resolve for Haiti's future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And whereas the city of Medford and the United States of America have thrived as a melding of immigrants, united by common values and the promise of a better tomorrow,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and whereas there is a strong connection between Haitians and Medford's community and I encourage all of our residents to honor this observance now therefore I

[Edouard-Vincent]: Breonna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor of the City of Medford, do hereby proclaim the month of May as Haitian American Heritage Month, signed with the seal of Medford by our Mayor, Mayor Breonna Lungo-Koehn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can't resist sometimes, so I just want to give a shout out right now to my seniors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So seniors!

[Edouard-Vincent]: June 7th will be here sooner than you can think.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I'm so happy to be here to celebrate with all of you, Black History Month celebration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to give a great shout out to our PSU advisors, to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Faye and Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Jackson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please wave so everyone can see you and Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Jackson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in preparation for today's remarks,

[Edouard-Vincent]: the leadership and guidance that we've been giving to the students all along.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I know that as we kind of talked about the theme of this year being about change agents, I wanted to take a few minutes to actually just share with you who some of the great change agents are from Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We heard from our mayor,

[Edouard-Vincent]: She gave us the names of some change agents, but I think that this is really important because these were normal people who ended up doing extraordinary things and they became change agents for the world.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So many times I've spoken to you in Medford, in particular West Medford,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's one of the oldest African American communities in the entire United States of America.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that community was established in the early 1800s just after slavery.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I talked about in the past about the Underground Railroad and the wonderful abolitionists that were here in Medford, George Stearns, and

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lydia Marie Child, where people know her for her famous poem, Over the River and Through the Woods, but she wrote a book called An Appeal in Favor of That Class of Americans Called Africans.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She was an abolitionist.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I also want to tell you about some change agents of African descent that came through Medford and made an impact

[Edouard-Vincent]: not only in Medford, but beyond.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to talk a little bit right now about Prince Hall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was born in Barbados.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I know we have students here that are of Asian descent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When people were wearing their flags on a Wednesday, I talked to one of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was born in 1735, but he came

[Edouard-Vincent]: to Boston at the age of 17 and he settled in Medford at the age of 25.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What he ended up doing, he bought real estate and he ended up joining the Continental Army.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What I can say to you about Prince Hall, he served as a change agent because he started the Freemasons and he used his status to help liberate slaves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Bedford was part of his story, and his story was part of freeing slaves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you go into Boston, in a section called Roxbury, Grove Hall in particular, it's a predominantly African-American community in Roxbury.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is a hair school there called Lyell In School of Beauty Culture.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Elizabeth Oliver Newton started her business in Medford and from Medford she was the first African American person to be able to open a hair school for

[Edouard-Vincent]: African Americans because at that point in time, they weren't accepted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And she was an hairstylist.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So she's just someone that I wanted to just highlight as someone who came through Medford but ended up creating an establishment that supported African Americans

[Edouard-Vincent]: and or Afro-Caribbeans to do something that they wanted to do when it wasn't accepted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if you're in the Brokaw area, between Bowling Alley and Lawrence Street, her hair school is still there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also want to just, because you know, I may have said to you I grew up in West Medford, if you ever go by the fire station in West Medford, Mr. Charles Booker,

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was the first African-American firefighter in the city of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Alonzo Fields.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was the chief usher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He served five presidents of the White House.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Then there was also a change agent, Mr. Ansel Alexander, known as Bud Colbright, Jr.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was an orphan, and the city of Medford reunited him with his mother and siblings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He went on to serve in World War II, and he was so appreciative of what the city of Medford did.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As an adult, in 2003, he donated $100,000 to bring new play equipment

[Edouard-Vincent]: to the Duggar Park community because that was where he grew up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I think about change agents and people who make a difference in the world, I think about all of those people who make a difference who have come through Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want you to know that Medford has a rich history.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of you who are in here are part of Medford's history.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am part of Medford's history, and so are you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I encourage you to know that just because I mentioned a few change agents, I want all of you to know that you can be change agents of tomorrow as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want to close with a quote from Dr. Rae Jameson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She was the first African-American astronaut to fly on a space shuttle.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She once said,

[Edouard-Vincent]: by other people's limited imaginations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Jameson speaks the truth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I want to thank you, Mustangs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Happy Black History Month to you all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's try that again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good afternoon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: OK.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're here for this wonderful, auspicious event today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have so many phenomenal women on the stage.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not going to steal the thunder, because I know we have many students that have practiced and are prepared to read their opening remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want to say a special thank you to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Walker and to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Evangelista for all of their coordination efforts in getting this special event off today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to say I'm very happy to be part of this panel and to be able to celebrate the positive contributions of women.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank all of our special guests, but I also thank you, the audience.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've received wonderful questions, and we look forward to hearing from all of you, staff and students, and anyone else who's here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to just say thank you for supporting us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And just in true style, if I say Medford, you say Mustangs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mustangs!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All right, good job.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to just invite our mayor up, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, who's part of the panel today, and she also has a few opening remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we are ready for our student introductions of invited guests.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If I may, one piece of advice that I would give to myself if I could rewind the clock back would be to have taken even greater advantage of all the different opportunities that were before me starting in high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do wish that I had played more sports.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was in drama, I was reading, I was more kind of on the academic side.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I do wish that I had pushed myself in other areas just to be exposed to other people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because the more that you're exposed to, the more well-rounded you are, and the better it is for you in the end to be able to interact with all different kinds of people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's what I would say.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Take advantage of all of the opportunities that are here, because you don't get a redo of high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So take advantage of it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my hope that everyone had the opportunity to spend quality time with their family and friends over the holiday break.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We at the Medford Public Schools have been diligently working to bring forth a plan for a new year that provides a renewed sense of safety and a means to highlight the many accomplishments and opportunities provided at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Often a tragic situation takes the focus away on what is good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I feel compelled to state that the Medford Public Schools, in particular Medford High School, has a tremendous amount of good going on daily.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I had stated prior to school break, so many of our students were actively involved in helping others to have a nice holiday season.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Friday before the holiday break, students at Medford High School were decorating gingerbread cookies, playing holiday carol music with their guitars.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The senior class of 2023 enjoyed their senior breakfast, complete with their pajamas on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was a bagpiper strolling in the hallways at the end of the day to bid farewell to one of our teachers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and there were plenty of blow-up characters in the hallways.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Seeing all of these things, it definitely made my heart sing that our high school students were able to leave for vacation on a positive note.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our teachers, working with central administration, wanted all of the students to leave for the holiday break with a positive experience, and they truly went above and beyond to make that happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank them all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While it doesn't wash away what has happened, it does allow me to focus on a quote by author Melanie Beatty.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The new year stands before us like a chapter in a book waiting to be written.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a community, we must come together in order to write that new chapter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that the mayor, the school committee, central administration, our counseling and behavioral health office staff, along with teachers, administrators, and the Medford Police Department had not stopped over the holiday break.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our school community can only achieve peace and greatness if we do so collaboratively.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I announced last Thursday, we produced our 10 point action plan for safety, transparency and accountability at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I plan to discuss that plan more in depth later this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, let me state once again, that our top priority has always been to provide a safe and secure learning environment for all our students and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As Mustangs, we know a positive school culture is paramount to providing quality and supportive education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is our time to move forward together with attitudes and knowledge to help our students reach their academic and personal potentials.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our students, staff, and families require nothing less.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On that, I would like to share an important information note.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that the Massachusetts Behavioral Health, the helpline is now available, it's live.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanna thank member McLaughlin for bringing this to our attention.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Whether there is a crisis or you are unsure where to turn,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now there is a number that you are able to call or text, and that number is 833-773-2445.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, that number is 833-773-2445.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 773-2445.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, please note that there are 25 designated community behavioral health centers across the state, which can be accessed regardless of your insurance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These centers can be utilized for all behavioral health evaluation and treatment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The center that will assist Medford residents is located at Cambridge Health Alliance, 1493 Cambridge Street.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And their number is 833-222-2030.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, the number is 833-222-2030.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if people want to look and do research for additional information, you can go to mass.gov slash community behavioral health centers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The boys will play at noon, and the girls will follow at 1.30pm.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, donations can be canned food, household cleaning items, feminine hygiene products, baby diapers, and toiletries.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the Lunar New Year will begin.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It starts on January 22nd and it lasts for seven days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is the year of the rabbit and the rabbit embodies the yin or the passive principle of the universe, which means the new year will bring with it the hope that people will be able to lead a more relaxed and balanced life.
