[Edouard-Vincent]: So before you, you have my goals proposed goals for school year 2223.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'll be presenting on three goals the district improvement goal, the student learning goal, and the professional practice goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For 2223, the Medford Public Schools will improve the systems and structures that directly impact student services and operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Improved outcomes or plans to improve outcomes will be seen in student transportation, communications, and facilities operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The goal is to continue maintaining a learning environment built upon the pillars of safety, equity, and consistency,

[Edouard-Vincent]: creating a culture that values consistent communication and creating structures that promote healthy transportation to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So one of the things we are proposing to do is to establish modern and accessible bicycle racks at schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to leverage partnerships with safe routes to schools for walking school buses,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bicycle lanes and other options to reduce carbon and promote student welfare.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Three, consistent communication to families across all schools and student services such as athletics, counseling, career services and student governance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Four, we would like to begin the process for a school bus RFP that examines busing options beyond the MBTA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would also like to convene the capital planning committee to examine building systems and create a replacement timeline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to fully collaborate with MSBA, Massachusetts School Building Authority, to improve facilities and building systems.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the outcomes that we would hope to see by the end of this school year, bicycle racks updated at the middle and high school complexes, walking school bus routes clearly defined,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bicycle lanes painted on city streets and school access roads.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Looking into purchasing a communication platform that is used regularly by all schools and student servicing groups.

[Edouard-Vincent]: such as talking points, which we have invested in this year, possibly some mores and others.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're still continuing to research additional communication platforms that can be used consistently across all schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have launched a new website and the hope is in the near future to launch a new district smartphone app, which is connected to the newly updated website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, by the end of the school year to be well on our way with the school bus contract that responds to our student transportation needs and have the capital planning committee review can conduct reviews at each of our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under my student learning goal, because again student learning goals do take time to see results.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are still prioritizing early literacy in Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so as we are working on prioritizing early literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to continue to implement interventions in literacy to improve outcomes for all of our students by deepening teacher and principal knowledge, again, of early literacy practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at the same time, we would like to be maintaining a district-wide focus on instruction and assessment through the continued use of NWEA MAP.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the key actions,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to continue to support the development of our early literacy program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are continuing to work closely with DESE and following the DESE guidelines, which includes our dyslexia guidance through the implementation of the enhanced core reading instruction program, ECRI.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Continue to provide professional development for our teachers, supporting coaching,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are continuing our partnership with Hill for Literacy during this school year for 22-23 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the continued use, this will now, we are coming upon our first year of NWEA MAP, which is again, the Northwest Evaluation Association Measures of Academic Progress.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are continuing to use the NWEA MAP assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for outcomes, we want to see consistent, full implementation of ECRI across all K-2 classrooms within the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we will be able to identify and see that visible implementation of the science of reading, the best practices that are being taught to our teachers during literacy blocks, also through conducting early literacy learning walks district-wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we will be very intentional and strategic about our analysis of data and literacy outcomes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Looking at progress from the beginning of the year and then looking at our mid year benchmarks and end of the year benchmarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Beneath that it says accountability.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this is new for this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I say that

[Edouard-Vincent]: This will be the measurable goal that I would hope at the end of the year, we are able to see our students achieving.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's an ambitious goal, but my hope is that we will be able to see significant movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would like to see 100% all of our students at the four elementary schools in the aggregate demonstrate growth again,

[Edouard-Vincent]: at the 50th percentile or higher based on the RIT scores.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, although this is our early literacy goal, but an additional accountability measure, we would like to see not only at the elementary levels,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Throughout the rest of the district, grades six through 10, 100% of all students in the aggregate demonstrating equal growth at the 50th percentile or higher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we would like to see 65% of our students meet or exceed their projected growth targets on the NW EA map assessments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By the spring of 23.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so last spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a partial presentation on NWEA MAP was presented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were other indicators that other pieces of information that needed to be presented as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so right now, schools are still administering the beginning of year assessments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when we complete the beginning of year assessments for NWEA MAP this year, we will be presenting to the committee the results of the fall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And looking at the results of last year, and showing a comparison from one year because now we have a full, full year cycle to look at from the beginning of the year last year to how we performed the beginning of the year this year to see what direction our students are moving.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are hoping we're very optimistic that we're going to see positive movement continued positive movement and growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I will be presenting that to the committee in the in the coming weeks, once all of that data is available and addressing as many pieces that were on the original request

[Edouard-Vincent]: as many pieces of possible that we are able to present now that we have more data to be able to paint a fuller picture of how NWEA map is in Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the bottom of that goal I have a small star just showing that the RIT scale is a stable scale.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Similar to feet in inches that accurately measure student performance, regardless of age grades or grade level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so this is the information that we will be using my third and final goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: is my professional practice goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And my previous years that I was presenting my professional practice goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I always listed this up because I participated in Jesse's new superintendents induction program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which is where the NSF NSP came from, and I participated in the supplemental programming that they had.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so now I have transitioned, and I am now participating in leading now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I am part of mass ready.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And these are two additional professional development groups, leading now is a national group, and working with superintendents from across the nation, and mass ready is Massachusetts school superintendents that are participating in professional development around.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Racial equity diversity and inclusion so it's referred to as ready.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I am actively participating.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am helping to support and co facilitate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When asked at many of these events, and supporting and mentoring and working with other superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I also some of the outcomes that I have listed again continuing to leverage the expertise and collective knowledge of superintendents across the state.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Seeking input and incorporating suggestions from our own NPS race equity task force, leading and learning about ready and providing mentorship, and also continuing to work collaboratively with our Middlesex County DA's office, their anti-bias, anti-hate task force.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I presented, I was part of a,

[Edouard-Vincent]: panel last week, speaking to the new assistant DAs that have just come on for this first year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I am continuing to do that work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And these professional development sessions take place on a monthly basis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And those are my goals for this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, as of right now, it's mostly central office, but we would definitely like to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Broaden broaden that the capital planning work, and we can work in collaboration with one of the subcommittees I'm sure we can definitely do that but we wanted to at least have the district improvement goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: be inclusive of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm trying to think of how it was awarded to me the other aspects of the district that aren't always connected to academics and learning but are equally important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I would be remiss to say that I have had the opportunity to speak with many members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and many conversations and received feedback and consult for many of you to help inform these goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do hope that everyone can kind of see some, a little bit of trying to, their input.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That is my hope and that I will continue to work collaboratively with the committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, that is it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we also when possible we always work collaboratively.

[Edouard-Vincent]: with Alicia hunt and like consulting with her, like the project, you know for solar panels or just different things like that where she, she will always support us I think there's even some, you know, with the bicycle racks and just trying to do things to enhance the community and be thinking of health and safety.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We definitely would partnership with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: create partnerships with the community and the city for the advancement of the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Lucy, can you please come forward to share what the timeline there was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't have the specifics let me ask Mr. Lucy, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So last year, I don't have the hard number because one of the, with the NWEA map, there are a few exceptions that I wanna like share.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One, for example, we are providing the assessment three times a year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, in the winter administration,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The window of the NW map assessment is the same window of time that our English learners are taking the access test.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So during that window of time we do have students that will not be double tested.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, we're not going to have 100% complete data, which is why.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We actually had a really rich discussion back at Central on what would be a reasonable number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have, you know, due to test fatigue for some students, so we're not going to like, you know, give them the double whammy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we have some students that it could be, you know, maybe due to the interventions that they're having or it could be extreme.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Maybe anxiety or distress around assessment taking that we would not want to have this in house assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: know, harm them, because we're thinking about the whole child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also know that there's mobility that takes place with some of our students, they may start, they could potentially leave or they may come midway through the year and so we don't have beginning of year data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, with all of those pieces we were thinking about how do we show student growth, we know that all students will grow all students will learn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that was where we came up with a conservative number of 65% because we do know that there are some special populations that will not be.

[Edouard-Vincent]: participating.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So last year, we didn't have consistent data across the board.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was the first time that it was being given.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some students love taking tests.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They take it as a challenge, and they gave it their all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was the first time that it was administered.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were some technical glitches that ended up happening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so due to all of those reasons,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We said 65% would be like a reasonable number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also there's some information like with the bell curve and, you know, there's a percentage that will maybe not show as much growth, and some that will show significant growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we were going back and forth but

[Edouard-Vincent]: Trying to say what is a reasonable accountability measure.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that was where we came up with the 65% being reasonable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we were looking at the data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: there were ebbs and flows, there were some stronger pockets, there were some pockets that we were looking at, but there were so many factors with the pandemic, with kids that were still out, with quarantining, there were just so many factors that we felt like the initial data was a little shaky, it was a first time out, and that this is gonna be the real year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so by the end of this year,

[Edouard-Vincent]: we will calculate where we land and we're not sure, like I'm saying 65 and the data could say that it's really 55 or the data could say, you said 65, but actually it's 75%, which would be even more fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're really trying to get as many students assess this year and then use that data

[Edouard-Vincent]: To, you know, propel us to the next level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So since this is the first time that I was putting an accountability metric.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I really didn't want to say 100% of students are going to meet or exceed, knowing that some students will only take two assessments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some students, you know, for whatever reason, where, you know, we're thinking about them, the whole child that we know we have to remove some students from the SS assessment cycle that we said you know we can feel pretty certain that 65% of students that we can probably get 65% of our students to take.

[Edouard-Vincent]: all you know portions of the assessment, and then look at our performance based on that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, but the other two bullets, the 100%, based on a presentation that I did in the late spring, we were able to show growth, even though all students didn't grow the same amount,

[Edouard-Vincent]: All students showed growth and the hope is that we will continue to have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 100% growth in the aggregate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is something where I didn't lower it to say 90% or 88%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're trying to keep that number as high as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So no matter what your starting point is, you need to show growth by the end of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we're pretty confident that we're going to be able to show growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we want to show growth at 50th percentile or higher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So

[Edouard-Vincent]: we're still going to be, you know, staying very positive and wanting to see us get to that very high number or as close to that number as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wrote it down, I'm gonna, I will revise it, add climate and culture assessment at middle and high school as an outcome under the district improvement goal, and to add Hill for Literacy core program review under key actions, and then the outcomes will be new selected elementary literacy program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I will, I wrote it down, I'll make those revisions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we begin tonight,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would be remiss if I did not mention that yesterday was the 21st anniversary of the horrific September 11th terrorist attacks on our country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that everyone remembers where they were that day when that first plane hit the World Trade Center.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Despite the unspeakable pain and loss, we will always feel at the deaths of over 2,900 people

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also remember the sense of unity and service that was palpable during this time 21 years ago.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Indeed, in our work, educating students who were not yet born on September 11th, we strive to continue that commitment to service and in the hope that there will be moments devoid of tragedy in which we will once again feel, at least to some degree, that sense of unity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To honor the memory of all those lost, I respectfully ask that we rise for a moment of silence to remember all those who perished and for all the public safety personnel who ran to help the victims that day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And sadly, I would also like to ask that we just take one additional moment of silence to honor the memory of Kyle Roust, a 2019 Medford High School graduate who lost his life in a tragic accident this summer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Over the last several weeks, this is regards to the opening of school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The hallways and classrooms of our school buildings have once again been filled with students and staff, as together we once again embark upon a new school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Administrators and first year educators arrived on campus the week of August 22nd, and our new staff were treated to an induction week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: as well to help them get acclimated to the Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Induction week this year included a tour of the city of Medford, in which our new colleagues visited Tufts University, the Royal House, and the slave quarters, and the brand new Medford Library.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After the library, the group was welcomed to Medford by Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There will be a more detailed report next week from Dr. Riccardelli.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If the last few school years have taught us anything, it is that the partnerships we enjoy as a school are critically important to the execution of our mission.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to take this opportunity to recognize several different invaluable partnerships that make it possible for us to do this work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First, our most sincere thanks goes to our Members Plus Credit Union for providing 100 filled backpacks for our students, and to Wegmans for providing additional school supplies for our middle and high school students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Second, I would like to note the generous donations from Tufts University, Herb Chambers, Simple Fare, and East Cambridge Savings Bank.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because the networks night of 10,000 lights had a wonderful fundraiser at rights pawn this past Saturday evening, and due to generous donations of our partners that event was able to take place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to share, as we announced last week, that the Medford Public Schools has reached tentative agreements with three of our bargaining units, representing administrative assistants, carpenters and maintenance personnel, and school nurses.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are grateful to each of these groups for their commitment to the district, and we'll be submitting those tentative agreements to the school committee for your final approval in the coming days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, as we announced last week, and with the unanimous support of the school committee, we have declared an impasse in our negotiations with the Medford Teachers Association in order so we may petition the Massachusetts Department of Labor Relations to assign a neutral mediator to assist toward a resolution on a successor agreement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These decisions will be discussed later in the agenda in our labor update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But to be clear, the declaration of an impasse in no way constitutes the district walking away from the bargaining table.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It instead means we are looking to engage in this negotiation with the assistance of a mediator in the hope of expediting a resolution.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Finally, there are a few reminders and updates that reflect what a busy time of year this is for our Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fall sports season is in full swing, and we wish all of our athletes well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our Mustang football team began their season this past Friday against Arlington.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do encourage all community members to check out our sports schedule to support our student athletes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This week, Medford Special Education Parent Advisory Council hosts its first virtual meeting of the new year on Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sunday, Mustang alum Dave McGilvery's inaugural Run Medford event will be held.

[Edouard-Vincent]: CCSR and Power Kids were selected as beneficiaries of this race.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On September 24th at Hormel Stadium, the Mustang Band will host and compete at the New England Band Competition.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While there are very limited number of teaching positions and power positions that we still need to fill, we have successfully filled the vast majority of vacancies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As noted in one of my back to school bulletins, we are welcoming several new leaders into administrator roles.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While we hope to have an opportunity to introduce you to several of these new faces in presentations in the coming weeks and months, I've asked our two newly minted school leaders to join us tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my pleasure to introduce Mr. Andrew O'Brien, friendly assistant principal at the Roberts Elementary School, who is now the principal of the McGlynn Elementary School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and Dr. Lori Hodgdon, who is now the principal of the Curtis Tufts High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lori most recently held the role of school director at the Collegiate Charter School of Law.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At this time, I would like to ask Mr. Andy O'Brien and Dr. Lori Hodgdon to step forward so that they may be recognized.

[Edouard-Vincent]: My name is Dr. Marice Edouard-Vincent, and I am so honored to be the superintendent of the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford is a welcoming community, and in our schools, we thrive to be inclusive and offer so many educational and athletic opportunities for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools has always encouraged our parents and caregivers to collaborate with us to benefit your students' education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that it takes all of us, parents, caregivers, teachers, administrators, the Medford School Committee, and the community at large to work together for the betterment of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford is one of the oldest communities in the United States, settled in 1630 and established as a city in 1892.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is a community rich in diversity and history.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a district, our guiding pillars are achievement for all, collaboration for all, equity for all, and support for all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As Maya Angelou once said,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We should all know that diversity makes for a rich tapestry, and we must understand that all the threads of the tapestry are equal in value, no matter what their color.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I look forward to us working together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay, just, I wanted to say, as I read the feedback under instructional leadership that I did agree with the feedback that I know that there is work that needs to continue to be done where it was talking about the secondary level remediation for students in literacy and in math, especially trying to close the gaps from the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I definitely, in agreement with the feedback that's being shared, I just wanted to offer that as we think about layering the different programs, K-12, one of the things that I'm always trying to balance is like the caseload, the workload on the teachers, because if in fact we end up

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm introducing too many different topics at the same exact time, then you don't have time to really go deep and fully understand like we when I got here we adopted the fast science and now we just adopted the math and

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're looking at the literacy as the third program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I just wanted to share that I am trying to balance how much is a reasonable amount of new content new programs to be able to present.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to the teacher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is part of why there isn't this let's go whole hog and change everything all at once, because it's overwhelming.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The teachers need to have time to learn the new programs and then to be able to teach it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a little context as to why I wasn't trying to go faster at a faster rate because I truly don't want people to

[Edouard-Vincent]: feel stressed or overwhelmed that it's too many programs happening all at the same time that they're not able to fully process it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for the data informed decision making.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so as a district,

[Edouard-Vincent]: we were showing growth, that we were hitting at least 50% at almost every single grade level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were above the 50th percentile.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They helped to unveil a beautiful Mustang statue.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's placed near the entrance to the Caron Theater.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The plaque that accompanies this beautiful bust of a Mustang head says in recognition of the class of 2020 Medford High School Medford vocational technical high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We remember your strength resilience and unending commitment to our school community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You so ably demonstrated the true meaning of Mustang spirit, setting an example for alumni and the many students to follow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Special thanks to Mr. Devaney of Oak Grove Memorials for designing the marble base that supports the bust and giving the school a significant discount.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to have that bust displayed beautifully in the foyer area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So last week, we had the opportunity to enjoy some events that in the past we would have missed out on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We celebrated our Junior Olympics at Hormel Stadium with fifth graders.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was an absolutely beautiful day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Graham, Member McLaughlin, Mayor McLaughlin, Mayor Lungo-Koehn, Member McLaughlin.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to wish all of our dads out there a happy Father's Day, this coming Sunday, this coming Sunday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: June 19.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also want to just remind everyone that June 19 is Juneteenth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It became a federal holiday last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The name is the blending of the words June and 19th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It commemorates June 19th, 1865, the day that the Union Army Major General Gordon Granger rode into Galveston, Texas and told slaves of their emancipation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That day came more than two years after President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1st, 1863.

[Edouard-Vincent]: even after Lincoln declared all enslaved people free on paper that hadn't necessarily been the case in practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Juneteenth is also known as Emancipation Day, Jubilee Day, Freedom Day, and Black Independence Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: People across the country celebrate with food and festivities, much like the 4th of July.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In celebration of Juneteenth, schools will be closed on Monday, June 20th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: School will resume on Tuesday, the 21st, and our last day of school is Thursday, June 23rd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I said, this is our last regular school committee meeting of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be scheduling additional meetings, which we mentioned earlier.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I especially want to thank

[Edouard-Vincent]: all of our students and staff, as well as our school committee for another successful school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And since we are still finalizing details on this list, we will be individually recognizing all of our retirees at our first meeting officially in September.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This presentation was also in response to a request, community request, to just

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let us share some of the key, key pieces that we are allowed to share to say what Medford Public Schools is doing in support of our safety and security measures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Questions?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Just waiting a moment for the slide deck to be pulled up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm here this evening to present the update on the implementation of our first full administration of the NWEA map assessment system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: NWEA standing for Northwest Evaluation Association.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I begin my remarks, I wanted to say that

[Edouard-Vincent]: Having NWEA math growth assessment right now in Medford Public Schools, that the first purpose of the assessment system is to be a diagnostic tool for us to be able to make data-informed decisions about what's taking place in all of our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so in order to create a data-informed culture, it is important to consider that data is to be used for instructional improvement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This data that will be presented today is based upon growth and it is by nature very, very dynamic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is not a fixed number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We should also consider and remember that we're thinking about the whole child, that data is not fate for any individual child, classroom or school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Like a map, it is an opportunity to see where we are in relation to where we want to go.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So let us tread cautiously upon how we interpret the data that I'm going to share with you this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as we look at this data, I have two protocols that are in front of you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The arrow says that we collect data points

[Edouard-Vincent]: We assess and make meaning of the data, and then we adjust our practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The image on the right shows the data-wise ladder of inference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so you have data, you interpret the data, you draw conclusions, and the final step is you always take action and we begin the cycle over and over again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here, the image on the left is an iceberg.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An iceberg is something where you can only really see the top of it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as we're looking at this data, the hard number is the tip of the iceberg that we can actually see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We don't see all of the other components that are beneath the water.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that's why I said a little earlier that we're talking about the whole child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, we're not taking this data point to define a child

[Edouard-Vincent]: exclusively by a number, but to be able to say that this is just one point of many points as we work with children and think about the learning of the whole child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these are a few summary of actions of things that we've been doing working with data analysis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, we had professional development,

[Edouard-Vincent]: with all of our teachers for NWEA MAP training for them to understand what the test was going to be like and how to use this new tool.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also this year, administrative meetings focused on

[Edouard-Vincent]: data analysis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also use the preliminary baseline data for NWEA map.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this professional development took place with principals, directors, and coordinators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Dr. Carmen Williams was also part of the body of research that she worked on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But during these professional development meetings, we developed a common language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We talked specifically about data analysis and the importance of triangulation of data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have inside a document.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that was used, Dr. Cushing, are you able to just click on that?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you go back one, please?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you click on the example of data analysis conclusions that this happens on some levels within department meetings where the educators are looking at

[Edouard-Vincent]: Where are the areas of success?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Where are the areas that we need to revisit?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this is just one hard copy of an example of how teachers are looking at data and using their data to inform their instruction and to inform next steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you revert back to the slide deck, please?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Coherence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this work with NWEAMAP, we finally have one assessment system that's being used in all of our eight schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Every building is using the assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's the same exact assessment being used district wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are able to compare data and look at how students are demonstrating growth with the content that is being covered.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I talked a little bit about the slide deck, the sheet that we just showed you showed the stoplight activity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These are the types of questions that teachers and principals, administrators, curriculum directors are asking their teachers as they look at data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What do they notice and wonder?

[Edouard-Vincent]: the single loop, double loop learning, and stoplight activity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of these activities, again, are happening at all different levels across the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: The spotlight activity

[Edouard-Vincent]: Red, what can we stop doing because we don't have evidence that it is effective?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yellow, what do we need to adjust and or consider an alternative way?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And green, what do we need to continue doing because it is working?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I get ready, Dr. Cushing, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I get ready to show the hard data for the district, I wanted to just bring up some relevant vocabulary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to be talking about the RIT median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you see the words or the letters RIT, it's the rash interval unit scale.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's named after a Danish mathematician, George Lash.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The RIT scale is a stable scale, like feet and inches, that accurately measures student performance regardless of age, grades, or grade level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Like marking height on a growth chart and being able to see how tall your child is at various points in time, you can also see how much they have grown between tests.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can use this height analogy when explaining RIT, the RIT process, to students as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The higher the RIT score, the more achievement the student has in the subject.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The student's percentile ranking in conditional growth percentile can show how much the student has achieved in comparison with their peers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's a few other vocabulary words that I just wanted to highlight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to be sharing the median score today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The median score is the middle number of a data set.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It separates the upper half of a data set from the lower half.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The mean is the same as the average value of a data set and is found using a calculation by adding up all of the numbers and dividing that number, dividing by the number of numbers in the data set.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the mode is the number in a data set that occurs most frequently.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You'll also see CCR, which is talking about college and career readiness.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to begin with our science benchmarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm really pleased to report to the committee that this purple band in the middle, which says NWEA median score, it's at the 50th percentile, that the majority of our performance as a district was above the median score listed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which on the left-hand side shows higher achievement, lower achievement, where that little arrow is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So science was given two times this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're showing the data for third grade,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The median score was 188, and in the winter when our score was given, our range was, our first number ranged from 191 to 199.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Kirshen, you can go forward to, thank you, third, fourth, and fifth grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the median score that we were looking for in third grade was 188.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At all four elementary schools, the range that was shown, we exceeded that median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In fourth grade, the median score was 195.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In all elementary schools, we exceeded 195, the 50th percentile, we were above that score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In fifth grade, the median score was 200, and our range was from 203 to 208 in the winter administration of the science.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the elementary level, all of our elementary schools were above the non-referenced median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, it's nationally normed, so we are at or above the nationally normed reference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For grade six, the median score was 204.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and our range was between 203, our lowest score, and 206.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the three numbers that are showing shows you the range of scores within the school, 206, 207, 208, 203, 204, 205, but the median score was 204.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In grade seven,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The median score was 207, and we were above that at 208 and 214.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the eighth grade, the median score was 210.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were at 216 and 210, respectively, hitting the median percentile.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For high school, Dr. Cushing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: The median score was 211 for ninth grade, and we were at 217.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In 10th grade, the median score was 213, and we were at 219 as our lowest score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our summary of science is as follows.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that we were able to show growth, and again, this was a diagnostic tool at all levels, and we showed even greater growth between the winter and spring assessments that took place for grades three through eight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was limited growth at grade six, but this again is the first time when we get to the secondary level that our sixth graders end up having a science, an individualized science teacher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was one area where we saw a slight adjustment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, we can move forward to math.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In math, this is a similar scale.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, Member Ursula.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the three numbers are the range of scores that were administered in that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So all the scores fell between, Dr. Cushing, you can leave it right here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So grade 10, the winter range of scores

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the high school, we fell between 219 and 221.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this was the average.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they broke it out by individualized tests.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then when we pulled a specific report to say

[Edouard-Vincent]: 10th grade, which is where I'm meeting right now, what was the range?

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was 219 to 221 in the fall, in the winter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then in the spring, we were 220 to 222.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there was small growth, but there was positive growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is saying it based on where the school is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was the first time that the assessment was given.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What you're seeing, this range of numbers showed us when we were looking at the data that the schools are performing similarly on this diagnostic assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these numbers are not individual students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was the entire grade level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, this is, no, exactly how Mr. Sealy explained it, but when you put the report, it showed you this was, I was using the term range of scores, but the median number was in the middle, and we were exceeding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: the median score, which is why we included the table, in almost every, there were a few areas that were outliers, but it wasn't even an outlier by significantly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It might have been a difference of one point, and by the, and again, this is showing growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But by the time the second or third administration of the assessment was given, students showed significant growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at some particular grade levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Science, the assessment was only given twice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was given in the winter and in the spring, but for ELA and math, those assessments were given three times, and you could see the growth, and there were a few areas that there was not as much growth, but we also realized that this year there was a pandemic,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year was the first time that the students were being introduced to this new assessment system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we also took that into consideration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also took into consideration that we had some significant attendance issues.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we had to do makeup tests and

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also had some people that might have taken the assessment the first time and not really put their best foot forward they just were like I want to just hurry up and get it done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So despite that, for me, looking at this data and looking at what the medium scores were.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a district, we were aligned that the majority of the district was performing at or above the non-referenced median score, which some were 50th percentile, some were 70th percentile when you average the entire grade level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Exactly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the median numbers were even higher.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the numbers that I was actually saying were the lower end.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for example, since we were still on science, if I look at 10th grade in science,

[Edouard-Vincent]: 213 was the recommended median score, and we had 219, 220 was the actual median, and 221.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we were higher, we performed better than what, we performed above the 50th percentile.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the 219, if you looked at,

[Edouard-Vincent]: 10th grade, the 219th was one increment lower than the 220, so we were closer to like the 69th percentile at ninth grade, which is very good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's something that you should, I mean, I was pleased when I saw this data because I actually had no idea where we were going to perform with last year being a remote year, trying to get back to some sense of normalcy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the first time that it took place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had almost complete data set.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have middle school finishing the literacy this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and being able to look at it as this is a first step, this is our baseline, this is diagnostic, and then we can use this to continue to inform instruction and next steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Director Sierra has an additional comment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was going to have us move on to math.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When we still take the we have the science MCAS that so all of this I feel this is helping the students to prepare for the state exams as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And also just to inform the instruction that's taking place so in ninth grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's intro to physics, earth and space science, biology and chemistry.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we are having students take the biology exam, but they're being exposed to multiple content and they are taking those classes between ninth and 10th grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So are you saying you would prefer that ninth grade and 10th grade not take any science assessment?

[Edouard-Vincent]: I guess I'm trying to understand your question.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when I think about the, and this is just me saying my thought about the assessment, when you are instructing, and where I talked about the data-informed instruction and the cycles of learning, these assessments allow teachers, it's fully aligned to the Massachusetts curriculum frameworks, so it is aligned to the content, the standards that have to be taught anyway.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the teachers can use this data, give an assessment, have a piece of data to inform their next steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It identifies areas where students do have weaknesses, and it identifies areas where students do have their strengths.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I feel like

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the absence of not having an informal assessment system, when we used to give the MCAS, well, we still give the MCAS, it's a requirement of the state, you never got the results until the following October.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those students were never in front of you to be able to go back and make adjustments to your instruction and learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, I mean, even at the science level,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although they're not able to measure growth the same way, and the MCAS is only given in science in fifth grade, eighth grade, and at the high school level once, ninth or 10th grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think now we're doing it in ninth grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This tool can still be used to

[Edouard-Vincent]: reinforce the content, show the content, and give the teacher an additional measure of what do the students know, what have they acquired, and what haven't they acquired?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, are they above the 50th percentile on this norm reference test, or do they need additional support?

[Edouard-Vincent]: We didn't have that data before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, and I see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's move forward to math.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this table that I showed for both math and for ELA

[Edouard-Vincent]: The goal where you're showing student growth is to be above the 50th percentile.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The same is true when you take the MCAS.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You want to see student growth percentile above 50.

[Edouard-Vincent]: any number above 50, and that's wonderful, because growth is showing measure, it's just showing that you grew.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Everyone can start at a different point, but you're showing growth over the course of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's critically important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In math, Dr. Cushing, if you advance,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Similarly, of what I was saying earlier, the median score for kindergarten was 140.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you look at our scores, all of them are above 140, and by the end of the year, our kindergarten students, the highest outer range was 165 in the spring assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, I'm gonna ask you to just go back one,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The 165 is essentially in the first grade

[Edouard-Vincent]: beginning of year benchmark.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when you see kindergarten ending a year at a 165, you're able to say like, wow, they showed from kindergarten beginning of year to first grade beginning of year, that's what you wanna be able to see, the growth and the movement in the positive direction, anything moving up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we stayed on the kindergarten lane, even though this table here is,

[Edouard-Vincent]: beginning of the year, but the 165 score is off of the chart.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if we went to 160, that would have been the 95th percentile.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in terms of growth, the students are showing growth, and that is a very good story.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Not that it's just a story to tell, because we know we're dealing with the whole child, but our students are showing growth this year as we come out of the pandemic with all of the things that we had to work with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was not sure if we were going to hit the median or exceed it by the end of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, Dr. Cushing, can you go forward again, please?

[Edouard-Vincent]: For first grade, the range was 160 was the median.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we're showing positive movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even for some schools where there was a slight difference, those of you who might look at the McGlynn, for example, you see the 159, the 160, the 162.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The goal of 160

[Edouard-Vincent]: By the end of the year, you can see the growth, which is absolutely wonderful when you look at the ranges.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Second code, the medium score was 175, and

[Edouard-Vincent]: We saw at second grade that there was one that was a little outlier, but the actual median score at the Mississippi was 173.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were still in the range, very, very close, either above or just right at the tail of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can we move forward to third, fourth, and fifth grade, Dr. Cushing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: The story is similar in third grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 188 was the median score that we were looking for.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fourth grade was 200.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we look at fourth grade math scores, again, the first time it was given, students were absent, students had quarantined, but by the end of the year, we moved all the way, we showed significant growth, which is important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fifth grade, beginning of the year was a 209, so we had two of the four schools that were within that range.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, this is diagnostic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're looking at what the median score is and saying, what do our next steps need to be?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, can you go to middle school, please?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Middle school was where we did identify

[Edouard-Vincent]: some areas it was 215 for the start of the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so both schools were not yet at the 215.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In seventh grade, the median score was 220.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, we do see a slight difference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: but we're looking at the range and seeing where they ended up by the end of the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Eighth grade, the median score was 225, and we did see that that was an area that we were able to identify as this is an area we need to work on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: High school please.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ninth grade, the median range was 226.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for 10th grade, it was 229.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we were right at the cusp, 230 in high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next slide, Dr. Cushing, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The math summary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The NWEA map test was given three times this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fall results.

[Edouard-Vincent]: were higher than the reported median scores, and we identified the few schools that were slightly lower than the median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also were able to show growth by all schools between the fall and the winter testing periods.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, I feel like the essential message is that this was a good story in terms of first time being given this assessment,

[Edouard-Vincent]: first time having the professional development and really being able to do this deeper analysis, data analysis with an in-house tool.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, can you go forward to ELA, please?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Similar format where I'm showing you the median scores.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so at the elementary level,

[Edouard-Vincent]: 137.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our kindergartens were, the majority of them were above, and then McGlynn School was exactly at 137 during the first administration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But by the time they took the assessment in the spring, we saw significant growth and movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 159 was the outer range of kindergarten.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, it was off the chart.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even though this was a fall assessment, but saying we saw significant movement in growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First grade, it was 156.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had two schools that were slightly lower in first grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The others were above that number of 156.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In second grade, we had 172, and we had one school that was, their range was a little bit lower, but again, the median was exactly 172.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Moving to third grade,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The median score was 187, and all of our school, we had one school that slightly missed the mark, but their median score at the Missituk third grade was 186.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fourth grade, the median score was 197, and all of our fourth grade at all four schools were above that median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Fifth grade, the median score was 204, and at the McGlynn, the score in the middle was 204, the outer range was 202, but all of the other schools were above the 204.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the middle school levels grade six, the median score was 210, and both schools were above that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, between the fall and the winter, we did see almost some like static movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In seventh grade, the median score was 214, and respectively, we had 222 and 217, which were significantly above the 214.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the eighth grade, the median score was 218, and again, we had a range, one school slightly behind.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the high school, the median score

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, at the high school, the median score was 219, and we were significantly above that at the high school level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grade nine and grade 10 was 221, and we were above that as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the summary on our ELA for the fall to winter results, again, K to two, we saw growth at all schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grade three, we showed growth at all schools from fall to winter with the exception of one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grades four and five, we showed all-on growth at all schools with the exception of one, which remained static.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Elementary, winter to spring results, we showed growth at grades K to three.

[Edouard-Vincent]: compared to our winter results, winter to spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In grade four, remained fairly static.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Grade five, we showed a slight decrease.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In grade six through 12, we showed decreases in growth from the fall to the winter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, at one school, it remained static.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the high school, we showed increases compared from winter to spring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the spring results for the middle school will be available in mid-June.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are anticipating to see growth levels at those two schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we will update the slide deck once that data is available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And all K-12 faculty have been trained again, as I said earlier, in data analysis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they spent time having professional development on how to use this tool.

[Edouard-Vincent]: during department meetings, principal meetings, and they spent time examining their data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as this data examination happens, it promotes, it prompts a shift in instruction, which is part of the data cycle.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our summary of actions, we are continuing to do data analysis with principals and curriculum directors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And through the use of NWEA and the data that is available,

[Edouard-Vincent]: These are based on the individual student rate scores.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are able to align Lexia Core 5, Lexia Power Up, Nuzella, and Khan Academy, the mappers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So these are supplemental resources that we have as a district that speak to the NWEA map assessment so there can be individualized targeted support work there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, the use of data based on analysis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is promoting adjustments in instruction at all discipline levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if necessary, we can make adjustments to our wind block, our response to interventions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If tier two support is needed, we can provide that support based on data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also can provide enrichment opportunities for students that show that they are hitting those benchmarks and doing very well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then there are shifts in instructional resources, if necessary, based on the information that is revealed from the data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, I just want to share the next steps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that we have the after action review where we are, teachers have been meeting in whether it's grade level teams and department teams providing feedback on the testing and testing protocols.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have realized that we're going to be modifying the district assessment calendar and teachers will have access to baseline data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at the start of the school year, which will help them to be able to measure and assess potential summertime learning loss when we begin the process again at the start of the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So newcomers are not taking this assessment yet.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Neither are any of our students with disabilities that qualify for the MCAS alt.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those students do not have to participate in NWEA map testing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've also had some families

[Edouard-Vincent]: speak to administrators to say that they don't want to participate in the assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, it is a diagnostic tool so it does serve a purpose.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's a lot of information where once you identify the area that a student needs help, it's targeted, it's pinpointed, and you can make those

[Edouard-Vincent]: necessary adjustments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I am hoping that we are really able to continue to use this as a diagnostic tool so we can see where we are and say, this is where we need to move.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This NWEA can be used as like a blueprint, print a roadmap to help inform instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not taking over what the teachers are doing, but it's just another piece of data

[Edouard-Vincent]: that can help to inform instruction and say, okay, this is where I need to double down.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is where the students are really strong and solid.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We can move on to the next concept.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For EL students, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Newcomers, no.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think it might have been, I wouldn't say, it might be like two days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't have the specifics for the amount of time, but it would not be the entire school day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they may have used

[Edouard-Vincent]: two blocks or three blocks, I'm not sure of the exact amount of time that was used to administer the assessment because this was the first time that we used it as a district and that's where we're still in the fact finding, gathering information and seeing how much of the information we can use to inform instruction and how long the assessment does take.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you and I think some students are able to go through it at a faster rate than other students and the way the test is designed and if either Dr. Chiesa or

[Edouard-Vincent]: Rocco Sierra, you wanna speak to this, or Faiza Khan, depending on how you perform on the NW, like the better you're doing, the more it adds.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So some students end up being able to do more because of how they're performing and it's showing their growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's not like it,

[Edouard-Vincent]: automatically will just stop with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's some fluidity to it, if that makes sense.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay, so I'm gonna ask if either Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Galuse, if you think you can come up to give some feedback and or Dr. Cushing on specifically at the elementary and secondary levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With this being the first time that the assessment was given, I have to say that this was a baseline, like we finally went through the full cycle.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I can say to you, I've seen the sample document that

[Edouard-Vincent]: teachers are using to look at how students have performed and what are next steps to inform what's happening during their response to intervention, their wind blocks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is being used to inform instruction and say, what do we need to readdress?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So some of the questions with this being the first go round, I actually feel like we're not gonna get

[Edouard-Vincent]: all of that information until now when it happens next year, because the fact of Mr. Russo's question about when they're taking the test, that the test continues, it continues with you based on how you're performing on the assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I would love for them to help respond to some of those questions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Absolutely.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So my response back would be that Medford never had an assessment system outside of the MCAS.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there was no way that teachers could have the same conversation across all four elementary schools or both middle schools to look at data and say, this is where my students are performing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: right now, whether we went with NWEA map assessment, but we never had anything.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in the absence of having an in-house assessment tool to use as a diagnostic tool to inform instruction, it just didn't exist.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you weren't able to get to coherence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's a similar conversation that I had with the committee when we had five different math programs between two middle schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You were using five different programs, how are you getting one, a clear picture on how the students were truly performing, because you did not have the same system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in order to bring about coherence in order to say we're moving the district forward, you have to have some kind of data assessment system in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a district, we went with the NWEA map.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It could have been iReady, it could have been others, but we were using NWEA map, and we're getting data now that at least tells us that's norm referenced.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Are we on track?

[Edouard-Vincent]: or are we off track?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Are we hitting that median score?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Are we doing it or not?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So a year ago, if you asked me, I would be like, well, we'll wait until the MCAS comes out, and then we'll be able to tell you something.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the first time that I have data outside of the MCAS that I'm able to just at least say in the month of June, wow, you can see the growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was the median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is our range.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is where we started in September, October.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is where our students ended up in June, so it's something if I'm just saying in the absence of not having anything and saying that we can't test students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: how are teachers, how are parents gonna be able to say, how is my child actually doing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now they can actually look and say, oh, this is the median score.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is where my child performs when they receive their, whether it's the fall or winter results, they can look at it and say, okay, you're doing well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you get your MCAS report card,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The following school year in October, the report card spells out for you is your child, you know, meeting the benchmark or not and they do a nice little graph and that that's part of the parent report card.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel it's worth the investment, we never had it before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to try to be moving instruction forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are a school first and foremost.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our goal is to educate students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to have a consistent tool that we are monitoring their growth and their progress.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we don't have a consistent tool in place, then essentially I'm just making up what I'm saying to you and saying, let's wait until October to find out how we're doing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I have, you know, I'm sorry you don't feel like the data

[Edouard-Vincent]: is showing that we are making progress.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also just wanted to say to piggyback on Suzanne's comments, because this data rolls over.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's really going to put the teacher, the teacher is going to have a clear map of like

[Edouard-Vincent]: What are your strengths?

[Edouard-Vincent]: What are the areas?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then we're going to have the new baseline data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the first time this assessment is given in the fall, they'll be able to look at June results, September, late September results, whenever we figure out when it's going to end, like cross map them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So students are actually going to be receiving more targeted support

[Edouard-Vincent]: earlier on because we have a reliable norm referenced assessment that's gonna be able to help us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that's why I was saying that this tool, not only that we're using it, but many other districts are using it as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So even if students transfer into Medford, if that data is available, we will have access to it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just feel like it's going to better position us

[Edouard-Vincent]: I felt like our weak link was always our lack of data accessibility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And now we finally have access to in house data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do feel like this is going to be a game changer for how we provide supports justify, you know, oh we need additional interventionists or additional this.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is what our data is saying.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is how many students are impacted by it and truly make data informed decisions to improve the entire district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am very excited to be at this formal public hearing for our budget.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: project that you've been doing at the Andrews this year, and I look forward to hearing more news next year as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thank you to the both of you for coming this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, we meet tonight on the 78th anniversary of D-Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On June 6, 1944, Allied forces crossed the English Channel and began to reclaim the European mainland.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This date is important as it marked a turning point on the Western Front in World War II.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are grateful for the greatest generation whose heroism changed the course of history for the world.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, I would like to share that it was truly a pleasure to witness our high school and vocational technical high school graduation last Thursday night at Hormel Stadium.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So much happiness and good energy surrounded all of us, and it really filled my bucket.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to congratulate once again the class of 2022.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that they will be successful in their future endeavors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also wanted to take a moment to commend and thank our Mustang Boys baseball team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They helped to place flags on the veterans graves throughout Oak Grove Cemetery in preparation for Memorial Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is gratifying to see our student-athletes volunteer to help our community at large, and especially to honor our veterans.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations are also in order for Ibrahim Ahmed, a seventh grade student at the McGlynn Middle School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ibrahim won the hardest math problem student contest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was presented by Scholastic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Actuary Foundation and the New York Life Foundation challenges students in grades six through eight to solve multi-step grade-appropriate math problems with real-world situations and engaging characters.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The contest energizes students' perceptions of math with fun, challenging story problems that combine math reasoning skills with writing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations, a job well done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, in keeping with congratulations, the McGlynn Elementary School was selected to receive the mathical book prize collection development award.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This award will allow the McGlynn Library to expand their collection of literary fiction and nonfiction books to encourage students to discover a love of mathematics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This $700 grant was awarded by the Mathematical Sciences Research Institute, MSRI, in partnership with the School Library Journal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in the wake of many recent multiple tragedies, I feel it is incumbent upon me to mention that June is National Gun Violence Awareness Month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Clearly, the fight to end gun violence has never been more urgent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Despite the horrors across the nation,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Over the course of this past year, weekend, there were 13 other mass shootings that occurred.

[Edouard-Vincent]: No matter your views on guns, we must try to work together towards the goal of allowing all of us to feel safe, whether in a movie theater, a medical building, at a concert or a party, at places of worship, a grocery store, and most certainly our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: June is Pride Month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last Thursday, I was happy to participate in Mayor Lungo-Koehn's flag raising here at City Hall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was wonderful to see so many different faces from our community come together in celebration and in commemoration of our LGBTQ plus community, family, friends, and neighbors.
