[Edouard-Vincent]: In closing, I want to just share a few remarks about safety.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There have been several emails coming in, in light of all of the violent events that have been taking place across the country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And members of the community in some of the emails are asking for specifics regarding safety and what is Metro Public Schools doing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are things that Metro Public Schools does do in order to maintain the safety.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do maintain doing fire drills, we're working closely and collaboratively with our fire department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do do at selected times, shelter in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But there are other pieces of our security protocols that we don't publicly or formally announced, so I did not have it listed this week as an official report, but at next Monday's meeting as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will be providing more guided information, follow up information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want the community to know that I work very closely with Chief Buckley and working with our administrative team and following the safety protocols that should be in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want people to know that we prioritize the safety of the entire community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it is our goal to keep our community safe, as safe as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I did want to say that there was also a district-wide safety team that administrators, special ed administrators, it's a collaborative group that does meet and discuss safety protocols, including building and grounds, and select administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I'm going to be sharing a very brief, well, I don't think it's that brief, but

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to share a somewhat brief slide deck with you on the results of equity audit of human resources.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's jump into the human resources audit I just want to recognize our students at the Curtis Tufts, who had a graduation ceremony last Wednesday, June 1 as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to acknowledge anyone who may be here any staff from the Curtis Tufts as well, and Mr. drowsky for leading the school and.

[Edouard-Vincent]: hosting that celebration that took place last week at the Irish American.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So congratulations to our students at the Curtis Tufts as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So what I'm going to share with you are key recommendations and results of our equity audit of human resources.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in terms of framing, I was starting off saying, why is diversity important?

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is important for us to consider perspective taking

[Edouard-Vincent]: Developing a sense of belonging is incredibly important for all of our learners, our students, our scholars.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A strong sense of belonging leads to higher levels of student achievement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So our why.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The equity audit of human resources was the first phase of a greater body of work that will continue in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please keep in mind that in light of the pandemic, it wasn't prudent for us to begin the equity work of the district starting in classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, with our focus on students first, we began this journey by looking at our policies and procedures that bring talent to NPS.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our goal is to improve and build an inclusive culture within Medford Public Schools hiring system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when we talk about a sense of belonging, sense of belonging is one of the greatest predictors of success.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Educational research tells us that one of the greatest predictors of academic achievement for students is a sense of belonging.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Increasing the diversity of our faculty is a measure to increase the sense of belonging for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanna share some data with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is Medford Public Schools student enrollment data from the DESE portal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have slightly over 4,000 students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first section of the blue bars is identifying student race and ethnicity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: African American students within the district represent 11.1%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Asian students, 9.4%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hispanic Latino students, 14.4%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Native American, 0.4%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: White students, 59.2%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Native Hawaiian Pacific Islander, 0.1%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Multirace non-Hispanic, 5.3%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in essence, we are almost a 60-40% split within Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under selected populations, we have 26.8% of our students, nearly 1,000 students in the Medford Public Schools, their first language is not English.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 1,000 of our 4,000 students, significant.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not English, meaning that they can be bilingual, speak other languages, and are equally conversant in English.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, our English learner population is 10.4%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These are students that are receiving intensive ESL supports.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our students with disabilities, 20.2%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, if we're thinking about 4,000, we are nearing the 1,000, 800 to 900 of our students within Medford Public Schools are receiving special education services in some way, shape, or form.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's a significant number.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This number was a little staggering to me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our students with high needs, 53.9%, more than 2,000 students in the Medford Public Schools are classified as students with high needs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: More than 2,000.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So within high needs, it's taking into account also not only socioeconomic and learning needs, it's inclusive, I would say, akin to saying most vulnerable, that these are students within our community that face greater challenges

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Desi identifies them according for us, that nearly over 2000 students fall into that category.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for those specifically classified as low income students, it's 40.5% that are classified as low income, which was also another staggering data point.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This slide here shows our staffing in Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we have over 600 staff that classify as or identify as white staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for Hispanic, Asian, and African American staff, and this is including more than the teachers as well, it's including other departments, we have very, very significantly smaller numbers than what was previously shown.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I just wanted us to be able to keep this data in mind as I continue to share some of the findings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you look at the image, depending which way you look at this image, it can be confusing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you look at this image, hopefully you're seeing something.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So here is some key vocabulary, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some key vocabulary that was used as part of this audit.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Throughout the audit, members of the school committee were interviewed, administrative members were interviewed, members of human resources, a specific office, business office at central office, they were interviewed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Race Equity Task Force were part of a conversation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were select conversations and surveys that took place to kind of gather and give us this information that I'm getting ready to share with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But here are some key terms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Diverse learning communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The definition of diversity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: equality, inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Diverse learning communities are learning communities that support collaborative partnerships between students and staff and attempt to restructure the curriculum to address structural barriers to educational excellence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are inclusive of all races, ethnicities, genders, creeds, sexual orientations, and abilities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next slide shows diversity hiring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Diversity hiring is hiring based on merit, with exceptional care taken to ensure procedures have reduced biases related to a candidate's age, race, gender, religion, sexual orientation, and other personal characteristics that are unrelated to their job performance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Diversity hiring is what we are going to be aspiring for here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we wanna be in our endeavor to improve our policies and procedures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want you to know that this audit was not about myself.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Maurice-Edouard Vincent, or my professional values.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What we are aspiring to do is align to the 2030 goals that are outlined here for the city of Medford, that are outlined at BSE, and that are outlined in the national 2030 global education goals that are both national and international.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What we are aspiring to do here in Medford

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're not on an island unto ourselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were some key recommendations that were based on the survey data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'll just read a few of them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of them under survey data was developing a hiring process that includes questions grounded in equity that meets the needs of our diverse populations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to work with supporting our building-based leaders by allowing them to lead and focus on instructional leadership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to be able to host informative community events that keeps all of our stakeholders up to date and explain to them the difference between diverse hiring and hiring for diversity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing, next slide please.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These were some recommendations based on facilitated discussions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: talking about creating inclusive standards that include accountability and confidentiality for all staff who work in the HR department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Creating a structure that fosters a sense of belonging for all staff while centering those from minority groups.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Creating a system for training building base leaders on equitable hiring practices and procedures, including but not limited to diversity hiring practices and processes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Creating a process that allows for competitive hiring.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The hiring timeline, to have it begin as early as February or before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and to be able to end in June and seeking approval from the school committee to see if that's something that we could continue to do and do it in a more formalized way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We wanna be able to also create exit interview processes that tracks and records all exit interview data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We identified some inconsistencies that currently exist right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of the things that we do not have yet but we will be working on is creating an HR human resources handbook to consist of policies and procedures and expected practices that include but aren't limited to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we do not have a handbook that houses everything all in one place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that's something that we will be working on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We would love to have a diversity statement that speaks to the environment that Metro Public Schools will create to support, empower, and celebrate members of our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also want to include statements and processes on our values, performance management, talent development, confidentiality,

[Edouard-Vincent]: constructive and cooperative discipline, dress code, the evaluation process at all levels, clear and transparent expectations of reciprocal communication between human resources and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Christian.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For school committee recommendations,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to be able to set the smarty goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, this is from Desi, that is Jedi driven.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I put at the bottom Jedi, that is one of the key vocabulary words, justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Reminding us that we have over 4,000 students within the district and always putting our students first.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Centering policies practices procedures around their needs and expected outcomes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Recommendations based on our current district vision and mission statement to co-create a simple, simplified district vision and a simplified district mission statement that is aligned to the 2030 global education standards.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Here is a continuum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have participated in significant professional development this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This particular slide is from the professional development that I was part of that was based out of Desi, and it worked with 25 superintendents and equity directors across the Commonwealth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Half of those superintendents were BIPOC individuals of color, and half of them were white superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we engaged in this learning together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They would separate us, and they would bring us back together to share our learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Diversity, belonging, inclusion, and equity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Looking at those four buckets, I want to preface it to say that this takes about eight to 10 years to achieve.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under diversity, it says you've been asked to the party.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under belonging,

[Edouard-Vincent]: you feel welcomed and comfortable going to the party.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under inclusion, you've been asked to help plan the party.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And under equity, it redefines what the party entails, who has the power to plan the party, and if there should even be a party.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are just embarking, I see Medford in the diversity bucket.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're just starting there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the bigger picture for us here in Medford, our North Star.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, you might see the Little Dipper or Big Dipper there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to set our intended priorities based on the audits recommendations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was only phase one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to create and continue to foster an HR department that embraces diversity hiring in the 2030 goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We wanna be ensuring that our students are centered in a part of our creation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to work closely with our internal and external stakeholders to ensure that we are inclusive and objective during our processes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we want to be building stronger partnerships with our community organizations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Christian, this work takes time and thoughtful planning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We can get there together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That other company where they did the letter reversal next year, it can be a new word, you know, that is all of a sudden it's the new word, like everyone's using, you know, fire.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, that's hot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's fire.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's fire.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I don't know if there's a way to

[Edouard-Vincent]: I guess some of it's objective.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I feel like that word is a moving target.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know if I'm really helping the conversation at all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, the comment that I was just going to make about the covering of the bathing suits, and I know that

[Edouard-Vincent]: a few bullets up where we're pretty explicit in terms of

[Edouard-Vincent]: not wanting people exposing private parts, showing their body.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you're thinking about a bathing suit for a female student, if she was choosing to wear a two-piece swimsuit, we do clearly state that they should have a top, a bottom, and footwear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they shouldn't be walking barefoot in the schools or outside.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They should have some type of footwear on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They need to have a top and they need to have a bottom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I know that there are,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some swim trunks that are really long, like they look like skateboard pants or whatever so some students may actually wear that as part of their fashion, but I think just being clear that we don't want to encourage.

[Edouard-Vincent]: swimsuits, people saying now, you know, it's warm, swimsuits, you know, this is my top, my bottom for the day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I think if we're saying to them, you need to wear a top, you need to have a bottom and you need to have footwear, that being explicit about that, so people just understand, I don't know if it's,

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, whether someone is having a swim class as part of their PE or their particular rotation, they understand that they are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, to have their swimsuit covered in that regard, or if it's someone wearing the swim trunks and they go swimming and they don't plan on changing their clothing, we wouldn't want someone walking through the hallways with wet clothing on for several hours it's just people can get sick and it's not something that you would be encouraging.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I think it's okay to say cover bathing suits and undergarments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm thinking, again, at the secondary level, we know we have the pool here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if for whatever reason students were to be wearing it at the lower grade levels, that they should have a top

[Edouard-Vincent]: a bottom and footwear, and that we're not talking about bathing suits.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's kind of like that gray area, but I think saying that that's not what we wanna see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, it's up to the administrator or teacher to have a conversation with the child or with the parent to say, this is what we're hoping to see the child wear to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I see nothing wrong with saying that, understanding that you said, well, my son does wear swim shorts to school, but if he's wearing them more as a fashionable statement and it isn't causing any kinds of disruption, that's, I think it's, in that regards, we're not gonna be the swim shorts police, but again,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think trying to be explicitly clear, sometimes you end up opening the door to challenge, no matter what way you look at it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I feel comfortable with the term undergarments.

[Edouard-Vincent]: whether it's bra tops or thong underwears or boxer shorts or kids wearing their pants halfway down their.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's all undergarments and we really don't need to see it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's not necessary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, going back to the top, a shirt, a blouse, a sweater, a sweatshirt, a tank, et cetera.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We say top, we say bottom, we say footwear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I'm comfortable with a bra strap because some tops have very thin straps.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the bra strap will show.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But again, I know that there have been situations where students weren't just exposing the bra strap, but other parts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it's just, I think it's,

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we can focus on, you know, tops bottoms and and footwear and say this is what our expectation is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if you know you have one or two outliers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that the teachers and or administration will speak to those students, but if it's something where

[Edouard-Vincent]: it becomes egregious.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And, you know, people want to say, you know what, this is my top.

[Edouard-Vincent]: My top is, you know, a bra, or my top is, you know, something that really, you don't need to wear that to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think by saying undergarments where, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're covering all of it, whether it's it's or for male, because, again, they both have different clothing styles, and we do see undergarments of male students as well, quite often and they're told, you know, fix your clothing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think by saying undergarments, if people, and again, we've qualified it about saying with the exception of the bra straps, that that's pretty clear in terms of what it is that we're talking about.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, I see that as being more of a secondary concern, but I think we have more, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the elementary levels, I don't see as much of these types of issues surfacing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It would be more at the secondary level where you would have students really wanting to see what they could get away with in terms of clothing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I feel like this is a happy medium and then removing the other piece about the bathing suit, et cetera.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think that this covers it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening, I am pleased to share with you my self-evaluation for school year 21-22.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is a little bit of a lengthy document.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will go through the documents and there are several hyperlinks within the document for you, the members to be able to review as you take this document to look at the evidence of practice for the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I would just like to open my remarks with the following remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please find my self-evaluation attached, which you have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evaluation is based on the events from July of 2021 through the end of the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You may refer to the superintendent's goals from school year 21-22, and you may use the link to access the goals that were established earlier this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The newly adopted Medford Public Schools District Strategy for Improvement document, which is our strategic plan, was approved last year on June 7th of 2021.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that document provides the blueprint for the district staff to achieve the mission of the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our mission is as follows.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools is a caring educational partnership of school, family, and community designed to ensure that all students are afforded a safe and healthy learning environment in which they develop the knowledge, skills, and attitudes to reach their full academic and personal potential.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This partnership is dedicated to providing all students with a 21st century education that will enable them to be lifelong learners and contributors to a diverse and rapidly changing world.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I want to just remind everyone that the strategic plan document is a document that's a living document, and we will continue to add additional information to that document.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Um, there is a hyperlink referring to the strategic plan update that I referred, uh, that I shared and presented to the committee in January of 22.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the following information I'm going to share, I have one district improvement goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have a student learning goal, and I also have my professional practice goal that I will be sharing with you this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So under the district improvement goal, it states the following, given the unprecedented hybrid learning environment during the school year of 2021, MPS will utilize common assessments, common systems and assessments to accurately assess the learning and social emotional needs of our students this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, through professional development, observation, and evaluation of staff, we will provide increased support to staff to better meet the needs of all of our learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So under our district improvement goals, we had a focus on developing a district-wide focus on instruction and assessment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And under that particular goal,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, where we had hybrid learning and we had some students that for the entirety of school year last school year were remote this school year we knew we had to take.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We needed to take stock of where we were as a district and so between staff absences student absences due to quarantining.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lack of substitutes, there were many, many challenges and obstacles that we had to overcome this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we also noticed that many students and staff are still recovering emotionally and academically, the students, from the periods of hybrid instruction and missed work that didn't happen from being in school for a full academic year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So particular professional development that was offered this school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had social emotional learning professional development for our staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We added the the nexus classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We added additional supports with our guidance and behavioral health teams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The execution of the multi tiered systems of support and the return of extra curricular activities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had training this year on implicit bias.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had training this year on race, equity, diversion, diversity and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on responsive classroom using a train the trainer model.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had training this year on NWEA math growth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had training, robust training this year on supervision and evaluation training for all administrators, and that was provided by Rebus Associates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that is going to continue working with Medford Public Schools next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We've also had significant work on developing a community of practice for system coherence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was a professional development work that took place this year with Dr. Carmen Williams in executing professional development and looking at data with all of our administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so many of the proposed outcomes that were listed in the goals were improved cell practices, cell acknowledgement and working with our students around social emotional learning practices for staff and for our leadership team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tailored instruction to improve student outcomes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: targeted feedback for teachers to improve practice and school and districts leaders leading and learning together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those were our, our first goal under the district improvement goals.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our second goal listed under the district improvement goal

[Edouard-Vincent]: was maintaining a learning environment built upon the pillars of safety, equity, and consistency.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Safety, equity, and consistency were the three pillars that guided us throughout the pandemic, and they continue to guide us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under safety, Medford Public Schools continues to use our safety protocols.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And although right now we are masked optional, we still fully utilize our safety protocols.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We continued our collaboration with Tufts University.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and the Broad Institute with testing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we concluded the formal testing right at the end of February of 2022.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And now we are using the at-home testing where families test their child either Sunday evening or Monday morning before students report to school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we had a link, well, there was a link in your document to the COVID-19 positive case tracker, the school testing consent forms, the at-home testing consent forms, the vaccine clinics that were offered throughout this school year, and an additional reference to school counseling presentations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: support presentations under equity, which we continued to champion equity in its true sense of the word, providing all students with access to district opportunities to ensure individual student success.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so under equity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We talked about the professional development, which I mentioned to you earlier, and we continue to have the work of our race equity task force.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we have NWEA map.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and we are conducting the human resources audit, our equity audit through the equity process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those are initiatives that the Medford Public Schools has been working on in addition to my being a part of the statewide mass ready group, which is racial equity, diversity and inclusion initiative.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was part of that pilot group through the state.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under consistency, NWEAMAP is the district's way of having an informal assessment system where we gather data at the district level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And by gathering data at the district level, we are able to start looking at trends.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the first year that we have used NWEAMAP.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be making a presentation to the committee next month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on our data thus far with NWEA map, but we are looking forward to next fall's data to really have a full one-year cycle of where we were in the fall of 21 to the fall of 22 and use the fall of 22 data as our new baseline data where all of the kinks have kind of been worked out and we're able to, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: start using our in-house data in a more consistent fashion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that's what we would say under consistency, trying to have academic consistency across the entire district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, our NWEA map data is district-wide, K-12, although we stop at like 10th grade, but at each level, elementary, middle, and high school, we are gathering common assessment data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is my information under the district improvement goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am going to transition to the student learning goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, I did transition and the student learning goal was on elementary literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: early literacy skills and implementing interventions in literacy to improve outcomes by deepening teacher and principal knowledge of early literacy practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the forms of evidence that support this goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We supported the development and the implementation of an effective early literacy program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We adhered to the department of elementary and secondary educations, DESE's dyslexia guidance through the implementation of the enhanced core reading instruction, our ECRI program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With ECRI, we are implementing during our tier one, it's being implemented district wide in our K-2 classrooms during our tier one English language arts instruction blocks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We continue to have a partnership with Hill for Literacy during the school year where feedback from the listening tour, the teachers were very, very complimentary and very happy about the quality of the professional development and the coaching that they were receiving.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they believe that it is really helping them to improve and grow their practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was something where we received extensive feedback and going through the classrooms, you can also see the implementation of ECRI.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even if I'm walking through not in a formal walkthrough, if ECRI is taking place, the teachers will say to me,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, come and see, I'm doing an ECRI lesson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that has happened when I'm there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they are really proud to really showcase what they've learned and what their students have learned using this consistent methodology.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, we are all using the NWEA map assessment tool.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, we're going to be looking at the middle of the year and end of year data, and finally having an in-house assessment system, which is truly, truly a remarkable feat, something that I'm very excited about.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although it wasn't listed as an official goal, I did wanna just provide a very brief update to the members that on elementary math, my first three years within the district, we were focusing, my student learning goal had been on mathematics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just wanted to update you that I am still committed to addressing elementary achievement in math.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that again, due to the pandemic, we were not conducting

[Edouard-Vincent]: learning walks, they were suspended, but where we are truly moving, getting to a better place, I am hoping for next year to be able to continue doing our rounds in the classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want to share with the members that this year, our math director, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Faiza Khan, worked with a task force and that Turk Investigations 3

[Edouard-Vincent]: was selected as the official new elementary math curriculum, and that this coming year, we will be piloting the integrated math pathway at the secondary level so that we are still keeping our focus on mathematics, although we are also looking at early literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do just wanna share that, and I've attached a few math resources there just for you to review them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After the student learning goal, my third goal was my professional practice goal, and my professional practice goal, which has been about the professional development that I participate in, I completed the full coursework through DESE of NISP, which was an intensive three-year program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the end of our third year, DESE offered superintendents who were graduating from the program, the opportunity to participate in a fourth year of NSEP.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I did take advantage of that opportunity for continued learning to work with a smaller cohort of superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I participated in the professional development sessions and working on problems of practice and working with a focus on what equity looks like within the different districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is a lengthy narrative that kind of explains what equity looks like

[Edouard-Vincent]: what some of the work look like of what I was doing with NISAP in addition to NISAP's fourth year extension.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also participated in the Massachusetts REDI group and the REDI, R-E-D-I

[Edouard-Vincent]: stands for Racial Equity Diversity and Inclusion Group.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was the pilot cohort group for Massachusetts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it consisted of 24 superintendents, assistant superintendents, and directors of equity throughout the Commonwealth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 12 of them identified as BIPOC individuals of color.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and 12 of the superintendents or white superintendents and this pilot group was giving superintendents and assistant superintendents this opportunity to come together as two groups as one whole group and then we would separate

[Edouard-Vincent]: into affinity groups to really tackle issues of racial equity diversity and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And today was our eighth session meeting throughout the year and I participated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in all sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And at today's session, they said they would be reaching out to us next month to let us know what the extension would look like for next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The work that we did as a pilot group is going to be offered again throughout the Commonwealth to other superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the feedback that we gave being part of this pilot group is going to help inform

[Edouard-Vincent]: the work that's going to continue to happen across the Commonwealth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You will be hearing about much more guidance from the Department of Elementary and Secondary Ed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: DESE is going to be giving clearer instructions and support resources for districts to use when working with topics of racial equity,

[Edouard-Vincent]: diversity, and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The third professional development group that I was tapped on the shoulder to be part of is the New England Multistate Leading Now Cohort.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, this is another cohort of superintendents from Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this work has just started, so I am halfway, not quite halfway through.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The work will continue next year as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and helping us really see what states, different states are going through and how to support our districts first and foremost with issues around racial equity, diversity, and inclusion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Most recently, they did share some additional resources with all of the superintendents regarding the tragedy that had taken place in Buffalo last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is another professional learning community where I am receiving training and participating actively and gathering information that I'm able to bring back to the district and use to better inform my leadership here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next portion of the report,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm on page six is essentially talking about the four standards that are recommended by DESE.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I've listed and I've cited under instructional leadership, standard one, several pieces of evidence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But under instructional leadership, again, many of the things I mentioned earlier, and also citing school committee documentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, this year, being fortunate to have a superintendent in residence, and providing instructional leadership there as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under standard two,

[Edouard-Vincent]: which is management and operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, one of the key pieces that we did as a district was the submission of the application to the MSBA and trying to maintain an even more transparent budget process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those were two key highlights, which I listed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: under management and operations under category three family and community engagement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, continuing to maintain weekly communications with the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We

[Edouard-Vincent]: had our first full year with the engagement hub, continuing to work with our race equity task force, participating in Women's History Month celebrations, the Lunar New Year celebration, Haitian Flag Day celebration,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The middle school lottery process, we had middle school open houses that were in person this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kindergarten open houses that were able to be in person.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are many, many things participating in department head meetings, which take place at the city hall level, but really trying to be well rounded.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But again,

[Edouard-Vincent]: focusing on communicating with parents weekly and meeting with parents and interacting with parents when possible at in-person events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, there were a few things from a community engagement perspective, supporting the stand with Ukraine event that took place, our Arbor Day celebrations, many of our CCSR initiatives,

[Edouard-Vincent]: participating in the legislative breakfast where many of you members were able to participate in that at the West Medford Community Center, participating in the Martin Luther King Day event, participating in District Attorney Ryan's Cut It Out program, and events to come next week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A high school graduation on June 1, and many other senior events senior prom at the end of this week, and award ceremonies taking place this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, for number four under professional culture.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, I listed the superintendent's listening tour and I listed many other documents and supporting initiatives, but the listening tour really gave me an opportunity to hear from educators and from staff to just see, get feedback in an informal way and just see and hear what

[Edouard-Vincent]: stakeholders would like to see more of and hear more of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in closing, I just want to share that I am fully committed to the work that I am doing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am committed to ACES achievement, collaboration, equity, and support and safety as the four guiding pillars that are the basis of my educational leadership as an educator,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I believe in the achievement and academic outcomes of all of our students and as this graduation season is upon us and our seniors are moving on to college and careers, I want to stress the importance of academic achievements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for all of our learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am pleased, and I said it before, that next year we will have nearly 600 students participating in vocational programming, which is showing that there is a shift happening in Medford, but we need to be prepared for that shift because participating in vocational programming does not mean that you cannot go to college.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If anything, it enhances and means that you can have a trade

[Edouard-Vincent]: And you can also continue on to college and be fully well rounded.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in order to continue the work of leading this district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I must say that it cannot be done without the support of a team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wholeheartedly thank the support of my senior leadership team and the administrators who manage all the schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This takes collaboration and coordination of teams, administrators, teachers, and staff to create the best learning environments for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I thank them for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's my C of ACES.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the goal of meeting the needs of all learners must be done through the lens of equity, which I talked a lot about today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It doesn't mean giving all students the same things, but giving each student what they need to keep learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Equity is not limited to race, but it is a fully inclusive term that embraces all of our unique characteristics, such as learning styles,

[Edouard-Vincent]: language needs, religious affiliations, gender and sexual identities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is our diversity that makes us stronger.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, support and safety are key pillars to meeting the diverse needs of our population.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although the pandemic is now being referred to as an endemic, the effects of COVID-19 will remain with us for the foreseeable future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is incumbent upon us to keep our community whole and supported in every way possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In closing, I am proud to be your superintendent, and I am incredibly grateful to be a member of the Medford Public Schools community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With all of the societal pressures and plagues that our world is encountering, I will use my position to make this district a better place for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I believe in Medford Public Schools, and we are Medford Strong.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Despite all of the great things going on in Medford schools, I unfortunately must open my remarks tonight by expressing sadness and grief over this past weekend's mass shooting in Buffalo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now designated a hate crime, the tragic killing of 11 and wounding of two at the supermarket reminds us all that racism and gun violence are scourges facing our nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Targeting a supermarket in a predominantly black neighborhood, the gunman replicated tragic acts that have become far too familiar to all of us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know teachers and Councilors are working hard with our students to deal with the emotional trauma caused by this terrible event.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although our nation aspires to goals of equity and inclusion, events such as this remind us of so much that has to be done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The students and staff of Medford Public Schools are striving to achieve these goals on a daily basis and are committed to eliminating discrimination of all kinds in our society.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I kindly request a moment of silence for those viciously lost in Buffalo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to share some updates from what's going on in the district and definitely take a more positive note.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mayor?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Dr. Williams, I am proud to call her Dr. Williams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dr. Williams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nope.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I just want to say thank you for the credit for life and thank you to, again, all the volunteers and community partners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is an excitement or energy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was surprised at how quickly the apps allowed the students to go through all of the stations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I am hoping, I think it's such a great learning activity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when the students did respond and say like, your credit score is everything.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I said to them, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that's not only just now, it's for the rest of your life.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your credit score is very, very important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I felt like it was such a great aha learning moment for them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I hope that we're able to continue doing the credit for life.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if possible, do it for juniors and seniors so they have the opportunity to do it junior year and then senior year before they go off to college or their careers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was, I think, a great learning experience for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I had the opportunity to talk with member Graham about this, and I welcome the conversation and the discussion with the committee to be able to get an idea of what the committee members are thinking about for the following school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I did share that it's critically important to take time over the summer months to look at our data, to reflect as a team, to regroup,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and be able to make data informed decisions about what our priorities are going to be, whether it's a district improvement goal or the student learning goal.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that it's the data that comes over the summer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, embargo data that comes right at the end of the summer and into September.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the September 30th date, that will give us time to at least have a good amount of new data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to feel more confident in the recommendations that are being made to the committee by that date.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it is in keeping in agreement with many other districts, because I did consult with other superintendents to figure out what timetable they were on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And most of them said September, October, they submit their goals for the year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I look forward to that discussion next month with you all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today, we're going to start off our day two for budget, and we have another set of presentations today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We'll be hearing from our assistant superintendents on specific initiatives, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Galussi and Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When I met with Mr. Fallon and saying like, what are the numbers, what do we think will be our Medford numbers in another two years time?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with 1300 students at the high school, it's possible that we could end up with 7, 8, 900 students wanting to participate in vocational programming, the excellent programming that is happening right now, and possibly bringing on other programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it is something that we know we need to work on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Muslims believe that the past year sins are forgiven, good deeds are multiplied, and prayers are answered.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Eid Mubarak, which means may God flood your lives with happiness, your heart with love, your soul with spirituality, your mind with wisdom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Every year we have to report to Desi and take an official vote and so I'm coming before you, your body this evening again, asking that Medford continue to maintain their status as a no school choice district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'm asking for your support with this.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford has a lot of diversity of population and students here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I feel that we truly are doing the best we can do to service our current community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so my recommendation would be that we remain a no school choice district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you're a school choice district, you receive other, you're able to receive students from other communities and other districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there are a lot of some districts that are school choice districts, but I think with the complexities that we have here in Medford, our current population.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have, I feel that we definitely have our hands for servicing the population that we have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when you're a school choice district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You're not able to pick some students and not pick others.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So once you have that status.

[Edouard-Vincent]: people are welcome to apply, and you don't always know what may happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I think just for where we are as a district, it is not in our best interests to become a school choice district at this point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Every year I have to bring it before your body, but I would kindly request that you support the fact that we're a no school choice district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As of yet, to my knowledge, I don't believe that that has happened yet because it's still in a draft phase, but I would definitely say when we have

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, the more corrected version presented to this body.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this body has an opportunity to kind of see it in action and, you know, give feedback.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And maybe as that particular meeting is coming up, maybe to spend a little more time saying to families as well, please jump on this particular subcommittee meeting because we're going to be piloting or doing a demonstration of our new website that's expected to come

[Edouard-Vincent]: in the summer of 22, and we're looking for feedback and create, you know, use this platform as an opportunity, or from that presentation, create, you know, an additional opportunity to get feedback and have people, you know, look at it and see the interface and say like, oh, this is excellent, or, oh, don't forget about something to consider.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Is there a way to add X, Y, or Z before we try to take it live?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So definitely open to that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to receiving additional feedback, definitely open to it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for languages, it definitely will be able to be translated into multiple languages.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I'll say a little spoiler alert.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was trying to keep some surprises, but I was really excited by the draft presentation that we got to see and the significant progress that was made.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is a plan to actually try to slowly roll out

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, multiple ways of communicating and where you were talking about accessibility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Not everyone has a computer or a desktop where they have access to that all the time, but almost everyone does have a good old cell phone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One, if not two, if you're lucky.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we are definitely, this new platform will also have a component that is cell phone

[Edouard-Vincent]: friendly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So from an accessibility in terms of access where, you know, I'm sure 97% of our community has access to a cellular phone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm sure that not only parents and caregivers, but also students, especially at the secondary level, because I know some elementary students may not have cell phones, but for our students as well, they would be able to download the app

[Edouard-Vincent]: and have the downloaded app version of the website available so that they would be able to receive feeds and, you know, important pieces of information related to the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there is, um, you know, I gave a little bit of a spoiler alert but there are definitely a lot of

[Edouard-Vincent]: additional functionality that isn't available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also had asked about the text messaging option, which is critically important.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When we just, you know, got off of the April break and

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, I got an alert for my child to just say don't forget to conduct your rapid testing it's Sunday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So something as simple as that a very, very brief text message that wouldn't take up that much space, but just another way for

[Edouard-Vincent]: know to communicate with families it would be one-sided but it would just be oh remember this is happening in your building or this particular event is happening so really hoping to eventually get to that level of functionality where it doesn't only have to always be an email but you know all the time we're checking our text messages because we get a little alert and using that functionality again to

[Edouard-Vincent]: be able to communicate with parents on timely events, not oversaturate their text message inbox with a million messages a day, but those particular messages where you may want to say, here's a little reminder, and you see it and you're like, oh yeah, I need to do this.

[Edouard-Vincent]: communicate with them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we definitely are in agreement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do feel the direction that we're moving in is really going to put us in a much stronger position to provide accessibility, language translation, and keep our families informed, and up to date on what's happening in the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to pass the baton on to Mr. Murphy, who has been lead on this portion of the project.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Murphy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, President Morell and honorable body.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We thank you for your support of this MSBA application, our statement of interest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, our high school is in serious need of repair and renovation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are hoping that with your support, we will be able to

[Edouard-Vincent]: This time be approved by MSBA to be considered for renovation, or how can I say it, a new high school to be able to be built for us here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's our statement of interest and we are asking MSBA to approve us for the core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we explained statutory priorities number five and number seven.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those are the two key areas that we are requesting that MSBA consider for Medford High School's core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know if you have a question.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Statutory priority number five is regarding replace, renovate and modernize the school facility systems, including the roofs, windows, boilers, heating and ventilation to increase and improve energy conservation and decrease energy related costs in a school facility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And statutory priority number seven was replacement of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to obsolete buildings in order to provide for a full range of programs, consistent with state and approved local requirements.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm gonna ask Mr. Murphy to come give some of the specifics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Assistant Superintendent of Finance and Operations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If MSBA was gonna give me one thing, it would be that they would approve our petition to go for the core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the past, sometimes we've also attempted to go for the accelerated repair program where they just focus on a small section of the high school and repair a small section, but I think right now where the building is over 50 years old.

[Edouard-Vincent]: there are so many areas that are just starting to show their age and it wouldn't be to just go and focus on one area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We need to really fix the entire structure from bathrooms to leaks to the pipes bursting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So my wishlist would be that MSBA approves us for the core program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It takes a very long time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So from this point to actually

[Edouard-Vincent]: Having something done could take anywhere from eight to 10 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There were many, many steps, but we do need to start somewhere.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And right now the building's 50 years old.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If it were to take a full 10 years, the building would then be 60 plus years old.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that would be my wish that we would be approved, receive full approval from MSBA.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think one other piece that people need to be aware of as well when we merge both high schools, the vocational side and the comprehensive side.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We now have about 45% enrollment on the vocational side of the house the CTE side.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we currently have 15 programs there but there are other programs that we would like to offer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to really give our students the greatest opportunities and again the limitations with the physical plant that would limit us from doing being able to offer some of additional programming for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I really feel like if MSBA

[Edouard-Vincent]: If your body approves our application and MSBA receives our statement of interest and allows us to move on to the next phase, it will allow us to really keep Medford out in front of the eight ball and really giving our students the greatest opportunities possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you so much.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you to the team as well who worked on putting everything together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mr. Murphy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and all the others that worked.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, I think the report actually details many, many of the things that need addressing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the fact that the building is not air conditioned, and sometimes we have very hot summers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a lot of things that our students graciously put up with, but we know it's not easy for them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is our hope to give our students the best quality education

[Edouard-Vincent]: in the best facility possible if we are granted by MSBA and by your body to move forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I humbly request your support with this statement of interest application.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to open my remarks this evening by acknowledging that many members of the community are here to voice their opinions and concerns about a personnel matter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, I have received email communication as well, and I have responded that I am legally obligated to maintain confidentiality when it comes to personnel records.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All human resource personnel matters are confidential, and neither I nor any member of the school committee are able to respond to any questions or comments regarding personnel.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank you in advance for your understanding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The COVID update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This morning, the Medford Public Schools Health Services Department notified our team that events involving Medford students that occurred outside of school were likely places of COVID-19 transmission.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Due to the extenuating circumstances surrounding these events, our team of school nurses have engaged in contact tracing specific to these events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do have evidence of a slight uptick in positivity concentrated at our secondary level, and we will continue to monitor these events to defend against any type of surge.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I remind you as always to participate in the DESI-sponsored rapid testing program to help to continue to put the pandemic behind us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, on Wednesdays here at City Hall, there will be vaccination clinics happening in our Board of Health on Wednesdays from two to six, this Wednesday, April 13th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the shots that are available are Moderna for 18 plus and Pfizer for 12 plus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First shot, second shot and booster shots are available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Only 25 people have registered thus far.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please pre-register so that your medication can be reserved.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, history is all around us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we come upon the Patriots Day holiday, we know Medford played an integral role in the American Revolution and is actually mentioned in the now famous Longfellow poem, The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We remember how groups of minutemen came from neighboring towns to line up at Concord and Lexington to face at the time, the strongest empire in the world, the British Army.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This description sounds eerily similar to what is happening now in the Ukraine.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Colonial America wanted to live in freedom from Britain, and clearly Ukraine would like to remain free from Russian influence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lessons from the past can often teach us lessons about the present and future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: History is all around us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week, we were able to witness the appointment of the first African-American woman, Judge Katanja Brown Jackson, to the United States Supreme Court.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Judge Jackson is the first, but hopefully not the last, African-American woman to grace the court.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Her appointment may have taken 232 years, but as Judge Jackson stated, we made it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our children see that in America, anything is possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Khan with us here this evening as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: a truly collaborative process that working together they came and made this decision and i look forward to seeing how the district does with investigations three knowing that so many voices were able to contribute to the final decision so thank you for all your hard work regarding that thank you thank you and i i am truly grateful to all the teachers it was a it was a

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, I just wanted to say thank you to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Galusi and Dr. Cushing for pulling, and also Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bowen for pulling all of this, all of the summer programming together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you can see, there is a lot going on and member Graham, we are making a serious effort to try to communicate early so that people can start thinking about all of the options that are gonna be available as they're beginning to plan for the summer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanna say thank you for all the hard work

[Edouard-Vincent]: bringing everything into one presentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when you look at it collectively, you realize that we really are offering a lot for our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you to the both of you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For this presentation, during the month of March, I embarked on a listening tour.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this is going to be kind of a high level overview of what transpired during this listening tour.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the journey I took, it started in the month of March.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I embarked on a listening tour within the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I wanted to say in light of all of the adjustments and changes that we had to make as we navigated through the pandemic, it truly would not have been prudent to conduct business as usual.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yet instruction was taking place every day in all of our classrooms and schools were up and running.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in my continued pursuit of system coherence and the implementation of our strategic plan, the time was right to gather information about what was happening in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So how did it come about?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Drawing upon the research work that my superintendent resident, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Carmen Williams was working on, building upon the administrative professional development that took place this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I implemented portions of the coaching conversation guide, which was a protocol that we used on professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But in addition to that, we spent a significant amount of time this year looking at data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Street data, map data, satellite data, all different forms of data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And this was the book that was used.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in this particular book, which is a great resource, Street Data by Shane Saphir and Jamila Duggan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It also talked about the power and the importance of listening and listening being an important tool.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as I embarked on this journey, I kept in mind, empathy, I hear you, equity, I see you, collaboration, I am with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, data matters, but alternative data also matters.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Standardized assessments don't always tell the whole story.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our stories matter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And with that, I think about self, social emotional learning in general for adults as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the five tenets of social-emotional learning, you've seen this wheel before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This was taken from the castle out of Chicago.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The five tenets of social-emotional learning are self-management, responsible decision-making, relationship skills, social awareness, and self-awareness.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of those five spokes

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thus far, I have spoken with about 101 educators within the district, teachers, paraprofessionals, librarians, all different special educators, English learning teachers, specialists, all across the district in all of the different schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to meeting and listening to teachers and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also had conversations with principals and administrators, and at this point in time, I have met with 20 of them to have

[Edouard-Vincent]: conversations with them about problems of practice and saying, what's a challenge that you're facing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's work together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's think together about this possible problem of practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's troubleshoot together and see if we can come up with solutions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sometimes we could, sometimes we couldn't, but again, it was an opportunity to listen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I went on this journey,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am including here a few quotes that kind of jumped out at me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Teacher said, I love ECRI.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want math professional development to be like ECRI.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One point person to come to model in my classroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another teacher said, we want someone to work with us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is going to be a new program, and they were referring to math, having a point person with expertise in an area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another said, responsive classroom block is really working.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In another building, our school adjustment Councilor is amazing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Eleni, who's a professional developer with ECRI, the teacher said, it's the best PD

[Edouard-Vincent]: ever for them and they loved the coaching with the Zooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Others said, bring back the joy, bring the joy back.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's a great day to be a Mustang.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they wanted t-shirts to be made for all the students to say, it's a great day to be a Mustang for next school year because they feel like the pandemic has exhausted all of us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Other teachers asked for more teacher led professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There's really this thirst for teachers designing to work collaboratively together to learn from one another, even a suggestion of being able to go and visit.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when I was at the middle school, one of the teachers suggested, can we go up to ninth grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: do professional development, see what's happening in ninth grade and come back and say, oh, this is how we can make adjustments to practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So teachers gave wonderful examples, their best thinking and just different ways of looking at how we can improve the district and make a difference for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another teacher said, we need more support, training and grace.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Asking us to really keep that in mind because we've been working in a pandemic and there are a lot of unknowns that we had to experience and go through.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But that was something that had just jumped out at me when it was said.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another session, they said, bring back book groups.

[Edouard-Vincent]: bring back professional learning communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it was something where if I think about key themes, professional development ended up really surfacing as an area, Dr. Cushing, could you please advance?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Professional development really surfaced as an area that

[Edouard-Vincent]: Teachers want to continue learning, learning in different ways, learning from strong educators and quality professional development and having opportunities to learn from one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was definitely a theme that that surfaced.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Teachers talked about self social emotional learning and working with students and trying to meet the needs of students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as I had mentioned again responsive classroom and those kinds of things that we were being very intentional about to meet the needs of our students, bringing back the joy, because there were so many rules and regulations during the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: masks shields sanitizer, you know distance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so finally kind of getting back to some sense of normalcy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that kind of came through like they're, they're ready to bring back the joy for the students and get back to some sense of normalcy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Teachers did ask for more support as we think about the structure of the district, thinking about our growing EL population, students with disabilities, Councilors, to make sure that we keep those resources in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And additional staffing, like this year with the pandemic, sometimes we had some positions that still were not filled despite having them posted for months.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so thinking about, oh, I wish if there's a possibility to have more staffing, if we could have an additional paraprofessional or something like that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that was just something that also kind of surfaced.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I just wanted to point that out as some of the key themes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I really wanna just also say thank you right now, a special thank you to all the staff that were part of the listening tour.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanna say that your willingness to share, be transparent, be vulnerable, and provide feedback to me was greatly, greatly, greatly appreciated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your voice matters and it counted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in closing, I just wanted to say there was one final slide, Dr. Cushing, homage to you, Dr. Cushing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I ended with saying that to the teachers that were in staff and administrators that were part of the listening tour, that I am your proud superintendent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And yes, indeed, it is a great day to be a Mustang.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was really, in that particular quote, it was a group of students, not a group of students, it was a clustered group of teachers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because during the listening tour, I met with some people one on one, and we tried to have no groups, no larger than four.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it was, you know, they were talking about support, time to learn the new curriculum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think, Grace, in the sense of like we're bringing on new programming, we just went through all of this adjustment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please keep in mind that as we're getting the training, we need support, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and just keeping grace in mind so that it's not like you're pounding them over the head and saying, here's 500 more things to learn all at once.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But to really think about saying, OK, this is the next initiative that we're going to do.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So many of them were involved, especially in the math pilot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know depending on which program they were piloting so that also the feedback of like oh I did this one and this is the one we're going to go with we know we're going to go through training and that it was it was it's one thing to know that equity professional development is quality PD but to have so many of them in different buildings

[Edouard-Vincent]: echo the feedback that it was some of the best professional development that they've ever had.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for us as a district to try to mimic that type of professional development moving forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when I think of that statement, I put it all together in the context of the greater conversation that was happening at that moment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But that was just a statement that I appreciated the vulnerability

[Edouard-Vincent]: of the teacher to kind of say it, but say like, you know, give us the support and the time to learn these new programs and adjust, you know, to the changes, but, you know, continuing to do the work that needs to happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mayor.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, school committee members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So good evening, this is your proud superintendent sharing some updates for the week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For the previous two weeks that we haven't met the past two weeks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we meet tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today, March 31.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And today is World Down Syndrome Awareness Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's a global awareness day officially observed by both the United Nations and the World Health Organization.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today, being the 21st of the third month, it was selected to signify the uniqueness of the trisomy of the 21st chromosome, which causes down syndrome.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The theme this year, which is selected by the United Nations is hashtag inclusion means.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which empowers everyone to be able to advocate for equal rights for people with Down syndrome and reach out to stakeholders to bring about positive change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, this is being recognized globally today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as I had shared in my communication last Friday, you can wear a brightly colored top.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm wearing a multicolored necklace and I have different socks on my feet.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in support in collaboration of those who have down syndrome.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, the theme of this year was inclusion means, and just for us to be able to take a moment to reflect on what does inclusion mean to us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also wanted to share with our community that our parents and caregivers, this is an important announcement regarding your tax credits.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you don't normally file a tax return, but you're eligible for the child tax credit, you can still claim the child tax credit on your 21 tax return, even if you had no income during the entire year of 2021.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there were advanced payments that were made in 2021, but they were not the full amount of the credit.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the 2021 child tax credit is 3600 for each qualifying child under the age of six.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and 3000 for each child between the ages of six and 17.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for further information, you can go to the IRS website, which is irs.gov slash child tax credit for more information.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The color speaks of serenity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Respectful, responsible, and safe.
