[Edouard-Vincent]: So let me start with that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a lot of wonderful invited guests who are here to celebrate you, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette Vanderclute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do give a root for Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Vanderclute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So let me start this journey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for coming to join us today, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For 32 years,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The superintendent of the Medford Public Schools has enjoyed the counsel, support, and supervision of someone who has come to embody public service in this community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For 32 years, the teachers and staff of the Medford Public Schools have enjoyed the presence, enthusiasm, and loyalty of someone who afforded this city her time, energy, and leadership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The parents and caregivers of Medford's children and young adults have had a voice in the governance of their children's school system because of someone who has continually put the needs of her community before her own.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For 32 years, the residents of Medford have enjoyed access to their city school system through a representative who has worked to make this school system liable of the great community we serve.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For 32 years, the students of the Medford Public Schools have benefited from an elected official whose sole focus has been working to build a school system that will position them for success, achievement, and fulfilling lives.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And for the last four years, as the city superintendent of schools, I have enjoyed the friendship, guidance, and mentorship of the person whose service we honor tonight, Mrs. Paulette Vander Kloop.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette here is from Illinois, Illinois.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Coming here to study at Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 41 years ago, she married Bob Vandercroft, also a Medford transplant.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And together they raised three daughters, Katie, Megan, and Liz, each of whom are Mustang alumni.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Starting with her work with the Medford-Holman School Association, Paulette's support for the district has been steadfast.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette was elected 32 years ago, the day after giving birth to her youngest daughter, with a famous slogan of, give a hoot, vote for Vanderkoop, which resonated with this community for the next three decades.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She personified that slogan by supporting every Mustang sport, activity, and club the district had to offer.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette's vision for the school system was one that served the whole child and every child.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Through her advocacy of the arts, early education programs, and so much else, we are a district that is much closer to that vision than we would have been without her leadership and service.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so tonight, we say thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know we could not fit in one room all the people who want to say thank you, but the following guests are with us both to say thank you and as representatives of everyone else who Paulette has worked with in all of the good work they have done together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Former superintendents of schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have former superintendent of schools, Dr. Phil DeVoe.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Former superintendent of schools, Roy Belson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Former assistant superintendent of schools, Beverly Nelson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Former assistant superintendent of schools, Diane Caldwell.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to ask Mr. Roy-Belson, who has a few words to share, to please come forward at this time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to now recognize some of our former school committee members who are here in the audience with us today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have Patty Brady, Jack Buckley, former Build in the Future project manager, Emily Cuno, Ellen DiBenedetto, Fred Lasky, who is the current director of Massachusetts Water Resource Authority,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ed Nolan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have Beth Fuller, also here as a former school committee member.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I would like to ask Beth Fuller to please come forward to share a few words with us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm holding on to it just in case.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is my poet, which has been in my yard, not all year long, but just during the election season, and then also held at polling places for many years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I first met Paulette probably around 1989.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We were standing outside the Dame School at pickup time, and I probably stood out because I had a backpack with a child in it, a double stroller with two grandchildren, and then probably one or two others moving on, because I was a daycare provider at the time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And you said to me, gee, you don't really want to get involved in the things that are going on around the city.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And no, maybe you might want to run for school committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, that was gobsmacking.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And a few years later, I did.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we served together for six years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the time that we started on school committee, there were 11 elementary schools, three middle schools, and three high schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Most principals had two schools under their care, and inevitably, when things went wrong,

[Edouard-Vincent]: They weren't at that school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Instead, it was the school secretaries who held things together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And one of the very important lessons we learned was that you had to make friends with the school secretaries and the custodians, because they knew everything.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they were very discreet, but they were very good buddies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At that time, there were no cell phones.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, our families quickly learned that if you picked up the phone, you had to take a message, because otherwise, we would never know who called.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Generally speaking, the families left the phone alone and just walked away from it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there were no computers, no laptops.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was no social media, no Google.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we kind of did the best we could to get people together to meetings with handouts, with phone calls, just nabbing people outside school buildings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The nice thing was that when you went on vacation, you left it at behind.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It didn't have to come with you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was very nice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: you, Paulette, helped to support the kindergarten aides because Medford had one of the very few extended day programs for kindergarten students at that time that was free.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was no charge for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of the other districts around us charged for extended day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford did not.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The kindergarten aides were critical to making sure that the kindergarten teacher was able to make it through the day and go to the bathroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Harmon School Association became the Medford Educational Foundation eventually, or migrated to that, and you were there for that as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The parent involvement across the district has only increased in the years since then.

[Edouard-Vincent]: People really do know one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Facebook has made that possible, yes, but it's been largely because we were able to consolidate our schools, even though it meant the loss of our beloved Hervey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we understood that the little schools that we had did not have

[Edouard-Vincent]: They didn't have, for instance, cafeterias, kids ate in the classroom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They didn't have gyms, a lot of them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They didn't have a large meeting space for the school to gather.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They did not have elevators, and we didn't realize how many parents and students were not able to enter those buildings on the first day of school until we built the new schools and saw that for ourselves.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first day the books opened, we had two parents in wheelchairs who never, ever would have been able to share the first day of school with their children.

[Edouard-Vincent]: until we built those schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Think how heartbreaking it was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They were never able to meet with the teacher in the classroom their child was in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We did that with the new schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You've been around long enough to see the effects of the change from MCAT to MCAS.

[Edouard-Vincent]: From every form and the effects on school committee governance, it changed dramatically during that time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The rise of charter schools, all of our new schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's been an incredible ride.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you both for taking us down memory lane.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also this evening we have representatives from our school buildings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, Paulette, you see each of our individual schools as communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And like all communities, they require investment and care.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You have modeled that for each of us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At this time, to begin our presentation, I would like to ask the representatives from our schools to come forward to offer some tokens of appreciation, which will be presented

[Edouard-Vincent]: by two individuals who have worked with Paulette for a long time for a significant portion of our service.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our former Associate Superintendent Diane Caldwell and Principal Paul DeLeva.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would also like our other Principals and Administrators who are here to please come forward and represent the Administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have Chad Fallon here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have Diane Garino, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Shannon Demos, Dr. Kathy Kaye, Doreen Andrews, Nancy Sherman-Hudson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Administrators, you can come forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you so much.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I hope I didn't miss anyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's going to be a little crowded up here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So Paulette, it is my pleasure and my honor to say a few words about a person that I've known and admired for many, many years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You have been the anchor of the school committee for 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your knowledge of education and incredible love for the children and families of Medford has always been front and center.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your commitment and dedication to the medical school committee and community has been extraordinary in my estimation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I cannot remember you missing any school committee meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Maybe there was one or two, but I was here every other week and you were as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You were diligent about making sure you read the packets.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Remember those old-fashioned packets we had?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Big folders.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there were occasions when you would stop by the high school at four or five o'clock at night when we were still working on them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we said, can I have mine now?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because you needed to start reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You didn't want to miss a thing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You've been a supporter of the arts for as long as I can remember.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it was so appropriate tonight that they were here to give you a Christmas send off.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If I could speak on a personal note for a moment, as a teacher and administrator, I have always felt comfortable seeking out your opinion and advice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We didn't always agree, but you were always very respectful and understanding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it's very bittersweet for us on behalf of all of the principals and administrators that are here with us tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We thank you so much for all the years that you gave to Medford and we wish you and Bob and your whole family a long, healthy and happy retirement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you so much, administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would also, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Madam Superintendent, one moment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The principals would like to share with member Bandiclute some beautiful cards that the children have written.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also wanted to just thank the central office team that was just standing, all of the assistant superintendents, Galusi, Murphy, Cushing, Williams, and Vern.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The central office team sends great congratulations your way as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also with us this evening is someone who knows well both how challenging serving on a school committee can be and how unique it is for someone as talented as Paulette to be willing to do it for 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please welcome, from the Massachusetts Association of School Committees, Executive Director Glenn Coulter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please come forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Mr. Kuchar for joining us this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, I would like to thank our city councilor, Mr. Zack Beers, who's here with us this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many of our elected officials who could not be here in person, but wanted to send along their commendations to share those along with their thoughts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will now turn the floor over to Paulette's current colleagues with members McLaughlin and member Graham.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, you can tilt it in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They can hear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would now like to invite Member Ruseau forward to give remarks and present a citation from Representative Clark.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I would now like to invite member of the storm forward to make some remarks and to present a citation from our own governor Baker.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just asked Jenny to Google if Governor Baker was on the school committee, because I think he was.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you're right.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette, you can be governor next.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is from Governor Baker and Lieutenant Governor Perito.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in its form.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On behalf of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, I am pleased to confer upon you this Governor's citation and recognition of your 32 years of dedicated service as a member of the Medford School Committee to Paulette Van der Kloot the 20th day of December in the year 2021.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do just want to briefly say

[Edouard-Vincent]: that I've appreciated so much working with you for these past six years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Honestly, it's incredible the service you've given to the city of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't think anyone else in the city has given 32 years of their life or Bob's life.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to invite Member Kreatz up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She's going to present some remarks and a citation from Senator Markey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and you will be missed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I almost want to do a drum roll because, uh, yes, yes, yes, yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're going to have take the podium right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And, um, we have some special things to present governor Paulette.

[Edouard-Vincent]: whatever you choose in your retirement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Right, Dr. Cushing?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paulette Van Der Koeuw.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Given who?

[Edouard-Vincent]: No, I'm just kidding.

[Edouard-Vincent]: gratitude for 32 years of service to the method public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, member Van Der Kroot, you would put in a special request.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so that was the big, big one for you that you can read stories and enjoy when you go home.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But you put in a request a few years back, and I kept that special request in mind.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want you to know as I present you with this request, again, echoing the mayor's sentiments as well, that your contributions have been immeasurable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We don't want your contributions to stop, even though you are officially stepping down.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We value you very deeply.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And on the school side, we want you to know that we want you to continue to partner with us and provide counsel and guidance as a school committee member emeritus, as you had said to me the other day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I have a special gift that you made a special request for.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and I don't know if you recall, it says Paulette Vanderkoop, champion of our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford thanks you for 32 years of service.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so now, finally, I welcome you, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: van der Kroot, to come to the podium and share your remarks, your words with us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you again for your dedicated service of 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, it's a little bit like attending your own funeral, but you get to hear it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's really great.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I highly recommend it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One more citation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One more citation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bob, we have plenty of things now to wallpaper our house with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First, thank you for being with me tonight, either present here in City Hall or over Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In all my wildest dreams, I never expected to be speaking to a group of masked people or donning a mask myself.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am sure that over the years, especially in the earliest ones, there were times when certain people might have wished I was masked, or at least,

[Edouard-Vincent]: a little bit less loquacious, but let's face it, the job of a school committee person rests largely on words and the ability to persuade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Before I go on, I want to extend a warm welcome and congratulations to my successor, Sharon Hayes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sharon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I feel confident that you will bring your knowledge, insight, and thoughtfulness to the school committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will be cheering you on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you to Lisa Evangelista and Susie Weiss for your work, helping me put this evening together, and also for all of the assistance you've given over the years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So last week, a funny thing was happening at my house.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On two separate nights, we were awakened by our dog, Pippi, barking with great agitation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Something was up, including me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After I got her to quiet down, I heard it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hoot, hoot!

[Edouard-Vincent]: And ow!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Over and over, it was calling, hoot, hoot!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, you all know my slogan, and everybody's been reminded of it over and over, Give a Hoot the Underclute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And my owl appeared every two years without fail.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But if I had any doubts last week,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was clear the owls had come to reclaim my owl, and it was time for my owl and me to retire and go about other owly and other things.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've loved this work and all the things that have gone with it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Being connected to so many people of Medford, working with outstanding educational leaders, relishing the accomplishments of our students, some of which you heard tonight with the musical students, interacting with our very supportive legislative leaders, being part of the larger Massachusetts Association of School Committees, meetings with my colleagues,

[Edouard-Vincent]: many meetings with my colleagues, more meetings with my colleagues.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I guarantee you 800 numbers is not enough.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last March broke the all-time record with something like 45 meetings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By the way, some might think that the longest meeting held was one of the marathon meetings held in this time of COVID, but it was not.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Rather, the longest meeting I attended finished past 2 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in the morning, a budget meeting during the time of then Special Education Director Ernie Demos, a dedicated man far more worthy than I will ever be.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are so many people who I've had the great opportunity to work with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But before I acknowledge just a few, I promised myself I would not pull a Mike McGlynn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: See, Mayor McGlynn had the habit of making marvelous speeches, acknowledging many, and then leaving his family to the end.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then he would wrap up and then suddenly realize he had missed the most important people in the world, his family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I'm starting with my family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To my dear husband, Bob, the most patient man in the world, thank you for your continued support, your work on my many campaigns, your support as I ran out the door, leaving you with, at the time, our three young kids.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Then, thank you, fast forward, during the time of Zoom meetings for putting up with the tension that came with those meetings in our house.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And thank you for delivering those delicious dinners that was one upside to having meetings at home by Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bob, you're an incredible man and incredible support, and I love you dearly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you to my three daughters.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Kate, Megan, and Liz, who put up with their mom being on the school committee, which was a lot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Phone calls during dinner, going out shopping with mom only to have her stopped by a constituent, photo shoots for campaign literature, and we'll get to that in a bit.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that there was one upside in the early years when you were the very first to know about snow days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That doesn't happen anymore because everybody knows at once.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Being the child of an elected official is not easy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I love you, my sweet daughters, and thank you for your support and for choosing such fine partners in life, Dave Ryan, Todd Prokop, and Jamie VanderKloot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And of course, there are my three wonderful grandsons, Harry, who is eight, Charlie, who is five, and Ezra, who is four.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, hi.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Megan is here, and Liz and Jamie are here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Todd's home with Ezra.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they've all been so supportive.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am so fortunate to have had the help and support of my friends throughout the years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I credit my first win to two forces in life.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First, the very timely arrival of my daughter, Liz, who was born on my first election day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Liz.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, Peter, if I could ask you to turn on, will I be able to see what's up?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, this is... So the first one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is the first piece of election campaign literature I had.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You'll notice that there's only two children in it because that's Kate and Megan, because Liz was yet to be born.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you could go to the next one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There we are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And she wasn't born the day before election day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She was born on election day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There we go.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The next one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, here we are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And if you notice, this is the one I think that Peaches is in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Peaches was our first dog, and Peaches, well, frankly, more people knew Peaches than they knew me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, Mike McGlynn used to love a parade, and when we walked through the streets, Peaches would accompany us, and more people would shout out, Peaches, Peaches, than they would Paulette.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So anyway, that's why I included that one.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And is there one more?

[Edouard-Vincent]: That might be it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Oh, and this is fast forward to 2019 with my three grandsons now there.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So over the years, there's many more in between, but those were ones I wanted to show you tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am so fortunate to have the help and support of friends already I said that the second force was to my campaign manager, Dick O'Mara, who sadly has long left this world.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dick was a force of nature and a taskmaster.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nine months pregnant, and I was knocking on doors and giving a hoot.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to extend my thanks to Dick's wife, Gail, and his kids, Kathleen and Brian, who were so helpful in my early years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to other friends who have been so kind and supportive, in particular, my treasure and great friend, Dr. Laurie Davidson, who is with us tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And my wordsmith, David Locke, who sat with me as we painstakingly hammered out the right words for my campaign literature, and he's the photographer tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am very fortunate to have had the blessing of my director or boss at Winchester Hospital, Marie Johnson, also here tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when I skipped out to attend a function or run off to a meeting, and also thanks to my great co-workers Donna and Jillian, I am truly blessed to have a wide circle of loving friends and family who have always been supportive and there for me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've also been extraordinarily lucky to have so many reach out and thank me when I announced my retirement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many of you recounted specific times when I had been helpful to you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's meant the world to me, and I thank the citizens of Medford for your thoughtfulness and support, not only recently, but over 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a school committee member, I had the opportunity to work with school committee members from across Massachusetts in our professional organization.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is a real asset to members as it enables us to understand that the challenges our community face are so often shared.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to thank Glenn Kuchar and the staff of the MASC, as well as the great school committee members from across Massachusetts that I had the privilege to meet and work with.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd also like to thank our legal Councilor, Trinity Howard-Greenspan, who, like me, has been here forever.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During my tenure, I've had the privilege to serve with three Medford mayors, Mike McGlynn, Stephanie Muccini-Burke, and our current mayor, Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While there are differences among you, and after all, this is politics, some tension between you, you all have in common a deep commitment to our city.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am thankful that I've had the opportunity to work with all of you, and I've appreciated your leadership and devotion to Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd also like to mention that I think Medford is extraordinarily fortunate that our mayor serves as the head of the school committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This means that our mayors have been intimately aware of the goings on in our schools and the needs of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Personally, I think this has been a giant plus, and I hope it remains this way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've also had the privilege to work with a host of other school committee members over the years, some of which have graciously joined us tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some served years and years, others for a shorter duration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While I may have occasionally disagreed with you, we had a shared understanding that our work was dedicated to continuously working to improve the Medford public schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm going to call out all of their names to acknowledge their service and dedication.

[Edouard-Vincent]: those that have left us, Bill Brady, Lena DiGiantomaso, and Fred Pompeo.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And now my other colleagues, Mary Aliberti, Jimmy Giacomo, Fred Lasky, Carol Sharpton, Bob Scurry, Michael Marks, who is also leaving his elected role on the council, Jack Buckley, Bulldog Jack,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Paul Camuso, Ed Nolan, Beth Fuller, my friend and confidant, Sharon Gusek, another friend and confidant, Ron Vining, John Falco, who I also extend my congratulations to, George Scarpelli, Bill O'Keefe, Michael Ruggiero, Aaron Z. Benedetto, and Ann Marie Cuno, who once served as the president of the MASC.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and also to my current colleagues, Jenny, Kathy, Melanie, Mia, and Paul.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, I'd like to acknowledge and once again, thank you for the work of the Building the Future Committee, led by Rick Orlando and Tricia McDonough.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Of all the time I spent on the school committee, the period when we were deciding how to move forward with replacing our then current schools was one of the most productive and enjoyable of my tenure.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you to Tricia and Rick and all the members of the Building the Future Committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next is the really tough part.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Acknowledging and thanking all the dedicated teachers, staff, and administrators who have dedicated their careers to our children.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, thank you, thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've been lucky to be in your classrooms, in our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've attended so many events, concerts, and athletic competitions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've seen our staff and teachers supporting our kids.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in this time of COVID, so many have just been superheroes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank each and every one, every custodian, bus driver, paraprofessional, lunch mother, school nurse, cafeteria worker, librarian, IT professional, guidance Councilor, special education, administrative assistant, secretary, support staff, our dedicated afterschool staff members, staff of the Medford Family Network, Kids Corner, and of course, our teachers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a school committee member, ultimately, we get to know our principals, directors, and administrative members the most.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for all the reports you've brought to us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, maybe not those MCAS ones, because personally, I think purgatory is made of MCAS reports 24 hours a day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for all your leadership and thank you for being patient when the latest educational acronym needs clarification yet again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The world of education is filled with acronyms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To our assistant superintendents, both past and present, and those who are here, and I'm so grateful for Beverly and Diane and all you guys up here in the front row cheering section, thank you for your countless hours of work, your patience, and your dedication.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I've worked with three superintendents of school, Phil DeVoe, Roy Belson, and Dr. Maurice-Edouard Vincent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, the first thing I have to tell you is that nobody, Carmen, are you listening?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nobody, she's our intern, superintendent intern.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so she wants to be a superintendent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She's crazy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now, the first thing I have to tell you is that nobody should want these jobs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's tough.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know how superintendents do it, frankly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Everything they do, every decision they make, every conversation they have is under scrutiny.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Seven people elected by the public who may know something about education, or maybe not so much, get to weigh in on their performance all the time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good grief.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are on call 24-7.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They have to become experts on everything, including weather, and whether there is going to be enough snow to justify calling off school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Roy, for devoting 50 years of your life to the Medford Public Schools and for leading this district, for 23 of them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You started and guided so many great programs that are shining stars for Medford, including the Medford Family Network and the Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Maurice, thank you for stepping in and stepping up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your leadership since the beginning of COVID has been very strong.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You worked to get our students back in school at the earliest opportunity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Your guiding principles of ACE, achievement for all, collaboration for all, and equity for all, have guided your work and set the vision for our district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Edouard-Vincent, keep on going.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It takes a long time to thank a lot of people that you've worked with for 32 years.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for your kind indulgence.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In leaving, I have two words of wisdom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, let's say thoughts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For my colleagues, the toughest time I've ever spent on the committee was when we had to lay off teachers and staff who were truly valuable, but because of a national economic crisis, we could not sustain.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you spend the ESSER money, please take to heart the need to spend wisely so that in some future date, you are not facing a dire situation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, spend it for sure, but plan so that you put into place

[Edouard-Vincent]: but plan so that what you put into place can be maintained for the future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's going to be a huge challenge.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And lastly, this period in our community and in our nation has been tough.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The divisiveness has truly been heartbreaking.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While we cannot snap our fingers and fix the entire national divide, it is incumbent on every local elected official and each of us to listen to and work with all of our fellow citizens and constituents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's find a way to build bridges.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have the best students in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They have so much hope and promise.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You heard some of them tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank them and I thank all of you for your extraordinary opportunity I have had in being a member of the Medford School Committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now I'm going to finish with an inside joke, which some of you will understand and many of you won't, but

[Edouard-Vincent]: In honor of the late former athletic director, Bud Kelly, I have blue and white running through my veins.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, thank you all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Move toward the reading of the agenda.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Presentation of the public, seconded by?

[Edouard-Vincent]: All those opposed?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Number eight, we have new business for the Metro Public Schools COVID-19 weekly testing program will be implemented in the Kids Corner program to cover staff and children.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In light of the fact that these children are unable to be vaccinated at this time, testing will occur as many days of each week as necessary to ensure all children in the program are tested weekly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If some children are not participants of the program on the scheduled testing day, rapid tests can be used to supplement the normal testing program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And thank you Stacey for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, thank you, Stacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's really great news.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Before I begin with my comments, I must address incidents that have occurred at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As a school district, we have discussed repeatedly the pronounced social and emotional needs of our students coming off of such a long period of instructional disruption caused by the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are very aware that students cannot learn if they do not feel safe and supported.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As educators, it is our moral and professional obligation to cultivate an environment in which every student feels secure and ready to learn.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The most fundamental element of this culture that we are trying to build is a recognition that there is simply no place for violence in our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week's fights that occurred at Medford High School resulted in very understandable

[Edouard-Vincent]: and mostly constructive outcry from students who want to see change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are grateful to the many students who accepted an invitation to meet with our administrators and Councilors to begin discussing what steps we can take as a community to foster an environment grounded in support and respect.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This will not happen overnight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The work has begun and the process will continue until every student and staff member feel safe and comfortable at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are dedicated to this goal and we urge all in the Mustang community to work with us to help restore the normalcy we expect in all of our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as we continue

[Edouard-Vincent]: to tackle this, I ask our students to partner with us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you hear something,

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you see something, you need to say something to an administrator so that we can be a partner with you to address any challenges that might happen or a plan to happen later in the day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also put out a call to parents to partner with us because if you see something at home or you hear something,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We ask that you partner with us, call the school, speak with the principal or the Councilors and let us know how we can also support you so that together we can build a stronger community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those are my remarks on what has happened with last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do wanna continue to give you key updates regarding the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The first update is about our public health update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So turning our attention as we do every meeting to public health and COVID-19 related matters, this past week, coming out of the Thanksgiving holiday weekend, we saw a significant uptick in COVID-19 positivity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While our testing program had been returning a positivity rate under 1%, last week, in over 4,000 COVID tests, we returned a positivity rate of just under 4%.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While this was not necessarily surprising, it is a reminder of the need for continued vigilance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: especially during this holiday season when so many are gathering with loved ones for social occasions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I noted in my message to the community this past Friday, we have seen very strong participation in the vaccination clinics that the Board of Health and the Health Services Department facilitated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have an active discussions now with the Board of Health in the hope of organizing additional opportunities for our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: particularly those between the ages of five and 11, who just became eligible to become vaccinated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Saturday, December 11th, at the Andrews Middle School, from 9 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 1 p.m., we will hold the second dose clinic to complete the series for students that attended the November 20th clinic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Being vaccinated is the best way to fulfill the obligation we owe to one another to minimize COVID in our communities and keep our students in school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As many Medford public school staff members are aware, our employee daycare program, Kids Corner, has seen a COVID outbreak in recent days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Three of the five Kids Corner classrooms have been forced to quarantine due to COVID spread.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Daycare programs in our region and around the country have faced similar and greater challenges since the beginning of the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: with the age eligibility restrictions for the vaccine being what they are.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The need for heightened vigilance is substantial in programs like Kids' Corner.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We know that this has caused significant stress to our employees who rely on this service, as well as to parents of students whose teachers are affected.

[Edouard-Vincent]: vigilance will be critical to continued operations of kids corner, as it will for all components of our organization, as we continue to emerge from the pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do wanna say that I hope everyone had a safe and enjoyable Thanksgiving holiday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanted to take this moment to extend a special thank you to Bill and Sue Honeycutt of John Brewer's Tavern for hosting Medford and Malden football teams, coaches, cheerleaders, mayors, and both central administrations for the annual Thanksgiving luncheon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also want to extend a huge thanks to Dr. Cushing, Principal DeLava.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Athletic Director Maloney, Building and Grounds Director McLaughlin, Band Director Mizrelo, the Mustang Band, our cheerleaders, for presenting, I believe, the first ever outdoor pep rally for Thanksgiving.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By hosting it outside, it allowed us all to cheer on our football team safely.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For those who enjoyed the close game on Turkey Day, the Mustangs truly appreciated your support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although we did not prevail, it was a hard-fought game with the final score, Malden 12 and Medford 10.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Their show, The Force, earned them a score of 91.4 out of 100 from the judges at the competition in Reading.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on October 31st.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to start with a public health update.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we noted in the last two school committee meetings, I will be incorporating updates on public health and COVID-19 in my remarks going forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But of course, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hines, Mr. Murphy, and other team members are available to answer any questions you might have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Members, you've received our COVID-19 update memo in your email packets, and that document is also posted on the district website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We did see a slight uptick in positivity in last week's surveillance testing, after we had dropped a minuscule 0.37% the week before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our 1.54% positivity was reflective of both the concerning community-wide numbers and a cluster identified in a program unaffiliated with Medford Public Schools that our health services team immediately notified the Board of Health about last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Despite the uptick in positive cases, we were very happy to report

[Edouard-Vincent]: that we maxed out participation in our NPS students-only COVID-19 vaccination clinic that was held at the Andrews Middle School last Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Through our partnership with the Board of Health, we will be holding a second vaccination clinic for students ages five to 11 this coming Saturday, November 20th, from 9 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 1 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please be sure to sign up and we'll have additional communication about this event in the coming days.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It will be on the four-year side, so coming in through the main entrance, that is one piece of information for people to be aware of.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Finally, with respect to public health, today we issued a survey to both staff and parents and caregivers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The survey which I have referenced in my last few Friday updates to the community was commissioned by Tufts University, who as you know, they have partnered with us to have one of the most successful coven testing programs in the state.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The researchers at Tufts University are seeking to obtain data related to the barriers that districts faced in getting students back into school and how we can operate on a more equitable basis when it comes to COVID-19 and public health in general.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The surveys are voluntary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: of course, but all NPS community members are encouraged to participate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please check your email for that survey.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, being that November is the month of Thanksgiving, I have notes of gratitude to share with all of you tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A special thank you to the families of the five to 11 year old students who participated in a very successful COVID-19.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, that was held last Wednesday at the Andrews Middle School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nearly 300 students received their vaccinations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we also want to send out some special thank yous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First to the Medford Public Schools nursing team,

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is at the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please do not miss out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are looking for registered nurses, nurse practitioners, physician's assistants, and doctors who are authorized to administer shots to come out and help.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please reach out to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Avery Hines, our health services director at 781-393-2292.

[Edouard-Vincent]: or you can email her at ahines, H-I-N-E-S, at medford.k12.ma.us if you are interested in volunteering at the vaccination clinic this Saturday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also on this Saturday,

[Edouard-Vincent]: November is National Native American Heritage Month, which acknowledges the unique contributions made by our first Americans for the growth and establishment of the United States.

[Edouard-Vincent]: President Biden noted in the annual proclamation, we honor our Native American veterans and service members who have courageously served and continue to serve in our armed forces, including the brave Native American code talkers in World War I and World War II.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This month and every month, we honor the precious, strong, and enduring cultures and contributions of all Native Americans and recommit ourselves to fulfilling the promise of our nation together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, since we will not meet again before Thanksgiving,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to take this opportunity to wish all of our families an enjoyable holiday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the same time, Thanksgiving needs to be celebrated safely, and I am asking that all students, staff, and families rededicate themselves to our effective COVID prevention measures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is important that we remain vigilant in our COVID awareness as we go into the Thanksgiving holiday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Outside of school activities could greatly impact our exposure within school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please remember to wear a mask, meet with friends and family outdoors when possible, and stay home if you're feeling ill or recently exposed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in response to that,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The third bullet about whereas hiring practices in many districts are finalized in March and April, it would be our desire to be able to be equally competitive with other districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A lot of the strongest candidates are scooped up right in the middle of whether they're new graduates, but they're scooped up much earlier than when we have access to trying to recruit competitive candidates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's going to take a lot, a lot of work for us to be able to move the timetable up, but I think it will put us in a stronger, more strategic position to be able to recruit stronger talent to bring to Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we will work hard to meet the new deadline, but in the end it will benefit us as a district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, it's tabled, and I will try to bring it forward at our next December meeting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tanya Sullivan and Alex Lorik and all the members of CPAC for their hard work and dedication to Medford CPAC.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, there will be no school Thursday, November 11th in observance of Veterans Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As my older brother, a career Army veteran often reminds me, Veterans Day is different from Memorial Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While these holidays both honor the military, there is a significant difference between the two.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Memorial Day honors the men and women who died while serving in the military.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It honors those who made the ultimate sacrifice in service to our country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Veterans Day honors all who served in the armed forces.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We thank all of our veterans, those serving, and those who have served for putting their personal lives on hold to protect the freedoms we all enjoy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, and as I report on my goals this evening, I will be reporting on the district improvement goal, our student learning goal, and our professional practice goal for the superintendent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Under the district improvement goal, given the unprecedented hybrid learning environment during the school year of 2020-2021,

[Edouard-Vincent]: MPS, Medford Public Schools, will utilize common systems and structures to accurately assess the learning and social emotional needs of students while addressing race, equity, diversity, and inclusion throughout the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, through professional development, observation and evaluation of staff, we will provide increased support to staff to better meet the needs of all learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our key goal of maintaining a learning environment built upon the pillars of safety, equity, and consistency, with the intention of developing a district-wide focus on instruction and assessment,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some of the key actions that are taking place this year have been the following professional development opportunities from social, emotional learning, professional development, implicit bias, professional development, responsive classroom, professional development, race, equity, diversity, and inclusion, professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: NWEA MAP, the Northwest Association Measures of Academic Progress Assessment System, and supervision and evaluation training for administrators.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Intended outcomes are to have improved cell practices by leadership and staff,

[Edouard-Vincent]: tailored instruction to improve student outcomes, targeted feedback for teachers to improve practice, school and district leaders learning and leading together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The student learning goal this year has taken a slight shift.

[Edouard-Vincent]: My first three years,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I had a primary focus on elementary mathematics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am optimistic that with the adoption of a new curriculum, a new program coming at the end of the year, that we will begin to see the needle move in the area of mathematics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, we are focusing on early literacy.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be assessing early literacy skills and implementing interventions in literacy to improve outcomes by deepening teacher and principal knowledge of early literacy practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The key actions, we will support the development and implementation of an effective early literacy program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There will be full adherence to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education Department's dyslexia guidance through the implementation of ECRI, Enhanced Core Reading Instruction Program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: ECRI implementation will be taking place during tier one ELA blocks in all grades, kindergarten to second grade, district-wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is a continued partnership with Hill for Literacy throughout the 21-22 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This embedded PD model will ensure teachers are getting sustained monthly training and coaching that will enhance and grow their instructional practice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Outcomes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Full implementation of ECRI across all K-2 classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: visible implementation of the science of reading best practices during literacy blocks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Intentional analysis of literacy outcomes at middle of the year and end of year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Conduct early literacy learning walks district-wide with a modified protocol to include our five core actions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The new Superintendent Induction Program, NESAP, is now offering consultancy sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to NESAP, MASS, Massachusetts Association of School Superintendents, is providing a specialized professional development called Leading and Learning Ready Sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The intention is to further develop skills in strategy development, data analysis, instructional leadership through the use of consultancy protocols.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, through participating in the MASS pioneer cohort of superintendents to lead district level work on racial equity, diversity, and inclusion ready practices.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will be attending monthly affinity group and monthly equity, diversity and inclusion sessions via Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Completing all assignments and or providing timely feedback during consultancy sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And consulting with the assigned coaches and or mentors on an as needed basis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The outcomes would be to further leverage the expertise and collective knowledge of graduate NISAP superintendents.

[Edouard-Vincent]: leading and learning about race, racism, diversity, equity, and inclusion ready.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A pilot superintendent leadership practice network to support DESE with future statewide initiatives that can be implemented in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those are my goals for this evening, this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, so I've attended already one session with the MSS ready group, and it is a pioneer cohort of 2425 superintendents, and it's actually.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The 25 superintendents that are involved our superintendents and or equity directors or assistant superintendents across the state.

[Edouard-Vincent]: 12 of them by Park superintendents, people that identify as people of color, and 12 are white superintendents that identify as allies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the professional development is being led by Dr. Leigh Teitel and Dr. Darnisa Amante-Jackson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so they have the cohort together as a combined cohort, and then they break out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they are doing race, equity, diversity, and inclusion work during those sessions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I want to say that it was a competitive process, and I was glad that I succeeded.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I look forward to the learning that I will have that will happen this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't have a suggestion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm willing to work on wordsmithing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just wanted to respond to say that with some of the data, when it comes to the evaluation time, I will do the same thing as attaching multiple hyperlinks that actually show proof or evidence of it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, because we just made this significant investment in the NWEA map.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is like year one, where we just were in the process of getting baseline preliminary data.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which was why I had said that I would be including middle of year and end of year not knowing what that data is going to look like but with the expectation with all of the enhanced and added intentional moves that are happening right now in the area of early literacy that I would love to see the work

[Edouard-Vincent]: The professional developments that's taking place, and then looking at the assessment data, the in house assessment data to say, are we seeing the needle move in the right direction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they're definitely.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I did not want to go and say, it's going to be 10% when it could be 5% across the board, it could be 25%, because we've never had an internal system before.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Since I've been here, we've always dealt with the MCAS, so I'm actually very excited about that investment to finally have internal data to look at to help further guide and point us in the direction to achieve increased outcomes for all of our learners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in light of the way we were doing the learning walks before, I've been talking with the administrators and directors about how will the walks look this year, where we had much larger groups observing instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if we're gonna think about it and do the work where we're not having five people potentially walk into a classroom,

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the same time, how could we still go through the experience of a walk, but with a much smaller group of people, while we're still in this, you know, almost post pandemic era, but that so that is something that we haven't formally started doing the walks but how we can go in to look at what it is that we expect to see.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're going to be.

[Edouard-Vincent]: actively out there in classrooms and looking at all of these things and documenting what we see, and I will definitely have data by the end of the year to really share to say these, this is what the data says and be able to say okay, now we have

[Edouard-Vincent]: one year of implementation, what our data looks like, so that I think moving into next year, we'd be able to say, oh, we made this percentage of growth over the course of one year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Let's see how much more growth we can make the following year and give a more measurable goal based on the data that's in front of us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just wanted to weigh in to say that last year, in light of everything that was happening with the pandemic, it was incredibly difficult, even for myself to be able to attend all of the sessions, the timing was very, very difficult.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I too would prefer to have it go through the communication subcommittee to be able to just think about the

[Edouard-Vincent]: strategic plan that we have in place and the work that we are doing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do think that the intention behind this initiative was a very good and it's a strong intention but the timing just it was overwhelming with everything that we were trying to do moving from hybrid to fully in person and trying to fully commit to what was happening during those specific points in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I don't think we participated in the initiative, but I don't really feel like we were able to get 1000% out of it just because there were too many competing interests and trying to juggle all of the balls that were being juggled last year was just too much at that point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This evening we're going to have an opportunity to look at our MCAS results.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and hoping for similar increased outcomes at the elementary levels as we're piloting new programs that are more inquiry based and really pushing those higher order thinking skills.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we do have, we do have our student representatives available Dr cushion, would you like to just give the update on our two student representatives.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it has been wonderful that we have been able to resume some of our in-person activities at the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week, we were able to dedicate the new Priscilla Hoff cosmetology program space on the vocational side of the house.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we were able to gather at the Roberts Playground for the presentation of a communication board for our nonverbal and autistic students and all students at the Roberts School, thanks to the generous donation from the Doug Flutie Jr.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Foundation for Autism, who has partnered with our police department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Brooks PTO was also able to host their fall fest yesterday, and that was a tremendous success.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition to that, we had eight of our Italian students from Medford High School who were able to attend the Cavalleria Rusticana Opera at the Boston Lyric Opera.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So those were some really positive things that have been happening within the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On that same note, last Wednesday, Medford High School hosted in-person

[Edouard-Vincent]: PSATs for 550 sophomores and juniors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That is the first time that we actually tested both sets of students at the same time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, we tested 64 of our seniors were able to take their SATs in school at Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are very grateful to Stacey Shulman, our Councilors and teachers who made this happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are thankful that they organized the testing in a safe environment and served as proctors as the tests were given.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I say it often that teamwork makes the dream work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford High School now has proper signage at the entrance way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, the official Medford High School sign was hung and is posted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to thank

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mayor Lungo-Koehn, the Building and Grounds Subcommittee, and John McLaughlin for all of their work for making this happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It looks wonderful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we wanna thank the contractor, White Light Visuals, who designed it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And last Friday, it was put in place on the front of the building, and it really looks great to have the official front entrance with a proper signage.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thursday,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had some wonderful news happening in Medford at the Mustang football game.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Mustang cheerleaders hosted cheerleader for the day for over 25 students from our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was great to see the younger students cheering alongside the high school team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Once again, it is exciting that our students can go back to mentoring our younger students, something that came to an abrupt halt due to COVID.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we have stated, these social connections are important for all of our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I want to thank the chair leaders for hosting that event and reaching out to our younger students and also congratulate the football team on another win.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we were all a little surprised and saddened to hear this morning of the passing of former Secretary of State General Colin Powell, who was not only the first African American to lead the Joint Chiefs of Staff, but also the first African American to serve as Secretary of State.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford was honored to have had General Powell visit the students at the then Brooks-Hobbs Complex in May of 1993, while he was serving President George H.W.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Bush as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During that visit, he was introduced to the students at the time, which the principal of that school was the first

[Edouard-Vincent]: African American principal in Medford Public Schools was Miss Shirley counts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So General Powell told the students to never limit their dreams, work hard, and success will always come.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May General Powell rest in peace.

[Edouard-Vincent]: CCSR.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are looking for community support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Saturday, October 30th, from 10 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 1 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: at Hormel Stadium, CCSR is hosting the Halloween Relay Race to raise funds for Hope for Haiti.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Each relay team is made up of four people, and the entry fee is $20 per team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Any student, parent, caregiver, staff person, or community member can participate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: make up your own teams and contact Mr. Michael Skorka by October 22nd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hope for Haiti works to reduce poverty in Haiti and is focused on providing support and partnership for the Haitian people.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Other upcoming events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our unified basketball team has two more home games to wrap up their successful season.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Come and cheer them on at the high school gym on Thursday, October 21 and Wednesday, November 3 at 330.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have more good news.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Another micro pantry is also coming to Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On October 20th, this coming Wednesday, the vocational school will be having a micro pantry ribbon cutting in front of the vocational entrance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's hosted by CCR and that will be taking place at 1230 on Wednesday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On the same Wednesday, October 20th, is both the college and career information

[Edouard-Vincent]: event for our students with disabilities, and their parents and caregivers from 530 to 630 in room.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And immediately following that, the college and career information fair for the entire high school complex begins at 630 in the high school gymnasium.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please be advised that face coverings must be worn by all in attendance for these in-person events.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This will be a Zoom call from six to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Andre, our adaptive PE teacher, will be the guest speaker.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On October 21st,

[Edouard-Vincent]: will be our eighth grade open house at the high school complex at 6.30 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So for all rising ninth graders, students who are currently eighth grade right now, they are invited to the Medford High School complex on October 21st at 6.30 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and that will be their open house.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On October 28th, the Missittuck Elementary School hopes to break the record for most people reading the same book on the same day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year's book is Amy Wu and the Patchwork Dragon by Cat Zhang.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I hope you, if you haven't reached out, I hope you've been tapped on the shoulder to be a reader.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, on October 29, the Medford Chamber of Commerce, they're going to resume their annual business trick or treat in the squares from three to 5pm for the community to take part in that, if they would like to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, in closing, I have one brief update on transportation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have communicated on a few occasions in the last month that we were anticipating some potential challenges regarding student transportation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These challenges are attributed to, in large part, to the nationwide shortage of bus drivers affecting so many school districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Unfortunately, today at several of our schools, those challenges came to fruition in ways that were both frustrating and confusing to many of our families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we have been working very closely with our primary bus vendor, which is Eastern Bus Company, to alleviate these challenges as quickly as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Regrettably, the challenges to the driver workforce were compounded today by some missteps in communication, particularly with regard to buses at the McGlynn, Andrews, Brooks and Missittuck schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please know that Mr. Murphy is available to take specific questions this evening, in the event that any of you have been hearing from families about these challenges, but for now we want to convey our apologies to the families who waited for incredibly long periods of time for their child's bus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and note that we are actively working to improve both the communication and logistical protocols regarding our transportation services.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's nice for me to be back in the chambers with you tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and I'm happy to share a few updates.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I wanna share that some of our Mustang science teachers took the opportunity to attend a special training at the end of the summer provided by the Life Science Change Agent Teachers Program, LSCAT.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's a free week-long professional development series by Acera EI in partnership with the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This specialized training included lab activities and gene editing with CRISPR technology, microbiomics and climate change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All three units featured relevant cutting edge technology and research aligned to next generation science standards.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my feeling that this is a great opportunity for teachers

[Edouard-Vincent]: to take issues of modern science, like gene editing and climate change, and bring it into the classroom, making a positive impact on what students will be doing in the future.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm proud that Acera EI is partnering with Medford Public Schools to bring hands-on science education to a new level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I stated in our last meeting,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford is very lucky to have such a supportive business community that assists our district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you probably know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our country, continent, as well as some of our neighboring continents to the south are named after an Italian explorer and geographer by the name of Amerigo Vespucci.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hi, Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is your proud superintendent, Dr. Edouard-Vincent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am here today to share a few updates about the reopening of schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Although it sure has felt like summer this week, with the heat and humidity we have been facing, fall is soon to come and it is back to school time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am sure all of you have a mix of emotions as we return to our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have always loved back to school time, an opportunity to meet your teachers and make new friends.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Perhaps you're even moving on up to middle school or maybe high school this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As excited as you may be, I know that many of you are a bit nervous about returning to school during this ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to assure you today that Medford Public Schools is committed to your safety and your health in all of our buildings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you may know, mask wearing is mandatory for all students and staff, and we are committed to keeping our buildings cleaned and ventilated each day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are proud of the work that we did last year with in-school COVID testing, and we are committed to continuing this partnership with Tufts University and Armstrong Ambulance to offer the same program again this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I encourage you to look out for the testing consent form in today's communication, as well as on our website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are aiming for 100% testing participation from our students this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And by signing and returning the form to your school's office, your child will be ready to participate in the program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We also encourage our Medford community to continue to be vigilant with COVID-19 preventative measures, such as wearing masks, social distancing, and diligent hand-washing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my greatest hope that all who are able get vaccinated as soon as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The vaccine has given us hope and we must continue to do our part to keep all children and our medically vulnerable persons very safe.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In closing, I encourage all of you to enjoy the sunshine this last weekend of summer for us here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I look forward to warmly welcoming all our students in grades one through 12 this Tuesday, August 31st, and to also welcome our newest Mustangs, our kindergartners, on Wednesday, September 8th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can't wait to see you, and I hope that all of you have a wonderful weekend.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Go Mustangs!

[Edouard-Vincent]: Now you're an expert.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: equity and consistency, all of the things that we did to have a successful launch to the school year, from creating schedules to eventually testing and making sure that what we did was done in an equitable way to meet the needs of our students that were both hybrid and our students that were fully remote.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was Monday all the way again to Monday all the way again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, I just wanted to note that today was definitely Flag Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This holiday came into existence on June 14th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's commemorating the date in 1777.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to highlight that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am not going to go through everything that I had to highlight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am just going to pick a few pieces.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One piece is this Thursday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: CCSR is going to be featured on Channel 5 at 7 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The segment is called Five for Good.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Erica Tarentall, she was on campus interviewing Mr. Skorger, Mr. Trotter, and our students about their different projects.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So again, I hope you'll be able to watch them on, watch the segment on Channel 5 this coming Thursday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, there's going to be a COVID-19 vaccine

[Edouard-Vincent]: for our students between ages 12 and 17.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford's Board of Health is going to be hosting the clinics on June 16th at Mystic Market from 3.30 to 6.30 and also from 3.30 to 5.30 at the Willis Ave Community Center.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On June 19th, the West Medford Community Center will be hosting the clinic from 10 a.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to noon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and then June 26th again at Mystic Market from 3.30 to 6.30 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am going to ask Dr. Cushing if he is able just to quickly show the results of a student poll.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We looked at our eighth grade students, eighth through 12th grade,

[Edouard-Vincent]: They were given three choices for signage for Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had about 350 participants.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that was the sign that the students selected that said Medford High School with the white M and the gray Mustang horse.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then above the little doorway, even though it's a little blurry, they selected home of the Mustangs to be

[Edouard-Vincent]: above the doorway.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, um, that was a student choice and this was a recommendation from the building and ground subcommittee to, um, solicit feedback from our students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to, um, of the 350 responses, uh, participants, this was the clear majority.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think the last comment that I will make is that this Saturday does mark Juneteenth.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is a new holiday for Massachusetts, but a long celebrated day for so many in our country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Emancipation Proclamation took place or took effect on January 1st, 1863, and the 13th Amendment

[Edouard-Vincent]: Abolishing slavery was passed by Congress on January 31 of 1865.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It wasn't until June 19, 1865, that the enslaved people in Texas learned that they were free.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This day became a celebration for Black Americans in Texas.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and has spread to other areas as a descendants of former slaves migrated to other parts of the country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Texas was the first state in the union to recognize the holiday in 1980.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In modern day, we have 48 states in the union that are currently recognizing the holiday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: South Dakota and Hawaii are the two abstentions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A little known fact, if Dr. Cushing is able to show the image, there is a Juneteenth flag, and Boston Ben is what he's known as.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was one of the key people who was instrumental in the Juneteenth movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But Lisa Jean Graff, who's a Boston-based illustrator, she

[Edouard-Vincent]: took the description of what they said, and she was instrumental in the design.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And the design of the Juneteenth flag depicts a bursting new star on the horizon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The star represents a new freedom, a new people, a new star.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The red, white, and blue colors communicate that the American slaves and their descendants were all Americans.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's what the Juneteenth flag looks like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I just want to say thank you to everyone, and I wish everyone a wonderful summer break, as the last day of school is at the end of this week.
