[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, Madam Mayor and members of the school committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I thank you for this opportunity to come before you and share my remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, this is your proud superintendent, Dr. Maurice Edouard Vincent.

[Edouard-Vincent]: First off this evening in my remarks tonight, sadly, I must inform you all that we recently lost a member of our Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of our culinary arts teachers at the Medford Vocational Technical High School, Mr. Dennis Moriarty.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis began his teaching career with the Medford Public Schools in 1995.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was a teacher and mentor to so many of his students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of the vocational teachers, Mr. John Brown, said the following, and so this is an excerpt of what was submitted

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Tuesday, April 27th, 2021, the Medford Public Schools lost a valuable member of the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis Moriarty dedicated 26 years of his life teaching culinary arts at the Vocational High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis had been a part of the culinary program since its humble beginnings when the only kitchen equipment was a stove and an ice box.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis was extremely proud of the culinary program and he cherished working with the youth of Medford and serving the community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis was also an avid outdoorsman who loved to spend time with friends, hunting, fishing, or riding motorcycles.

[Edouard-Vincent]: He was especially proud of catching the biggest cod on one excursion on the Bunny Clark and never missed an opportunity to show someone the sticker he received for that occasion, which he had proudly and conveniently displayed behind his desk in Cafe Electra.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Whatever Dennis caught would typically wind up on the menu at the bistro.

[Edouard-Vincent]: After a good day on a boat, Dennis would be in his glory at the bistro overseeing the students, cranking out a batch of fish cakes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was quite a sight to behold.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis will be missed by his students, colleagues, and friends.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis had the natural ability to strike up a conversation with a complete stranger as if they were old friends.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This trait enabled him to connect with his students and made them feel like they were part of something special in the culinary arts program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dennis was a part of the Medford Volk family and the greater Mustang community, and his loss leaves a void that can never be filled.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To his family and friends, we extend our deepest sympathy, and may he rest in peace.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May is the month that we honor and celebrate our teachers, our principals, and our nurses.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Especially in this past year, like no other, it's very, very well deserved that they are praised and commended for going above and beyond the call of duty during this worldwide pandemic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have simply the best Mustang staff, and that was proven once again during this very trying time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please note that this Wednesday marks the end of Ramadan for our Muslim friends, and this Thursday is Eid al-Fitr.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Eid means celebration.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Eid al-Fitr features two to three days of celebrations that include special morning prayers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: People greet each other with Eid Mubarak, meaning blessed Eid.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and with formal embraces.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Sweet dishes are prepared at home and gifts or money are given to children and to those in need.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I say early in advance, Eid Mubarak to all of those that will be celebrating the holiday this Thursday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: May is also both Asian-American

[Edouard-Vincent]: Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander Month, as well as Jewish Heritage Month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Both of these groups have experienced numerous acts of racial hate over the course of this year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools supports our Asian community, most especially during this very difficult year of pain and fear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, we support our members of the Jewish community who have also been the targets of antisemitism and white nationalism.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Both of these groups have made important contributions to our society.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the words of the Torah, justice, justice shall you pursue.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want to be very clear.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I will always speak out against any and all racist acts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is imperative that we as a community do all we can to note that hate in any form has no place in the Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At this time, I would like to send out a special congratulations to the Mustang football team

[Edouard-Vincent]: for beating Malden 24 to 21 on Saturday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was Thanksgiving in May and it resulted in a great win for Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was the first time in five years that Medford High School beat Malden.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What an exciting day for our Mustangs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is with great pleasure that I also commend one of our outstanding students, Adrita Samanta, a grade seven student at the Andrews Middle School, who received the 2021 American Mathematics Contest AMC 8 Young Women in Mathematics Award.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Adrita got a perfect score in the American Mathematics Contest 8.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Adrita was also awarded the 2021 AMC 10A Certificate of Excellence as one of the top five scorers of the AMC, American Mathematics Contest, 10A Math Contest in New England.

[Edouard-Vincent]: AMC 10A is a high school math contest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The MAA's American Mathematics Competition program leads the nation in strengthening the mathematical capabilities of the next generation of problem solvers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations to Adrita on a job well done.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A reminder for our graduating class, our seniors, class of 2021,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and the items will be ready for you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: as we look forward to graduation at Hormel Stadium on June 2nd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, next Thursday, we will be having the scholarship awards that will be given out to our recipients, our seniors, and that will be by invitation only as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On Wednesday, May 12th, the CPAC is hosting Chad Fallon, Principal Chad Fallon, for a discussion about vocational educational program for students with IEPs from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: this Wednesday evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also for your information, the Medford Vocational Technical High School will be holding the Spring Advisory Program Committee meeting via Zoom on Thursday, May 20th from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The meeting will review the fall advisory meeting minutes as well as review shop, laboratory facilities and equipment, student projects and curriculum, cooperative education and industry trends, student enrollment, placement and recommendations for equipment or budget and any new business and or general recommendations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is a public meeting for those who are interested.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For our incoming middle school families, please be advised that both the Andrews and McGlynn welcoming orientation slash open houses will not be held this week, but instead on June 9th and June 10th in the hopes that we can meet our families inside the McGlynn and Andrews schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last Wednesday,

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Roberts Elementary School celebrated Spirit Superhero Day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Each classroom, including the remote students, had a visit from Super Roberts Man.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Students in grades preschool to five were given a Superheroes card and pencil to honor them for being heroes as they managed all of the changes and transitions during the 2020-21 school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next Saturday, May 15th, from 930 to 430 p.m., rain date is Sunday, May 16th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Family Network is hosting a clothing and book swap outside in the courtyard of Medford High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Shopping is by appointment only and all shoppers must wear masks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For further information or to make an appointment, please contact the Medford Family Network at 781-393-2106.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm also happy to report some additional good news about two of our Mustang graduates who were featured in Boston Magazine's most influential Bostonians.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Class of 1990 graduate, Mr. Sean O'Brien is currently Teamsters Local 25 president.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Boston Magazine stated, there's a good chance that later this year, he could be elected general president of the entire international brotherhood of Teamsters.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, we'd like to recognize Mustang graduate, class of 2008, who is a recording artist and model.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Known as Bia, but her full name is Bianca Mikayla Landrau.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Boston Magazine noted, Sean John chose the 29-year-old rapper from Medford to be the face of his new women's wear collection.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She has a new contract with Sony Epic Records label and just won Artist of the Year at the 2020 Boston Music Awards.

[Edouard-Vincent]: she is close to having one million Instagram followers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to congratulate the both of them.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And what this says to me is that Mustangs, if you continue to work hard, hard work allows you to realize your dreams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you and have a good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want to really just extend a humongous thank you to Miss Joan Bowen, our Director of Pupil Services, because to get through the entire TFM process was a tremendous amount of work for her and her entire team.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, it seems easy just seeing that we're implementing and we're at a commendable level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But in order to get there, all of our documentation, everything had to be in order.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are so many requirements that need to be met in order to meet the standard.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so the fact that Medford really is meeting the standards set before us by the state and that we got such positive ratings, I just want to restate and really thank Joan and her entire team that helped to make it possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say that again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you so much.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay, to briefly explain the no school choice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If Medford were to participate, we would have to accept students from other communities in the Commonwealth for baseline tuition, which could be well below the actual cost of the services that we may incur.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Such acceptances would be on a seat available basis and could also affect enrollments selectively throughout the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as a result, trigger costs, which would add up to our budgetary situation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the past, the Medford School Committee has continuously expressed a desire to emphasize servicing Medford students to the best of our ability and to concentrate our efforts in that direction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am asking the school committee to reject this provision.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And my rationale is that we will not be compromising our ability to work with students in our special education programs or our chapter 74 vocational programs, which are beneficial to our overall program and financial position.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's for those reasons that I'm asking the school committee to take a vote to reject school choice for school year 21-22.

[Edouard-Vincent]: so that I may formally notify the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mayor, I have a follow-up question.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That was the recurring theme.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't know, healing about writing a poem.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And art is beautiful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And students who are choosing to be poet artists, they're expressing themselves through the written word.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It has been filling my bucket, reading these poems and just giving me such encouragement and such hope.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They realize what was happening before wasn't working.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They want to make the world a better place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I believe that this is the generation that is going to be able to do that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want to say today we're going to embark on our second budget presentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we will be hearing primarily from what's happening under our director, departments related to Joan Bowen, the Director of Pupil Services, and what is happening with special education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dave and his team, Michelle Kingdon and all the others in there have been working incredibly hard

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I look forward again to today's presentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Dave.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I actually was in agreement with Dr. Cushing's comment about the two minutes or if we're going to say up to three minutes that we respect that it's up to three minutes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: where I think, you know, with emails and allowing the opportunity for the public comment, I think that that is important, community participation, but I too feel that there needs to be clear rules that everyone understands and that they are actually followed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The other piece that I had a question or a comment about

[Edouard-Vincent]: was the addition of people not stating the duration of residency in order to be a welcoming community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I wanted to know, would this verbiage be read prior

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this would be read at every meeting, this particular paragraph that's being added onto the official agenda so that everyone would know that's the goal that we're moving towards.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just was trying to get a little greater clarity on.

[Edouard-Vincent]: not realizing that the policy changed were to state that, then what would happen during that meeting, I guess, is what I'm trying to understand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I guess I almost feel like it sounds like we're creating norms and I don't know if we should call them, call it out as norms so that if we're saying, you know, we want it to be a welcoming community that, you know, earlier you mentioned that they will address the entire school committee and not individual members through the chair.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So should we also have a statement in there about,

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, we understand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, ensuring that we want to use appropriate language and, you know, even if we're presenting divergent views, we do it in a respectful manner.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening, everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I hope everyone had a relaxing April break.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During vacation week, both Administrative Professionals Day and IRF Day were celebrated.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our administrative staff for all their dedicated service to the Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I said in my communication last Thursday, often the administrative staff is the first face of the district welcoming families to our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are instrumental in helping to keep our district running smoothly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We appreciate you and thank you for keeping all of us better connected to our Mustang community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: To celebrate Earth Day, I would like to extend my thanks to Aggie Tudin, Medford's tree warden, who will oversee the planting of some trees along Steve Miller Way.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, I would like to thank CCSR students, Babin Gill, Eleanor Nicarra, Naomi Pierre, and Oprah Nicarra.

[Edouard-Vincent]: who volunteered this past week to transfer both strawberry seedlings and cabbage seedlings into unused flower beds in the Medford High School garden.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Special thanks to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Retter-Smith for her guidance and support during this process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want to thank all who actively participated in the Columbus School renaming process, either by submitting a new name for consideration or by submitting an application to serve on the renaming committee.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my hope that this process will help to bring the community together as we move forward in deciding a new name for the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: National Honor Society Induction Ceremony.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our National Honor Society Induction Ceremony will take place this Thursday, April 29th at 7 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: via Zoom for our juniors only.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to take this opportunity to recognize all our 37 students who have been invited to join this group.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Despite the challenges of the pandemic, you are able to persevere academically, and Thursday is our day to honor you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An in-person ceremony for seniors only will take place on Tuesday, May 4th at 7 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: in the gym.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is an invitation only event and we are following all Board of Health COVID safety guidelines.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I congratulate our 49 seniors who are part of this cohort.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to extend a special thank you to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: DiPrizio, our National Honor Society advisor for supporting and encouraging our National Honor Society students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to share that 35 local organizations in Tufts host communities in Massachusetts have been awarded $35,000 in grants from the Tufts Community Grants Program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The annual grants are funded by donations from Tufts University faculty and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Two of our school-based groups were recipients of these grants.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our Center for Citizenship and Social Responsibility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: for Medford's Food Drive to help supply bagged groceries and necessities to Medford Public Schools families, and the Strong Girls United Foundation, a student athlete mentor program at the Brooks School, which includes training materials and team shirts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Medford Public Schools are grateful to Tufts University for their continued support.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For everyone's information, Tufts University announced that it has acquired doses of Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine and is setting up a vaccination clinic for their students, faculty and staff in the Gantcher Center this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Doses will be administered on April 28th through April 30th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In addition, the announcement by the University Infection Control Health Director, Michael Jordan, he also said that all students, all Tufts University students will need to be vaccinated before participating in on-campus classes or activities for next school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would also like to take this moment to thank Stop and Shop for their gracious donations of food bags to the Medford Family Network.

[Edouard-Vincent]: At least twice a month, Stop and Shop delivers these bags to Medford Family Network, who distributes them to our families in need.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Speaking of the Medford Family Network, this Thursday, April 29th, they will be presenting the 10th Annual Parent Cafe virtually from 7.30 to 9.30 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This important discussion will revolve around stressing resilience in times of stress.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are hoping for at least nine more parents to register.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those interested should contact Marie Cassidy at 781-393-8255.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As you are aware, last Monday, all Massachusetts residents over the age of 16 are now eligible to receive the COVID-19 vaccine.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our Medford Public School nurses are encouraging parents to vaccinate their children for COVID-19 as an important measure toward reducing the spread of the virus.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Parents are encouraged to pre-register their child or children for a vaccine appointment at one of Massachusetts mass vaccination sites at vaccinesignup.mass.gov.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to say that all of our fifth grade students should now know which middle school they will be attending in September.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please note that orientations will be held for students and their parents or caregivers at the McGlynn Middle School on Wednesday, May 12th from six to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and at the Andrews Middle School on Thursday, May 13th from six to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: More details to follow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd also like to announce that Medford Public Schools has temporarily suspended the use of Google Hangouts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Due to some misinformation or cyberbullying and inappropriate exchange of information taking place on Google Hangouts, we have temporarily suspended the use of that platform until we are able to put in additional measures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So the temporary suspension of Google Hangouts is still in place while we are looking for additional security measures.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lastly, I feel I would be remiss if I did not mention the decision in the Derek Chauvin case.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The jury returned guilty verdicts in the murder of George Floyd, which raises hope that our nation is changing for the better.

[Edouard-Vincent]: According to a poll conducted by UMass Amherst, it is notable that a solid majority of whites, 56%, supported the verdict.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In a nation with such a troubled racial history and present, it is extremely rare and perhaps unprecedented that a majority of whites support the conviction of a police officer for the murder of a Black man, said political science professor Jesse Rhodes, who helped conduct the poll.

[Edouard-Vincent]: An Earth Day quote seems applicable here.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We all share the same mother.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is about time we treat each other like family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have said continuously that we are one Medford, one district, the Mustang family.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yet too often in our world, black and brown lives are devalued.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We must all understand that no matter the color of one's skin, we are all human.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As our Vice President Kamala Harris stated after the verdict was read, today we feel a sigh of relief.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Still, it cannot take away the pain.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A measure of justice is not the same as equal justice.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As your superintendent, as an educator, and most importantly as a mother,

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have said that change is hard and can be messy, but it is necessary.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Conversations about race and injustice are complicated, but must be had, so the quality of life is improved for us all.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As Tyler Perry said last night at the Oscars, let us reject hate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, great job.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to thank Susie for all the extra time she put in to really beautify the calendar as well to make it more user friendly.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, Susie.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mayor?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, I just wanted to say,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Hearing what Member Graham was saying, she wanted a list of the job descriptions added.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I agree with the comments that have been said thus far.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With the September 1st deadline, that will be right at the same time with potentially onboarding last-minute hires, but

[Edouard-Vincent]: from an accountability perspective to know what the jobs are and the job descriptions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We definitely have, you know, nothing to hide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We want to have that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're in compliance with DESE.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I guess I'm just thinking we have a completely different platform called Frontline, which is where people apply for jobs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we, you know, our HR wing of the district

[Edouard-Vincent]: uses the frontline system.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so where you were saying that you also wanted something added to the website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I was actually going to be asking for greater clarity, because I do think it's, I think it's something if it's just giving you a list of jobs that were posted.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think that may be able to be doable, but I just think at this particular point in time, it's gonna be a tremendous lift on our human resources department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I know Mr. Murphy probably could speak to that as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The amount of stress that will happen just to get school started smoothly and how much activity takes place on the 1st of September.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: No curriculum has been chosen at this point in time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in regards to the working groups that are going to be working on the math department, teachers will be piloting two, including parents, two to potentially three different curricula in order to make a decision.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So while they go through the process of

[Edouard-Vincent]: screening and piloting curriculum as they go forward, it will be a fully inclusive process.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But that is something that was said at one of our first curriculum subcommittee meetings to make sure that we're being inclusive of both English learners and students with disabilities, our special needs students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And to member McLaughlin's question,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had an asterisk for June as a possible follow-up meeting on disability awareness.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this Wednesday, it'll be world language and science, and then health and phys ed will be coming up.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then we're gonna go back to disability awareness, a follow-up on where we were from the presentation that happened at the start of the school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you repeat that question, please, Member McLaughlin?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with the anti-racism curriculum under humanities right now, Dr. Chiesa is looking with her team, they are looking at supplemental pieces, including in particular, which was said earlier, the Nuzella curriculum, which is infusing greater amounts of

[Edouard-Vincent]: articles and literature about cultural proficiency, anti-racism, anti-bias work.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So it is being added or folded into the curriculum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They are working, I know that the directors are working in collaboration with their lead teachers and their teams.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is some of the work that is taking place

[Edouard-Vincent]: right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We definitely will be able to get a presentation to the school committee in the near future on all of the professional development and where curriculum shifts or intentional shifts are taking place with our curriculum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just want to say thank you to the school committee, and I look forward to serving Medford Mustangs, Mustang Nation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And next year will be a better year for all of us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I look forward to working with everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for the opportunity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Congratulations again.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Well, good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: My remarks today, there's some breaking news.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In Knoxville, the Knoxville Police Department in Tennessee said that multiple agencies are at the scene of a shooting at Austin East Magnet High School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One person died and the shooter is in custody.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Before I begin, I'd like to bring your attention to the following.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last night, an African-American male, Dante Wright, was killed by police in Minnesota yesterday, less than 10 miles away from where Mr. George Floyd was killed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A curfew of 5 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: was put in place by the mayor of Brooklyn Center, a suburb of Minneapolis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, I would like to read a statement from the Minnesota twins.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Out of respect for the tragic events that occurred yesterday in Brooklyn Center.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and following the additional details in this evolving situation, the Minnesota Twins have decided it is in the best interest of our fans, staff, players, and community to not play today's game against the Red Sox.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While we don't know what exactly happened, an investigation is ongoing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We send prayers to Mr. Wright's family and all involved.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While discussing these events, I also must state how grateful I am that the Medford Human Rights Commission led another community conversation on the uncomfortable, yet extremely important need for racial equity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to thank Mayor Lungo-Koehn, Chief Jack Buckley, and Mary Ann O'Connor of the Board of Health, who realized the importance of addressing these issues of race in our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, there were over 140 members of the community who actively participated in last Wednesday night's discussion.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Special thanks to Mr. Neil Osborne for organizing these ongoing community conversations as we work together to improve the quality of life for all in our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to say this quote to share with you a quote from Jackie Robinson.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not concerned with you liking or disliking me.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All I ask is that you respect me as a human being.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So as we think about the things that are continuing to happen across the country, let's remember that we should treat one another as human beings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So just transitioning, I would like to say today was the first week of four-day instruction for our students in grades six through 12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Following April vacation on Monday, April 26th, we will return to five days of instruction for our students in grades six through 12 as we continue to increase normality in our schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week,

[Edouard-Vincent]: or this past week that just happened, we began five-day instruction for all elementary schools K through five.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they are now on their second week of five days of instruction at the K through five level.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would also like to take a moment to just thank Congresswoman Catherine Clark for choosing to visit the McGlynn School Complex last Thursday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She wanted to see the testing and the students in the classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Both the mayor and myself thanked her for the assistance of the Federal CARES Act monies.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Congresswoman spoke to us about the importance of passing the American Rescue Plan, another COVID-19 relief package that could see Medford receive an additional $5 million.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She explained that the funding is intended to help schools

[Edouard-Vincent]: with HVAC improvements, technology and PPE, as well as helping students to make up for lost learning time, potentially in the form of summer school or afterschool programs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: She was very impressed with the students COVID testing themselves and loved interacting with our elementary students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: A special thank you again to Congresswoman Catherine Clark for coming to Medford Public Schools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I also want to thank the members of the community who participated in our roundtable discussions last week around the Medford Public Schools strategic plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, I would like to thank members of the cabinet and department heads who actively participated in these important conversations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please know that we will utilize the feedback as we continue to move forward on the district's plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'd like to say that this evening begins Ramadan for our Muslim families, friends, and neighbors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ramadan continues until May 12th and is considered the most sacred month for the whole Muslim Umar, which means community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During Ramadan, you ask for forgiveness.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You exercise self-control.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You try to experience the life of the have-not, experiencing what the have-nots experience all the time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It teaches empathy, putting yourself in someone else's shoes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For example, if you thought of a have-not, it could be someone who's homeless temporarily.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my hope that during this holy season, happiness and joy will fill your homes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ramadan Kareem, which is said in the Middle East, or Ramadan Mubarak, which is said in Asian countries, such as Malaysia or Pakistan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What that means is enjoy the blessings of this holy month.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last week,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford resident Lauren Stern, who works for iRobot, visited Mrs. Lasky's remote fourth grade class at the McGlynn Elementary School as part of a computer class lesson about robotics and algorithms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Stern presented fun examples, particularly on ways Roomba reacts or performs in action.

[Edouard-Vincent]: During the interactive presentation, students asked questions and engaged in dialogues about robots.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Special thanks to Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lasky and computer teacher, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Elias, who organized the presentation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Marino.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There are a few important dates that I wanna highlight coming up this week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This Thursday on April 15th, from three to 4 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Parents and guardians and caregivers, you are invited to call in for the drawing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All results will be posted on our website and blog, and it will be available within a few hours of the drawing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If you have not received or if you've replaced your child's unique identification number, please reach out to Dr. Bernadette Riccidelli and she will be able to assist you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Her email is briccidelli, B-R-I-C-C-I-A-R-D-E-L-L-I at medford.k12.ma.us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So please send in your applications.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We don't want you to miss the deadline.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: is April vacation week from April 19th through the 23rd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there will be no instruction during that time.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Nurse Toni Rae will also mention this in her presentation later, but please keep in mind COVID safety travel is incredibly important when we're talking about return to school instructions.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please note that the last day of school for this school year 2021 will be Friday, June 18th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And lastly, I would like to take a moment to remember an important anniversary that is coming up this Thursday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Back in 2013, on Patriots Day, April 15th, the sunny spring day brought with it the usual, the ride of Paul Revere, the Red Sox playing at Fenway Park, and the running of the Boston Marathon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: but the day quickly turned dark as the marathon became the site of terrorist bombings.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of our own Medford Mustangs, Crystal Campbell, was lost on that horrible day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This Thursday, it is my hope that you will take a moment and remember those both lost and injured on one Boston day with reflection, prayer, and unity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're doing the work and member Graham, you did a great job explaining it in the elementary group, just about why, the why behind a strategic plan and how it really allows a district to have all of their work, kind of the work that's pushing us and moving us forward housed in one place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it was a requirement of the new superintendent's induction program.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it is something that we look forward to finalizing.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But even as we say, finalizing that document, it's a living, breathing document.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so it's never in its final phases.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It can kind of continue to change and grow and evolve.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I wanna just thank

[Edouard-Vincent]: all the parents who are on the call today to give their feedback and share their concerns, share their feedback, give us information so that we can take it, bring it back to the larger group and work on making revisions and improving our strategic plan.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just want to thank everyone who's on the call tonight.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, so what I had wanted to say, thank you for just quoting that, because I appreciate both David and Colin sharing their perspectives and giving feedback.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I was going to say that we're actually following the law that, and in Medford, I think the thinking behind having the two representatives at one point in time

[Edouard-Vincent]: Where we had both the high school and the vocational school, those are the two kind of we trying to take one person from each side, because the school kind of has two personalities if we can use that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: image but the intent was we always had one student at one meeting so they would alternate because pre-COVID times students were part of the band or they had you know practice and football games or whatever the case may be so I think the two the two members would alternate if there was maybe a test

[Edouard-Vincent]: the following day, then the other person could do it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So they kind of had like a backup responsibility.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I wanted to say, you know, when I think about this, I think of this experience as like a precursor or practice for those who would consider

[Edouard-Vincent]: becoming elected officials that you the school committee members were elected, you know, by the public.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, as elected officials, I do feel that you guys should

[Edouard-Vincent]: be the voting members because there is information that you're privy to that not everyone would be privy to in your official role as school committee members.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But I do like the idea of having a more active student council, I guess the way they were describing, you know, who the,

[Edouard-Vincent]: representatives would be etc.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just had wanted to say that we're following the law, and that in other, I think the newspaper article where the student did comment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: about providing specific opinions or feedback and the student was not allowed or they were not allowed to speak.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think in Medford, if Colin or David raises their hand and we see it, I've seen the chair or other members acknowledge and say a student's raising their hand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when we're eventually back in the chambers,

[Edouard-Vincent]: you could see one another.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when you raised your hand, it was like, oh, Colin's raising his hand, David's raising his hand.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, there was a little button and they would come over and speak into the microphone and go back and sit down.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel

[Edouard-Vincent]: The fact that, you know, we're on COVID time and that the meetings are taking place remotely.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we're not always all on the same exact page.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, if there are hundreds of people on the call, someone could be in another page, and if they don't use the raise hand function, sometimes you're just not seen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are a lot of limitations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I think that I don't want you, Colin or David, to feel like we don't value what you have to say, or we don't want to hear what it is that's being said.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I, you know, I know Mr. DeLeva's on the call.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Cushing's on the call.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You know, Ms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Galusi, we would love.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Riccadeli's on the call.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have administrators who would love to be able to

[Edouard-Vincent]: receive additional student feedback and even possibly ask for a school committee member to be a liaison or to also work with that because I think in some communities that might be that a school committee member is kind of elected

[Edouard-Vincent]: or selected to be the official point person between the student voice and the school committee body.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that person can kind of mentor and help to say, David has something to say today, or Colin's gonna be bringing something forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there would be a specific school committee person helping to

[Edouard-Vincent]: navigate that pass.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say we are, you know, taking little notes here and, you know, I'm really happy to see how the two of you have really been thinking about how you can increase

[Edouard-Vincent]: you know, student voice, and we're definitely open to that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But there are some guidelines, because we do need to follow the law, that we are, there is a slight restriction about that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just wanted to say that piece.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And thank you, Member Ruseau, for adding the law, Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 71, Section 38M.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you for that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, we will.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will use a very similar format to what happened last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So, um, I would say you should expect it from every department.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The department heads have already been told that we're going to be following a similar format to what we did last year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am going to be speaking to it in my remarks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Okay.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I mentioned in my Friday message, I have mentioned many times before that we all have a duty to stand up against all forms of racism.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Tonight, I wanna make it clear that the Medford Public Schools stands with our Asian American and Pacific Islander communities.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Last Tuesday, in three separate shootings in Atlanta,

[Edouard-Vincent]: eight Asian women were killed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are keeping all those affected by this senseless tragedy in our prayers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, we have heard stories of Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders being both harassed and abused throughout our country.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is both frightening and disgraceful.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Our district is committed to doing the work to create equity, inclusivity, and belonging for all in our community.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It is my hope that we can all come together and join Mayor Lungo-Koehn, the Board of Health, Medford's Human Rights Commission, the Medford Police Department, and the schools as we participate in a community conversation entitled

[Edouard-Vincent]: racism is a public health crisis.

[Edouard-Vincent]: What does this mean?

[Edouard-Vincent]: And how can the city address this crisis?

[Edouard-Vincent]: It will be held on Wednesday, April 7th, from six to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: via Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I applaud the mayor, Chief Buckley, Mary Ann O'Connor, and our diversity director, Mr. Neil Osborne, for organizing this crucial conversation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: we support hashtag stop Asian hate, hashtag support AAPI, Asian American and Pacific Islanders.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On March 10th, the school committee held a committee of the whole with the goal of launching the Columbus Elementary School Renaming Advisory Committee, which will review all suggestions for a new name for the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: While the task of creating the committee was accomplished, the means by which this was achieved was painful at times.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Some conversations in the meeting involved angry and derogatory language.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I know that the decision to change the name of the Columbus School is a controversial one, and especially upsetting to many long-term residents of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Unprofessional and unkind statements were not the positive displays of civic discourse.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We should be modeling for our children.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am hopeful that we can work together as one Medford to be better to each other and to overcome our disagreements constructively and considerably.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The renaming committee

[Edouard-Vincent]: will select three finalists for consideration by the school committee who will vote on the new name sometime in the late spring of 2021.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Interested parties who may want to apply to serve on the renaming committee can access an application on our website, the city's website, our blog, Facebook, and Twitter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For those who just want to suggest a new name, you may do so by completing that form on the website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All applications to serve on the renaming committee and any submissions for suggested new names must be forwarded to my office by 5 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: on Friday, April 16th, 2021.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Changing topics.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am pleased to announce that Ed Week, a school-based national publication, contacted our public relations office seeking input for their article entitled, Should Schools Test Students and Staff for COVID-19?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Medford has truly been a leader in this arena.

[Edouard-Vincent]: allowing us to bring students back into our schools sooner than most of our surrounding districts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We could not have done this without the help and support of the City of Medford, Tufts University, and the Broad Institute.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Both our assistant superintendent, David Murphy, and our director of health services, nurse Toni Wray, were quoted in the article and photos were taken of elementary students being tested at the McGlynn Middle School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The Mustangs are certainly leading the charge to protect our students and staff in order to bring our students back safely to in-school learning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to take this opportunity to extend my sincere thanks to our students, staff, and parents and guardians and our school committee members for actively taking part in our listening sessions regarding school during COVID-19.

[Edouard-Vincent]: When we planned these sessions, we did not yet know that the Massachusetts Education Commissioner would soon issue a statement mandating that districts abandoned the hybrid learning model, therefore increasing in-person learning for all students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This declaration has created some confusion for families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Remote students are able to remain remote students

[Edouard-Vincent]: but we know that there will be a small number of families who wish to switch models and have their students transfer from remote to in-person instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The deadline for making that switch is this Friday, March 26th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We currently have approximately 575 students who are fully remote at the elementary levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As of this morning, we have received 61 requests from families that would like to participate in in-person instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please do not miss this deadline of this Friday to notify us of your decision at the elementary levels.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to provide some greater clarification.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I reached out personally to the Commissioner of Education to ensure that Medford is properly following the guidance from DESE.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This week,

[Edouard-Vincent]: March 22nd, we have invited our younger elementary students, both kindergarten and grade one hybrid students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They have increased their in-school time to four days a week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next week, our second and third grade students will increase their in-school learning time to four days a week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please note that all elementary students switching from remote to in-person will return on Monday, April 5th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Again, all fully remote families that have selected to return to in-person instruction will return to school for five days of full instruction starting on Monday, April 5th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Next week, principals will be reaching out to families to notify them about their child's assignment for the week of April 5th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The principals will be reaching out specifically to students that were formerly in the fully remote model to set up that scheduling.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So in order to mitigate the impact of additional students from our remote cohorts, we do require extra planning time to make this happen as seamlessly as possible.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And in speaking with the Commissioner and explaining to him what Medford is doing to meet the deadline of April 5th, we are following the guidance that was provided by the Department of, by DESE, the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Transitioning, I would like to let the community know about some important events that are happening soon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The emergency preparedness Zoom presentation will be held this Wednesday, March 24th, from 6 to 8 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This presentation is being hosted by the Massachusetts Office on Disability and the Department of Homeland Security, and supported by the Medford Public Schools Universal Safety Committee, the Medford Special Education PAC, the Medford Family Network, the Medford Fire and Police Departments, and the City of Medford's Disability Commission.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This presentation will better inform our most vulnerable citizens to be best prepared to respond to an evacuation or shelter in place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We hope you can join us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: CCSR has planned

[Edouard-Vincent]: An April Fool's run between April 1st and April 3rd.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Donations are encouraged, but 100% optional.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Please plan to wear a mask while running.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Stay six feet apart from others and do not run in large groups.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additional information can be found on CCSR's website and the school blog.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This will provide an opportunity for the public to comment on the school's draft strategic plan and the draft strategic plan that the administration and staff have been working on for the past year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We hope you can join in with us on either April 5th or 6th via Zoom.

[Edouard-Vincent]: to 1 p.m.

[Edouard-Vincent]: behind the McGlynn School.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For a small fee, they will be collecting TVs, computer monitors, fax machines, cell phones, and other battery-operated or electric equipment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: please support the Citywide Elementary Alliance.

[Edouard-Vincent]: You can find the application on our human resources page on the website.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These positions will help us as we are transitioning to five days a week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So lastly, I would like to say, before our next school committee meeting on April 12th, we have many people in the community who will be celebrating Passover and Easter.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For our Jewish friends, Passover begins on Saturday, March 27th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Holy week is next week for Christians.

[Edouard-Vincent]: and Easter or Resurrection Sunday is on April 4th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For those of you who celebrate these holy days, I wish you peace and happiness with your families.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Happy spring to everyone.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I cannot definitively say that there will be a no go.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think, especially in getting guidance directly from the Commissioner and the Assistant Commissioner over the weekend and up until this morning.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In some situations where a classroom could potentially, and again, not having all the numbers, which was the reason why I wanted to present the elementary numbers, approximately 575 students at the elementary level that are fully remote.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And as of this morning, 61 students

[Edouard-Vincent]: or 61 families have opted to transition from fully remote to in-person.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But we're not sure of what the numbers are going to be by Friday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So if in the event that we were to end up with 250, 300 parents that

[Edouard-Vincent]: are fully remote that end up stating they want to become fully in person.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I don't think the numbers would be that high, but if something like that were to happen, we would then be in a position to not be able to operationalize it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We have a lot of constraints with how many students can fit in a classroom, what's the total amount of students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Even with merging right now, looking at the numbers, our current

[Edouard-Vincent]: hybrid classrooms.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I don't want to say that it would never happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In some schools, there's significantly higher enrollment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So you could have a school that may have 14 or 15 students and another class in another building may have 23 students or 24 students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so when you collapse and put the two hybrid classes together, you come up with a class size and looking at the square footage, respecting the three feet of distance right now and making sure that the students fit and that we're following all of the guidelines that need to be followed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would not wanna say that it would

[Edouard-Vincent]: never happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And also, we have another situation where you could have at a particular grade level that may have 16 or 17 students and 14 or 15 of them are requesting to come back

[Edouard-Vincent]: to participate in full in-person instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Those are the kinds of pieces of data and looking at the numbers that we have to be able to figure out.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Total number of students, capacity within the given classrooms, and who the instructors are going to actually be.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the case of the example that you quoted, Mr. Russo, about one of our schools that was oversubscribed and we ended up adding two teachers.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we don't have a classroom space that would be able to accommodate

[Edouard-Vincent]: 30 students at the elementary levels per se.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so for something like that, we would have to uncouple and figure out if we had 15 of the 30 students request in-person instruction,

[Edouard-Vincent]: And there were two teachers who were working cooperatively with a group of students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: If 15 of the 30 wanted to return, then we would need to ask for one of the two teachers, one would remain remote and one would physically come on campus because to be able to accommodate 15 potentially remote students all at the same exact grade level,

[Edouard-Vincent]: and the hybrid classrooms that have already been merged are near capacity, there wouldn't be any room.

[Edouard-Vincent]: we would then be out of compliance because we would have too many students in one particular space.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is not operationally, it's a lot of work that it's gonna require.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are working on that and looking carefully at the numbers that are coming in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And our priority is always the students, but we also are now working with

[Edouard-Vincent]: The guidance from DESE, and again, as I said, I reached directly out to the commissioner to receive clarification and greater understanding so that I am conveying accurate information that I received up until today.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In all circumstances, yes, we are going to try to not disrupt, but to guarantee you know 100% that that isn't that that would not happen in a possibility of a few cases where we have.

[Edouard-Vincent]: larger numbers of students that would not be able to fit into a given classroom, then I would be not honest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then we would be having a conversation where you would say, on March 22, you said to us, this would never happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it happened in three situations.

[Edouard-Vincent]: In the spirit of

[Edouard-Vincent]: full disclosure and transparency.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are closely monitoring kindergarten and third grade in two elementary school buildings right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Closely monitoring those rooms because we are perilously close to maximum capacity.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And all the principals met this morning with assistant superintendent Galusi

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we are closely monitoring those numbers, but we did give families the opportunity until March this Friday, March 26, to give us their final response.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so wanting to communicate frequently, being fair, and letting families know if we're going to make this work,

[Edouard-Vincent]: keeping safety, equity, and consistency as our priorities, then depending on the numbers, we may have to, in some situations, make an adjustment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want you to know that we're not trying to disrupt or pull someone away, but we're watching kindergarten.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're closely watching third grade.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Unfortunately, those are the two grade levels where it seems like thus far we've had the most movement and we do not want to deny families the opportunity to come back for in-person instruction as that was a mandate given to all districts by the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I want you to know we will do our best to not disrupt

[Edouard-Vincent]: but we're closely monitoring the numbers and we are not sure what the final count will be on this Friday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Thank you, member Graham.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I do want to say that I did mean to mention that the Medford Public Schools also does not support bullying of other parents in any way, shape or form.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Dr. Edward-Vinson?

[Edouard-Vincent]: In terms of the timetable, I just want to present the parallel timetable because Dr. Chiesa alluded to it, but just to give some greater specificity,

[Edouard-Vincent]: At the elementary level, the math screening team is reconvening in the late spring, and so the top two of the five programs that were being screened

[Edouard-Vincent]: are going to be piloted in September of 21.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So when we're thinking about a capacity and learning issue in September of this year, to

[Edouard-Vincent]: different math curriculum, they're going to be piloted throughout the district.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Teachers are going to need to receive that professional development.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And once the piloting of the two programs is done, we're going to make a recommendation to the school committee, same time next year, so that in March of 22, the recommendation to the school committee would be to pick

[Edouard-Vincent]: one of the two programs based on what was piloted district-wide.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so we would be essentially replicating that same exact process for ELA, but at least giving the

[Edouard-Vincent]: the teachers an opportunity to be able to focus on piloting a curriculum at a time so that when they're implementing the new math curriculum, they'll be piloting the new literacy curriculum.

[Edouard-Vincent]: if that helps with the timetable.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because to try to launch two totally different contents at the same exact time, you really need to give the educators an opportunity to be able to have that professional development, finish that process, and then restart it again with the next content area.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I can just say yes to what you said.

[Edouard-Vincent]: The children right now, we know that teaching under these conditions, a lot has happened from social emotional learning concerns to gaps that have taken place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we're already thinking about what are the modifications that need to be made?

[Edouard-Vincent]: How can we find ways to creatively close the gaps

[Edouard-Vincent]: What are the power standards that are going to be expected of us either being announced this year or for next year?

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we are definitely in the beginning phases of trying to map out what that's going to look like.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's definitely on our radar.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And just as we receive more information and think about where we are, where Medford is at, we will definitely be able to present

[Edouard-Vincent]: to the committee, you know, what our proposals would be, but it definitely is on our radar.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I want you to know that and, you know, the listening audience to know that we're very aware of that.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we know that we're not alone, but we're going to get through it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will come up with a plan and we will, you know, stick to that plan and work it to meet the needs of our students here in Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That is correct.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, he is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Good evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Today is International Women's Day, a global day celebrating the social, economic, cultural and political achievements of women.

[Edouard-Vincent]: which began in 1911.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This year, the theme is hashtag choose challenge.

[Edouard-Vincent]: From challenge comes change.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am proud that Medford is a community that values female voices at the table.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Celebrating women's achievements only helps to forge equality.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Also, I have some positive news to share.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This week's COVID-19 testing program, we administered over 2,700 tests, and I'm pleased to report that after three days of testing, our Mustang community yielded zero positive cases.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Additionally, earlier this week, or last week, Governor Baker announced that teachers and staff

[Edouard-Vincent]: in K through 12 education and early education and care would soon be eligible to take their vaccine.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this is a critical step, a critical next step toward restoring a sense of normalcy for our students and for all of Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So with the continued decline in virus positivity rates and the stated intention of the Commissioner of Ed to soon require modification around structured learning time, we are taking active steps to prepare for the likelihood of the increase of in-person instruction.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This effort toward restoring more normalcy is an important step in helping our students to prepare for next school year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Obviously, our hope for next year will be to open and be continuing to provide instruction for the full week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Working towards that goal,

[Edouard-Vincent]: Um, preparation will begin to take place right now.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We are continuing to wait for additional guidance this week from the commissioner regarding his announcement that was made on Friday.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Um, the focus would be to start with elementary schools and eventually stagger that out six through 12.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This week we have a time-sensitive request that we asked of the parent community of students that are in grades six through 12 that we are asking that you would confirm which cohort your child is in by this Friday, March 12th.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There is an exception for remote learning due to COVID-related circumstances.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, we do need to have accurate accounting of which cohort students are involved in.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so, in person attendance for all students in grades six through 12, starting effective next Monday, March 15.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And again, your identification of which cohort you are in and your participation in extracurricular activities will be contingent upon the adherence to the in-person attendance and scheduling expectations for your cohort.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this week, or this past week, I should say on Thursday,

[Edouard-Vincent]: We had the opportunity to hear from our elementary students, parents, caregivers, and members of our staff at the elementary levels regarding their expectations this year and their expectations for next year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It was a wonderful conversation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Many members of the school committee were able to join different portions of the listening sessions that took place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thank you, school committee members, for your support

[Edouard-Vincent]: attendance last week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to remind everyone that tomorrow, March 9th, we will be holding another listening session for our middle school students, and a similar session on Thursday, March 11th, for our high school students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We will be having similar listening sessions for all of our cohorts, A, B, C, and D, and we would like to

[Edouard-Vincent]: provide our seniors with an opportunity to be able to share their specific concerns as seniors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So March 11th, this Thursday, we want to hear from you.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Translation will be available both tomorrow and on Thursday in the following languages, Portuguese, Spanish, Haitian Creole, and Arabic.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Closed captioning is also available.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I would like to take this opportunity to thank DA Marion Ryan and her amazing staff of assistant DAs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Alia Khalidi, Doug Cannon, Catherine Folger, Adrian Lynch, Tom Ralph, Tom Brandt, Beth Dunigan, Alice Casey, and D.A.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Ryan's press director, Megan Kelly, for their important presentation on racial equity, anti-bias, and white privilege for our teachers and staff.

[Edouard-Vincent]: These difficult conversations need to be had in order for our community to be more unified.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I appreciate District Attorney Ryan's leadership on these issues as we continue to move forward together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I have some wonderful news to share.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Math Counts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It provides engaging math programs to middle school students of all ability levels to build confidence and improve attitudes about math and problem solving.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For only the second year, Medford's Club participated in the Math Counts Math Competition, a national middle school math competition

[Edouard-Vincent]: I am pleased to announce that Adrita Samant, a 7th grade student at the Andrews Middle School

[Edouard-Vincent]: finished in sixth place in the Math Counts Chapter Invitational.

[Edouard-Vincent]: By doing so, she has qualified for the state rounds of the competition that will take place in three weeks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: This competition began with a total of 2,000 students from all over Massachusetts.

[Edouard-Vincent]: only 300 students qualified for the chapter invitational, out of which Adrita is one of only 45 students who have qualified for the state invitational.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I just want to say congratulations to you, Adrita.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Make us proud and try your best.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We're very happy that you made this great accomplishment.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I look forward to hearing how the competition goes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Um, believe it or not, almost a year ago, Wednesday, March 10th, it's going to mark the one year anniversary that governor Baker issued a lockdown to stop the spread of the mysterious COVID-19 virus at the time, believe it or not, it's already been a year.

[Edouard-Vincent]: There was so much that was unknown.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Then we all assumed.

[Edouard-Vincent]: we'd be back to our regular schedules after a few weeks.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Obviously, that did not happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: All of us have been affected in some way by the virus, whether medically, financially, educationally, and or socially.

[Edouard-Vincent]: With the advent of the vaccine, we do see normalcy returning soon.

[Edouard-Vincent]: However, we must continue to wear our masks

[Edouard-Vincent]: social distance, wash our hands, and most importantly, work together.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As I have always said, we are one district, one Medford.

[Edouard-Vincent]: As we move forward in our uncertain world, the Medford Public Schools remains dedicated to providing a safe, equitable, and consistent education for all of our students with a strong focus on social emotional health.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So later today, coming up, you're going to hear an update from our nurse, Toni Wray, on what's happening with COVID-19.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And then after that, I will be announcing our poetry winners.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So that is to come, our unity poem.

[Edouard-Vincent]: that were selected, and they will be sharing their poems with us this evening.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So thank you, and those are my remarks for the day.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yes, that is accurate.

[Edouard-Vincent]: One of the observations that has been occurring, which prompted us to ask, notify parents and have them clarify what cohort their child is participating in,

[Edouard-Vincent]: because we have students who were signed up for cohorts, cohort B or cohort C, and there was inconsistent attendance and participation.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so for the purposes of reporting to DESE and also having an accurate record of attendance and data, there were different codes.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so students would come one week and then

[Edouard-Vincent]: go and be remote the following week and then come back another week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there's been a lot of inconsistency.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So this declaration of cohorts is really

[Edouard-Vincent]: mostly geared towards students that are in cohort B, cohort C, who are fluctuating back and forth between B and D or C and D. So there was a back and forth movement.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that was, the amount of movement was concerning because we're trying to keep accurate attendance records and we need to be able to plan accordingly

[Edouard-Vincent]: And even from instructional perspectives, where the teachers were expecting a cohort to be one size, and there were X amount of students one week, and then the following week, you're left with very, very small numbers of students.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And they said, this particular week, I'm going to be a fully remote student.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there was too much fluctuation going back and forth, and we truly needed to have

[Edouard-Vincent]: consistency and parents to also be notified and aware that this fluctuation was taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So by parents making the declaration for us on this Friday, effective Monday, March 15th, when attendance is being documented and recorded, we're gonna be using that new data to have it properly reflected.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Can you say that there are two days a week currently?

[Edouard-Vincent]: once it is in place, once we receive the final guidance, because Friday evening's decision from the board meeting, we were watching it in real time as were most people when that came forward.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So once we get to the high school level, it will be the five days a week.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Right.

[Edouard-Vincent]: From an accounting perspective of being able to know who's supposed to be in the building and who is not.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We took a lot, it took a lot of time to set up the schedule to set up the cohorts to try to keep the numbers manageable and the the flip flopping that was taking place.

[Edouard-Vincent]: it just wasn't being done in a consistent, from an operational perspective, it was very difficult with accountability, I would say, even if they were showing up online.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so again, from accurately documenting the attendance, knowing who's in the building, who was not in the building, and again, parents also saying my child's in school, cohort B or cohort C, but

[Edouard-Vincent]: that not happening on a consistent basis as well.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Dr. Cushing or Mr. Murphy, either of you could speak to the need to have this clearly documented.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And Dr. Maurice, yes, please.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I just was going to actually echo those sentiments that it definitely was the unexpected turn of events with the pandemic last year with this permanent shutdown in March and not knowing what was going to happen and just remembering it seems like it was a century ago.

[Edouard-Vincent]: were adding HEPA filters and just focusing on getting the air quality up and running for the buildings, that that's what ended up being our priority for the fall.

[Edouard-Vincent]: But now that we're coming into the spring, this definitely is a priority for us.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I mean, it's on our radar and we will work with that before going into another winter season.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Member Koretz, are you able to stop screen share?

[Edouard-Vincent]: Yeah, I think with the, the architecture and structure of the building where there is so much concrete.

[Edouard-Vincent]: facing that there definitely are opportunities to definitely add additional enhancements, even the area where Dr. Cushing was just talking about when you come up the hill.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I still know though, from just having been in the district for the three years that I've been there, people who are coming to the high school for the first time or are not familiar with it,

[Edouard-Vincent]: it's difficult to know where the front of the school is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we end up saying, if you find the big tall flagpole and the island in the middle, but as people come up, sometimes they end up going straight to the West courtyard, or even if they're trying to find how to access the pools.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So I do feel like,

[Edouard-Vincent]: whatever the wording could be, if we can work with our vocational students, which would be fabulous.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Mr. Donovan's picture where he had the lighting on the inside and just having something where people will know this is the official front door of the school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I think to have some kind of a marker just to be able to say this is your front door,

[Edouard-Vincent]: This is the official main entrance where when you walk into that entrance, you're greeted by, you know, the security booth and, you know, they can send you upstairs, downstairs.

[Edouard-Vincent]: That's the official main entrance because people do try to come through other doors because they don't know.

[Edouard-Vincent]: They try to come through side doors.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so I do feel as we think about

[Edouard-Vincent]: even though it would be for a short period of time, to add a little landscaping to the front of the high school, having clear signage, a bigger sign on the official front doors so people will know this is the main entrance, that would be my recommended priority.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And we could definitely use the other sections where we have large amounts of just, you know, that cement canvas, concrete canvas to be able to say, you know, whether it's the mesh sign or if it's having Mustangs

[Edouard-Vincent]: running toward the front door.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So we could say, oh, when you see the horses running to the right, follow the horses.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And so instead of saying follow the arrow, people will follow the horses and say, okay, I'm making my way to the front door.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So there are a couple of ways we can try to be funny and play on the Mustang nation, but think of a way to use that blank canvas

[Edouard-Vincent]: and at the same time, point people in the direction of where the actual front door is.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Because, you know, with paint, with additional lighting, with additional shrubbery, the building has the potential to look beautiful while we're waiting to figure out what needs to happen.

[Edouard-Vincent]: It's, you know, maybe I've watched too much HGTV sometimes, but...

[Edouard-Vincent]: When you look at things and you just see, wow, all they did was paint it.

[Edouard-Vincent]: For those of you, believe it or not, it was a year ago, last February, I believe, when we did the beautification project in the front foyer, the lobby of the high school.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that day, the Sunday, that everyone was just in there painting.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And when everyone came in, it was like, wow.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And that was just...

[Edouard-Vincent]: blue and white paint.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And it just lifted the lobby because the lobby felt, I don't know, you know, there wasn't enough lighting and it felt dark.

[Edouard-Vincent]: So just by adding, you know, our colors to the inside, it made a difference.

[Edouard-Vincent]: And I do think putting some of the shrubbery, getting signage up, you know,

[Edouard-Vincent]: If we can have it done by our students, our students would take greater ownership.

[Edouard-Vincent]: I'm not sure, we'd have to speak specifically with Mr. Fallon about do we have the right equipment to be able to.

[Edouard-Vincent]: We do have the 3D machines.

[Edouard-Vincent]: Lisa Hughes wanted to do something locally and came across our poetry contest.

[Edouard-Vincent]: On President's Day last week via Zoom, Lisa interviewed Violet Bell and Ibrahim Ammar from the Roberts, both remote learners who also submitted poems.
